reviews.review: Beautiful museum. Lovely museum with a great selection of azuelos. Be warned - there's no air conditioning so don't go on a super hot day like we did. While it's easy to get a tuktuk or taxi to get there, it's much harder to get one to leave as it's quite far out of the old own. We ended up walking back.

Beautiful , easy , worth it. The entrance was quaint and lovely , the courtyard behind The cafe was perfect , the prices reasonable.... Then the main course.... The tiles ..... They had a link that you can access a guide through your smartphone , but I was too busy taking pics, so I wish I had another alternative. When you think of "tile museum" it simplifies the beautiful art form inside a perfect Lisbon location .... A convent! It is much more than what you think a tile museum would be like.... And to me, the best is culminating in an actual chapel/church combining tiles and the typical Manueline style of the country.... Odd and interesting were the choir chairs - behind them , on each back rest ,were some interesting, some gruesome reliquaries that you might miss because you are in awe of what lies ahead . It's truly a special , unique, tastefully presented museum and delivering more than what you expect ...

An excellent resonance of Portuguese history and soul. A charming piece of architecture with many different styles of tiles. I found the religious ones less interesting but, obviously an important part of the culture. The small chapel is impressive. One can follow the Moorish influences and I personally found those tiles more impressive. There is a beautiful garden and a nice cafe, also decorated with tiles. If it happens your trip coincides with the first Sunday of the month, the entrance is free.

Amazing Art. I've never seen such beauty. Don't understand why there's always so much talk about other European countries,and Portugal always getting left behind. It's one of the oldest European countries with so much history and so much that the rest of the world owes to their people, their nevigators and what they discovered. They brought everyone together by their discoveries.

A great unique museum. Catch the 357 bus from Apollinaire station .......its 10 mins going north along the railway line. Restored with Euro Community monies this museum is top class with a very interesting historic overview. The entry includes the magnificent church and associated rooms
Impressive tiles. Went here because we had the "go Lisbon card", otherwise probably would have skipped it, ended up enjoying it - impressive tile artwork.

'don't miss the tile museum'. When she heard that we were off to Lisbon a neighbour told us 'don't miss the tile museum' did not describe it, just said we would see when we got there! It is a lovely peaceful building, with a shady courtyard where we had a coffee and after securing a very good map rooms full of tiles tracing the history from earliest Moorish patterns to modern ceramics. Formerly a convent as the suggested route is followed through severe stone corridors and cloisters suddenly you come into a huge gilded and decorated chapel which has to be seen to be believed. More corridors and tiles, and another lovely chapel on the floor above. We stayed for a very tasty and inexpensive lunch, in a refectory decorated with blue and white tiles depicting meat, poultry and veg from long ago. A lovely cool and interesting place to be on a hot day in Lisbon

Interesting if you like tiles. If you're interested in the azuelos (Portuguese tiles) this museum is worth a couple of hours of your time. The big tile mural of Lisbon before the earthquake is interesting.

Fabulous tiles. Wonderful to see so many examples of the beautiful tiles that Portugal is famous for. The panoramic ones of Lisbon are amazing. I also enjoyed the modern examples of ceramic pottery. Other highlights are the church and the cloisters. One small quibble would be that when we paid we were not offered a floor plan so had to go back. It felt slightly unwelcoming in view of the fact it is a bit out of the way and we had got a local bus. Surely they want visitors? We had tea in the café courtyard which was lovely.

Fabulous museum, that tells the history of clay tile, with many varieties...all beautiful. Must see!. With a free couple of hours you must go here. Woven throughout the history of portugal, Tile making was initially only something the church and the very well to do could afford...see the history of tile making right up to the present. Lovely museum, stunning tilework and interesting building, as well. Go!

Well worth a visit. As museums go, it's quite good. The 23m long tile wall showing Lisbon before the major quake was the highlight. If you like tile art, you'll like this museum. The cafe is also good as is the shop. Well worth a visit. Catch the 794 bus from Terreiro do Pacol tube station and ask the driver to drop you off. Takes about 7 minutes to get there and you don't want to walk.

Beautiful and interesting. Tiles? What could be interesting about them? That's what I thought until I got here. It is stunningly beautiful, with a huge range of tiles throughout the ages and a breathtaking church, all tiled and with some fantastic paintings. It was my favourite attraction in Lisbon.

Extraordinary collection, staff inadequate. The collection of the National Tile Museum is an artistic wonder - full of amazing examples of the beautiful colored tiles that have been produced in Portugal for centuries. The presentation is comprehensive, starting with early examples from the Middle Ages and continuing on to the present times. It is also possible to watch an interesting film about the history of tile making, although its format is insufficiently complete and systematic and concentrates too much on the self-indulgence of the filmmakers (a tremendous waste of time that could be used for a more meaningful experience). The building in which the collection is housed is a masterpiece of Manueline architecture that is worth visiting for its own sake. The behavior of the staff that I experienced there recently unfortunately makes it impossible for me to give a higher rating than average. They are not helpful and not friendly, even when asked questions in Portuguese. They are indifferent at best and frequently rude, for example when I tried to order something at their restaurant and only received disgraceful rudeness in response to a polite request in Portuguese for an item clearly posted on their menu. I couldn't recommend avoiding the collection just because the staff is so poorly trained. The beauty of the tiles is easily capable of making the spectator forget their inadequate sense of professional obligations.

Well worth visiting. We visited one morning after having read that you can only see the tiles in the church attached to the museum in the morning which was absolutely true, and a sight not to be missedWe reached the museum by going to the last station on the blue metro line Santa I Apolonia and walking - its about a 25 minute walk - on the way back we took a bus which stops outside the front of the museum back into the centre of townIf you want to learn about Portuguese tiles, this is the place to go to - its quite a big museum - two floors plus a gallery upstairs that was tucked away with a very good film running all the timeThere was also a nice cafe with a small gardenWorth a trip

Don't miss this!. We can’t recommend visiting this museum highly enough. Yes, it’s out of the way in a rather industrial area but all of that is forgotten when you walk through the door of the former palace. The collection of art is fascinating and walks you through time as Portuguese tile art evolved through time. What many reviews and maybe the museum description doesn’t tell you about is the palace chapel, it’s accompanying artwork – paintings, carvings, wood flooring – that will also take your breath away.Don’t miss this gem of a museum.
In an interesting old monastery. Tiles had been saved from many churches and other buildings damaged in the earthquake, so some were very old. The restaurant was peaceful, and did good food.

So beautiful. The azulejos ! Many of them! New ones and historical ones. You can feel the Meditarrenean spirit and feel like you are on a time machine when you are here. I think that on Sundays it is free of charge. Go see.

This is a must see in lisbon. Housed in an old cloister the national tile museum is a must seeThe exhibits run from the beginning of the title industry to todayIt shows how the patterns are made the beautiful motifs And provides and amazing tour of the cloister If you have time stay for lunch as the did is very good as wellIt takes about 2 hours to tour but it is worth it

wondeful presentation of dominant decorative motif in Lisbon's architecture. This museum is in itself beautiful as it is located in a "repurposed" convent which incorporated a great deal of the art of Portuguese tile (azulejos=tiles) in its construction. The museum explains the evolution of the tile from an Arab art passing to Holland and landing in Portugal. The Portuguese used the azulejo to decorate or cover entire walls of a building's interior so they had to speed up the azulejo manufacturing process.As you go through the museum which offers the opulence of the former convent as a subtext, you see its evolution and even modernist renderings in ceramic. Once you leave the museum, you start to see its "lessons" popping up as you walk through the street of Lisbon and into its buildings, churches, cafes, restaurants, etc.I would say that you could spend a very pleasant and informative two hours here. The cafeteria attached is also quite lovely "sort of" open air with awning to block any direct sun and a gurgling fountain.
Very interesting and great collection . A must in Lisbon heritage and history.Chronological itinerary and very rich collection. They restore old tiles. Restaurant service rude.
Beautiful exhibits. A smallish museum but intriguing to walk through the short narrow aisles and marvel at the range of wall tiles and roofing tiles.

History of Portuguese Tiles. This place is a little hard to find, but well worth a trip, we went on a Sunday afternoon and the admission was free, at other times of the week you have to pay, there are many tiles dating back to the 16th Century, lots of blue and white tiles, and also pictured tile panels which were great. Attached to the tile museum is the "Madre de Deus", a 16th Century chuch which is decorated in the Rococo style.
A must see!. Quite a hike to get to, but managed to find it. Well worth the entry fee to see the beautiful and historic tile of Portugal!

Worth the trip. You will need to take a taxi to the museum however it is well worth the trip. Very peaceful place & an amazing collection of old tile. The church within is stunning. A must while in Lisbon

MY KIND OF MUSEUM. I am an Azulejos fanatic and this museum did not disappoint. The tiles are exquisite and the building itself is lovely. It has a lovely garden and the restaurant is very good. The tiles will blow you away.

AMAZING - a must see!. This museum is a little outside the centre and I was never able to see it in my previous visits to Lisbon. What a mistake - it's amazing! The museum is inside a restored convent which is itself filled with incredible azulejos. The different rooms take you through the history of these amazing tiles with lots of incredible examples from all over Portugal. On top of that, you can visit the baroque church and the cloister which are - by themselves - worth the trip. Lastly, you can rest at the really cute cafe with both indoor and outdoor space. Highly recommended!
Cross eyed. This is well worth a visit. It has tiles displays from and pictures both old and new. We found it fascinating. Also a shop and a really lovely restaurant.
Great museum. Excellent museum, well worth the visit. The collection is in a former cloister, which is a lovely space to see a huge range of beautiful tiles. It also has a lovely cafe.

Nice museum for a 1-2 hours visit. I love tiles, especially Portugese style, so I really liked the tile museum (Museu de Azulejo). The building and the entrance are beautiful and the collection tiles and the process of making tiles is interesting. Not everything is translated into English, so sometimes you have no clue of what you are looking at. But still, worth the visit.
Beautiful monument!. It is better from outside than inside... but allows amazing pictures!!!! Relax and have fun with family and friends near a beautiful tower!

Hard to believe. When reading about Lisbon we had no intention to visit the Tile museum. Then, when seeing such beautiful tile in Lisbon, Porto and small towns, we resolved to visit. Excellent displays about the history of tile in Portugal from the Moors to today. Plus, the Lisbon panorama is something to behold. The museum also has a beautiful garden, a nice snack bar and a very interesting restaurant. It is well worth the trip.
I loved this place. Even the lack of air condition and some problems of maintenance I thing is most important to understand the portuguese culture

georgous ! so worth going. I'm not a huge fan of museum ... but this one is so typical of Portugal , I thought I should go and check it out . Had little expectation , turned out to be amazing . you can see some "azuejos" from the 16th centuary . they're in a very good state . they tell you how they're made and use for . then , beause you're in a monastry, you get from beautiful rooms to the most beautiful Church of the city .... stunning . and I can't believe they just charde 5Euros for the visit. I stayed 2 hours, I couldn't have enough of this place !! JUST GO !!
Great but out of the way. If you want to learn more about tiles this is the place to come, but it has so much more to give. I really enjoyed it - it also has a nice cool cafe in a courtyard garden.

A delightful museum. A delightful museum to visit when you have already seen the main sights of Lisbon. Wonderful display of decorative tiles in old convent. Visited on one day in Lisbon from cruise ship as it was a short taxi ride from port. As it was the first Sunday in the month admission was free ! Good discounts at other times for over 65s and disabled. Had lunch in excellent cafe there.
Don't miss this. I never thought tiles were this interesting! The museum is located in an old palace and is full of fabulous patterned tiles. Also a great gift shop.

Amazing museum to learn about tiles. Housed in an old 15C convent this is a well laid out museum with the chronological development of tile patterns and tile manufacture - the chapel gives the Sistine chapel a very good run for its money - painted ceiling, lots of gold ands superb tiles.

Very beautiful. We appreciated this museum a lot. Many tiles in different contexts in this beautiful building. As you will observe, experts are still renovating uncountable heaps of further tiles. The only point that needs a review is the lighting. Indeed, everywhere direct (yellow dominated) direct light on the tiles does not put thoses pieces of art to their appropriate value.

Brilliant place to learn about tiles. Well laid out in chronological order with so many different styles of art and how the tiles have changed over the centuries. There is some information but it would have been nice to have some more about what they thought the pictures and tiles depicted. Sometimes there was only very basic information, even in Portuguese. We asked about tile painting and the kind worker told us we needed to make a reservation in advance as it was only for educational visits. That and more information would give it a 5.Come and make time for the cafe afterwards! Loved it

Escape from the crowds. We went on a very hot day when a huge cruise ship had docked in Lisbon. We wanted to escape the heat and the crowds and this was a perfect place to do that. Really enjoyed the beautiful tiles and the elaborate church. Then sat is the lovely outdoor courtyard and relaxed.

Quiet museum, extraordinary collection and chapel. get away from the crowded sights and enjoy the space and serenity of this museum. The Techniques and historical significance of the use of ceramic tiles throughout Portugal is very well well explained.

Not really worth it. The best thing about this place is the chappel (Church of Madre Deus) found inside it, which is beautiful. However, the museum itself is quite boring, unorganized and some areas in a urgent need of maintenance. It is free on the first Sunday of every month.

Housed in historic convent with quiet courtyard restaurant. Interesting building and quiet restaurant. Don't miss the historic city of Lisbon (before the earthquake) in tiles on the top floor. But it takes ages to get there on the bus in August and there's nothing else attractive in the area. Don't try to walk and be prepared to wait 45 minutes at a bus stop in August (Taxi might be better option). We thought the Gulbenkian and the Artes Antiga museums were much more interesting, better displayed and obviously more varied. We thought they could have explained the differences between different types and periods of tiles better, and different methods of making tiles, too.

interesting and peaceful. This was something that I had never seen before: combinationn of glittering church deco (the building is an old convent) mixed with tiled walls.It would have been even more interesting if they provide more information of the history of tiles and why it becae the speciality of Portugal (perhaps of Arab origin with geometric designs)

Museo do azulejo - a must in Lisbon. It's quite difficult to get there. People in Lisbon are not exactly proficient in English so asking a local won't help much. We've used the subway but it's a long walk to the museum from the subway station. Using a bus would be better if you now exactly which one.Anyway, the museum is quite special. Helps you understand the Portuguese tradition of tiles on buildings. It's a insight look at tiles history starting with the Arabs and going trough Dutch craftsmanship.it's an unusual museum, a spacial one in Lisbon.

One of two top historic attractions in Lisbon (other was Mosteiro dos Jeronimos). This was a fantastic place to visit. A little hard to fine -- about 2 km east of Lisbon (Praca do Comercio), on Bus 728, look for stop: Av. Inf. Henrique/Ponte Xabregas; walk up small road (500 meters) from Port; under bridge; turn left; another 500 meters). Three floors of exquisite "azulejos" (tiles) from the 8th Century to the 20th Century). Three floors divided by time époque. The colors and intricacies were unbelievable; largely religious motifs. Attached to the museum is a church and chapel, again featuring intricate tiles and others pieces of religious artifacts. Absolutely breathtaking. On the top floor is a tile panoramic showing the entire port (east to west) as seen in the 17th century. Fascinating to see what's the same and what has changed. Lovely book and art store on the premises; also a nice small cafeteria.

Adds some perspective into the many tiles around Lisbon. The 759 bus that you catch at the Commerce Square by the river, stops very close to the museum. The displays were laid out in a logical way that explains different time periods. As a fan of ceramic tiles, my wife really enjoyed the exhibits. The more modern works were also interesting. If this is your thing, take a trip out to the museum.

Unusual museum. We tried to reach this museum using the local buses, but we missed the stop (think the bus route varies) and had to get a bus back. When we left, we waited for about a hour to catch a bus back to the centre but the scheduled one did not turn up so this is not the easiest of places to find.There is a fee to enter the museum and there is a good café/restaurant near the entrance. There are also toilets near the entrance.There is an extensive collection of historic Lisbon tiles, including religious, period and geometric themes. there are also some unusual scenes, such as the chicken's wedding, where the chicken is being driven to the church by monkeys! There is also a full-scale chapel in the museum. Towards the exit, there are modern exhibits and an impressive tile display of the Lisbon cityscape. Do not attempt to stray off the suggested route (which is not always marked out) or the security guard may get grumpy!Allow around one and a half to two hours for a visit.

Not worth the trip. So very disappointing and really not worth leaving the centre of Lisbon ( it's way outside and nothing else around) . This museum has a long way to go before it could be considered vaguely interesting. No Audi guide and no English translations available

A fun thing to do and you get to paint your own tile.. We were expecting a routine tour about how tiles are made but instead had a delightful presentation of the history of tile and tile making in a beautiful setting. The guide was very informative and kept us interested throughout the tour. At the end we painted our own tile which was delivered to us on our river boat at the end of our trip. It made a unique item to bring home.
Eye popping tile. If you have marveled at the tile throughout Lisbon, make this a stop. Check for free days. Bring a camera. The panorama room is not to be missed.

A MUST SEE MUSEUM. The collection is outstanding both
aesthetically and historically.
The church desrves special atention due to the "azulejos" and gold carving

National Tile Museum. National Tile Museum is one of the highlights in Lisbon. One which was top of my list to see. Beautiful tile exhibits in a beautiful building. Had typical Portuguese codfish lunch along with a Sagres beer in the courtyard restaurant (also indoors). Service excellent. Food delicous. Wonderful place to relax and reflect on what you've seen at museum. Highly recommended.

Very surprising!. This tile museum is housed within a monastery/ convent. The chapel is absolutely stunning. Lots of reliquaries complete with bits of bone! You can get right up close to see them. All the usual gilded altar and paintings but as its not a working chapel there are not the same prohibitions.The tiles are quite impressive and have come from other places and been cleaned up and rehung / stuck. You can wTch the people at work cleaning all the old plaster etc from them. It's a time consuming business - each one individually numbered and cleaned with small brushes and dentistry type tools!The cafe is reasonably priced and the food tasty. We had ham and cheese rolls, 2 bottles of water, a slice of cheesecake, coffee and tea for under 15 euro. You can sit in or out and it's quite restful. Good restrooms also .It wasn't crowded when we visited on a Tuesday morning.

Would have liked more information. Reading the other reviews I feel we missed an opportunity. The museum now offers an app you can download but no wifi there so we has to depend on the little descriptions next to each piece which were very brief. Although we saw beautiful work we can't tell you much about them or their significance.

Maybe Lisbon's Best Museum. This might be Lisbon's best museum. The collection of azulejos, or painted tiles, is stunning. In addition, the building is wonderful. The museum is located in the former Madre Deus/Mater Dei convent, and it includes the former chapel, which is decorated with astounding richness. Add to that lovely courtyards and cloisters, a chic cafe, and a tempting shop, and we have a top-flight attraction. Pro-tip: Don't miss the panoramic azulejo rendering of 18th century Lisbon, which is somewhat hidden in its own room on the top floor.

Beautiful Display of Tiles. The Museum has a rich display of beautiful tiles from very early times to the present. Learn about the development of the art through the ages as each rooms takes you in chronological order through the history of tiles in Portugal. Not a very busy museum, which is a shame because there is a lot to appreciate here. So a good place to go to get away from the tourist crowds. It is on the HopOn HopOff bus routes so easy to go to that way.
Nice museum. This is an art museum by definition. But it should be best visited if you have a clue on tile art, otherwise you should visit it just to learn about the art that made Portugal famous.

Good everything.. Great lunch place, serving between 12 and 3. Lovely waiters who are very helpful. Excellent menu (quiche, filled pancakes and a very good roast chicken) with a good selection of Portuguese wines. The puddings menu is a real delight: homemade chocolate mousse and also an apple pie. Not expensive, and then the beauty of the tile museum...

Great museum for tile lovers! . If you love tiles, you would be sorry if you miss this place. There is a bus stop directly in front of the museum, so it's easy to reach. At the end of your visit be sure to have something to eat/drink in its nice and peaceful garden. You can get great gifts from the museum shop too.

Big Hit. My wife loves tiles and handcrafts, so this museum was a bit hit. It is nicely laid out and has excellent explanations. It apparently is located in an old church/monastery structure, with the church preserved, so that is a nice bonus. We had soft drinks in the restaurant, but it looks like it might be a nice place for lunch.

Well worth the trip. Perhaps not the most obvious attraction in the city but well worth the trip. The museum present information about the art form of tiles in a well structured way and there is plenty of information in English without over-doing it.Yes, this was a "fill-in" visit for us on a very hot day but so much better than the crowds at BelemThe building itself is fascinating and the chapel should be explored.The cafe is good value and a peaceful setting. Despite some comments about being out-of-the -way there is a regular bus service from Sao Sebastian and a more convenient service with a couple of bus per hour from the Metro at Terreiro do Paco which also passes the station at San Apolonia. If you arrive before 10, there is a handy local cafe (clean and tidy) on the corner just up the hill towards town!

Fascinating collection of all types of decorated tile. I went to this museum hoping to find interesting examples of tile patterns which combine to form greater patterns. I was not disappointed. In fact, this museum has thousands of displays of tile decoration of all kinds - from simple patterns to grand pictures. As a quilter, I found a lot of inspiration here. I took thousands of pictures!

Loved this museum. This museum is in a former convent and has a stunning chapel inside. The tile work is vast and comes from many different time periods. Be sure to leave time for a snack or drink in the garden afterwards. I took a taxi there and a bus back--wasn't the easiest place to get to.Free wifi & I was able to use my student id for a discount.

Sumptuous. This small but well designed museum will allow you to better understand the unique art of "azulejos", these ubiquitous Portuguese variations on ceramics, rich with Arab influence. Vivid colours and beautiful designs are everywhere. The building used to be a nunnery, and its chapel is absolutely glorious.

Amazing. In Portugal, the art tile (Portuguese: azulejo) is a most important decoration art, especially in churches, chapels, & conventions. If one want to get more knowledge about it, the tile museum in Lisbon is the place. This is one of the best museums in Lisbon where one could not miss. When you step into the museum, the collections covers from as early as 15th century to today in various styles. Since it is located in a former convent, so a chapel decorated with gold & tile painting will surprise you. The highlight of the museum is the longest tile, 23m with 1300 tiles, made in 1738, which shows the city scenery of Lisbon before earth quake in 1775.

Great museum. The family had spent the holiday taking photos of tiles so visiting the museum seemed like a good thing to. We were staying near Alameda so were able to catch the 742 bus which took about 20 mins.It was interesting to see the exhibits on how the different types of pattern were produced. My preference was for the older tiles from the 17th and 18th century. Drinks in the garden were pleasant. Strangely the cafe sold more items than were listed on the menu so go to the counter and have a look before deciding.
Beautiful small museum. Set in an old monastery it's a picturesque location for the downstairs restaurant Over three floors is an eclectic collection of tilesA great building enough to be interesting
A good place to understand the effects of the earthquake in Lisbon. Interesting museum very informative as we didn't know anything about Lisbon....lovely quiet gardens with peacocks for company.

Fascinating history and tile artwork, especially the panorama. This is another fascinating museum in Lisbon that is worth a visit, but I would recommend visiting near the end of your stay. That's because the most interesting part of the museum is the giant painted tile panorama of the city of Lisbon, pre-earthquake. After spending a few days touring Lisbon and visiting historic sites, it is fascinating to then look at the panorama and compare it to what you've seen. Be warned, the attendants are quite strict about the order in which you do the walking tour and making sure you see EVERY room.

Very nice, but you have to like to look at tiles and more tiles. We enjoyed about 1.5 - 2 hours there and many of the tiles were beautiful and interesting to see. Great that this museum is preserving this important architectural treasure. Their café is lovely (it doesn't bother me that the grass in the courtyard is not manicured). This is a working, conservation museum. Visitors can see the cartons of tiles yet to be sorted and prepared for display, storage, etc..

Great family visit- gorgeous space!. Great building with terrific history houses a gorgeous collection of tiles. Self-guided tour over multiple floors allowed kids/ parents to go at their own pace, and linger in some of courtyard spaces or spend more time on historical explanations. Visitors see the boxes and boxes of tiles being cleaned and filed in the conservation area, plus gorgeous chapel. Not-to-miss café with relaxing ambience, outdoor seating in the shade, and friendly staffers. Some practical notes: get out at Santa Apolonia train station, cross street, and take bus on opposite side of road (5 min ride tops). There is an amazing waterfront restaurant right across from station as well, very new, with portuguese/California blended food and vibe- Cais da Perdra. Also, classy museum store with original art pieces closes between 12-3 daily, so we missed out on it! Not much english speaking in museum staff as well, FYI- but almost all is translated on panels.

Brilliant. A previous reviewer mention that there was no descriptions in English .This is Rubbish- nearly all the exhibits had descriptions in English and Portugese.The museum was not as expected- neatly packaged into different eras all showing the production and firing techniques to those not in the know.It was most interesting to know how some of the colour glazes change colour so much once fired up.Some truly beautiful tiles and friezes- look out in particular for the 'chicken wedding'!Much of the exhibition is in the old monastery and this made it really interesting around the old cloisters.Also the garishly ornate church with its golden interior is an eye opener.When you have finished have lunch in the outside/ indoors shaded courtyard where there are fish pools and entertaining turtles .The food was good too.All in all a great place to visit.We drove and parked for free right outside but our Garmin sat nav took us to a site a mile away so follow the road signs to the museum for more accuracy.Best public transport option is by bus which stops outside as does the hop on, hop off red bus.

Sounds boring . But gland you will be pleasantly surprised.. We were not going to go , but we spoke with a couple who had gone and they were surprised how beautiful and interesting it was . Would highly recommend a visit to this site.

Beautiful!. This is a place well worth visiting. It is housed in a beautiful old monastery, and you could spend an entire day here exploring. Visit the website beforehand to see what is on exhibit, and allow at least 4 hours to visit.

Lovely museum, but very little explanation for English speakers. Some wonderful rooms, and interesting exhibits - including a panoramic view of Lisbon, and some wonderful 18th/19th century exhibits. We also witnessed a wedding in the Church which was an experience in itself! Just would have liked more on how tiles were made, and much more on each room, in English.

Love it!. Every time we visit Lisbon we visit the tile museum. There's something wonderful about viewing the historic pictoral and decorative tiles, along with the more contemporary styles. Unique art museum that should be on everyone's list!

An amazing museum. If you like the Portuguese tiles (Azulejos), you'll love this museum for sure! It's not in the main center of the city, but it's definitely worth a visit. The museum has many impressive tiles and the history behind each one, but the most impressive is the church and the panoramic tile painting on the top floor. A must see when in Lisbon.

A magnificent collection of Portuguese tiles. The National Tile Museum is a 'must visit' for those interested in the art history of Portugal as tiles are a very important part of it. You follow the history of tiles through the centuries and at the end you can visit the wonderful church beautifullly preserved decorated with tiles and valuable paintings. There is a good museum shop and an also good café where you'll be able to relax after your visit.My favourite tiles? 'The wedding of the chicken'! 18th century tiles showing a chicken in a rich carriage being driven by monkeys to the church where the bridegroom awaits her!

Superb. This is definitely a must visit! Has great pieces of azulejo. It also has an amazing Church inside full of details. And to end the visit by the gift shop there is a nice coffee shop with a great environment. (Also free at the first Sunday of the month)

Didn't want to go but very glad I did!. This is a very visual museum probably best seen with a guide. It essentially is a history lesson told through tiles: how they were made, colored, shaped, etc all changed over time. You understand why Portugal is the leading maker of decorative tiles today. Fun to look at history through tiles. Art and history combined in a unique setting was a good experience.

Wonderful visit. Fantastic if you like tile. Nice explanations of ancient techniques, wide range of examples. Some interesting modern pieces too. Bus stop right out front (718, 742,759).Great little café with, among the standards, a passion fruit mousse, and today a baked apple in port sauce. Nice breeze on a hot day is free.

Great morning or afternoon activity. If you have about 90 minutes to spare then its a fun museum to go see. The history on the tiles is very interesting and it was beautiful. Its also a great place to get away from the hot summer sun.

Fabulous displays and great cafe. A friend visited a few days ahead of me and recommended I visit, if you like ceramics you will love the displays, the modern gallery exhibition was a knock out. The café in the cloister is a great place to chill out and I was especially touched when one of the waiters saw I was on my own and gave me a cake as a present, really lovely gesture

Interesting history of a national art. The museum is oddly quiet considering the wealth of beautiful work inside. As a newcomer to tile art, the information on the history of its development, both in historical and technical senses, was interesting and enhanced my enjoyment of the work itself. Add in a couple of small exhibitions of more modern work and you have a winner! We also enjoyed a lovely low-key lunch in the beautiful and serene courtyard cafe.

BEAUTIFUL!. I liked it so much! I believe every visito of Lisbon should spend some time there. The staff, the cafe with the beautiful garden, everything was so nice! The only thing I can say as a negative point is that the shop closes for some time. I recommend it!

Five Stars in Lisbon. This museum is totally mesmerizing. The tile collection and historical presentation are super, and the setting is divine. I fell in love with the beautiful Virgin Mary in the church. All this, plus the restaurant is very good too.

Well worth a visit. I went with my friend. We expected a good display of tiles and the history behind them and we got this and so much more! We did get what we expected and wanted, this was fabulous! However the church, the metres of intact tile art, modern tiles and the diversity of colours, we both loved this place!! We had lunch in the expansive courtyard and loved our lunch. On leaving we were able to flag down a taxi and left the museum to get to the Bairre Alto section of town for about €6. Make sure you know how to pronounce the museum in Portugese, it makes it more friendly and easier to understand for taxi drivers who often have limited English!!

Very worth seeing. This was initially just a nice-to-have option for us, as we were interested in the famous tiles but did not have big expectations to this museum. But it is truly impressive and I would highly recomment a visit here. They have a large collection of various tile "pictures" within a the rooms of the former monestary and a breath takingly rich decorated church as part of the museum. Do not miss the completely tiled large scale panorama of the city of Lisbon on the second floor.
A true treasure!. This museum is in an old convent. Incredible displays to tiles over the years including how they are made. Allow several hours for a good visit.

Not to be missed. This museum is not the tipical four walls with hanging stuff. It's a beautifull complex with included a chapel coverd in gold and tiles, not one single centemeter of empty surface, breathtaking

Absolutely gorgeous antique tile in a repurposed convent. Not quite walkable from the center, but accessible by bus. The building is a treat and the tile murals are beautiful. Lisbon is working hard to preserve their historic tile, and this is one repository that combines setting and exhibits beautifully

An inspiring half-day trip to the "other" Lisbon, not only for design buffs.. Its refreshing to leave the Old town behind and venture up north a bit, into the more casual part of the city. You can certainly take a bus but I would suggest walking from one of the surrounding Metro stations, so you can see a bit of the authentic city and perhaps check out the beautiful city cemetery too. The National Tile Museum itself is quite a sight too, even if tiles are not really your thing either: its situated in an old monastery, offering a peaceful atmosphere even in high season. Theres a contemporary exposition of modern designs too. After you view the exhibition, the museum offers a stunning rustic garden with a restaurant in which you can sit and have a decent cheap meal. All in all, this is definitely one of the most memorable city sights in Lisbon.

Wonderful museum showing the evolution of tiles throughout the centuries through wonderful tile presentations.. I loved this museum, but I also love tile work. I enjoyed the timeline of how the tiles evolved over the centuries. There are cards with information on each tile and the museum has an app you can download in English with more information. Because tiles are part of Portugal's history, I think this museum is worth your time. It's only 5 Euro. Plus, you can enjoy the convent and cloister, too.

Beautiful. The room that contains the panorama of Lisbon is worth a visit.. Excellent insight into the history of the beautiful artistic tiles of Portugal. Take a camera!There is a video which highlights many places where the tiles can be seen in their full glory

Perfect Set of History. I am a fan of tile art and its relations to any part of my house, especially kitchen to bathroom but here in this museum, the geniuses of Lisbon art surpassed its simple use, they made it so beautiful, relevant and perfect.

A little explanation would be nice. I loved the azulejos, but could have used a little explanation in English of what I was looking at--brochures in different languages, or headsets with different languages.
So much history and art created with tiles. On several floors the museum exhibits ancient and modern tile designs, and there is a nice cafe for snacks and coffee

portugal history on a tile. in this place you discover portugal's history. after visiting the museum, I understood why azulejos are so important for portugal. it has become part of its identity. the last room is breathtaking! you will definitely find it surprising!
Unmissable. A very unique museum ..well presented. The history of Portuguese tiles. A bit of a trek to get to..but worth it.

A unique and worthwhile place to visit. This museum is a stop on the yellow bus tour and well worth making. A peaceful compact museum with both ancient and modern tiles featured. The cafe is worth a visit itself - an oasis within a busy city. Highly recommend this museum for something unique.

Who knew tiles would be so interesting?. This place was a bit of a walk from the train station but well worth it. I wasn't really looking forward to this place but my wife was. I was amazed at how much I liked looking at all of the tiles and the history of them.

Tile Museum. My favorite part of the tile museum was the lovely cafeteria - So gorgeous in design and lovely garden to relax in..... The museum itself is a bit off the beaten path- there is a good selection and the old convent is quite interesting - I found that I liked seeing the tiles in the streets themselves more so than in the museum BUT the cafeteria is really special and not to be missed with it's lovely blue and white tile design

Unique museum. I always try to seek out unique museums and I think this was the one for me in Lisbon! I was fascinated by azulejos all around the city, so a visit here was a no brainer. We took the subway there and had a long walk (but you can also take the bus). We went on a Sunday and it was free entry (nice surprise) and we spent some time observing the beautiful tile designs. There is an incredible church in the middle of the museum too (stay on the carpets!) and there is also a cafe and a nice outdoor area. You can easily come to Alfama by bus from this museum too. Recommend!

Better than anything you'll see on the street. One of the first things I noticed about Lisbon was the prevalence of tile on everyday structures in the city. While I was not a fan of all of the patterns, I was much more enthusiastic about the tiles I saw in neighborhood shops, on random underpasses, etc. The staff at Santiago de Alfama suggested I indulge my interest at the National Tile Museum and I'm glad I did. All of the tile in the museum is just gorgeous and the history lesson put what I saw throughout the city in context for me.Enjoy a drink in the garden, too.
Fabulous. Out of the way and worth it. A magnificent collection of tiles through the years. Tile exhibits ranged from small works of art to mural-sized.

could'n imagine it would be so interesing. We had a wonderful guide of our own, she told a lot about tile and technique difference. and we saw amazing - simply amazing! masterpieces - I would never believe, that will be impressed so much. on our request for additional payment the museum organized in advance masterclass - now i have a tile of my own as a memory from this visit

Unique. This is the only Museum of tile that I have seen all of my travels. It is well worth a stop. The museum is very nicely set out, and there's a beautiful church in the middle of the museum filled with tiled walls and gold. What a glorious church. There's a great café there as well with a nice outdoor patio where you can get a cup of tea or coffee. This is a good stopping it's worth the walk. The tiles are very old and very interesting.
Visit. Beautiful tiles and works of art.The staff there was very helpful especially explaining the tiles of the blue period in their history.

must visit for art lovers. Despite it being a bit far out from the main city, this place is well worth the visit if you like art / patterns. be prepared to spend a good few hours there looking around. its not too busy in there so you can often take your time and relax. It has a very nice restaurant there and price was reasonable. The best part of the museum is the chapel. It is absolutely stunning inside. make sure you dont miss it.

interesting. I never thought a tile could be so interesting.Lisbon tiles seem to come alive. I wanted to visit this museum and was not disappointed. Was a little way out from where we were staying in downtown. But easily accessible by taxi.They have wheelchairs available for no cost and allowed me to enter for free as a wheelchair could only access the first floor. However, I have limited mobility so could do all the floors- we didn't ask for audio guides so don't know if they are available-but the signs were enough in English to understand what it was about.We had lunch in the cafe and had to restrain myself in the shop- It's hell having excess baggage!Definitely recommend a visit

Fascinating. Amazing examples of the art that can be achieved using tiles. Both tiles and the building itself were very interesting. I was late in day so did not have a chance to try the cafe but it (and the garden area beside it) looked inviting.

Girls holiday . Really lovely and interesting place to visit. A wonderful collection or tiles and some paintings too. The entire place was light, cool and spotless. Perfect retreat if the sun is too hot during the day. The church was out of this world. The only thing I would say is watch out for the polished wood floor inside the church. It's a bit slippery but they have someone guarding it, asking you not to stand on it for your own safety.I'd advise that anyone who visits, should spend some time in the cafe. The cakes and coffees were wonderful. Really tasty large portions. The outdoor area was so relaxing with plenty of seating amongst the water features with turtles/terrapins. The gift shop is excellent too with something available for everyone - no matter how hard to buy for. Not your usual gift shop tat but really classy looking gifts at affordable prices. I left with a tiled lighter and lanyard.

Interesting Historical Perspective of Portugal. This museum traces the history of Portugal through its' tiles. There are tiles all over Lisbon on buildings, walls, the metro, etc. Here there are tiles from the beginning of Portugal through today. An interesting full wall mosaic of Lisbon before the earthquake.

Lovely museum & staff. This is a beautiful museum. What I found quite unique though was how thoughtful the staff was in making sure the visitors had seen all the floors. When it starts getting close to the closing time, they will actually tell you - you need to see 2/3 more floors...you need to move on...see this and then that...very sweet I thought Amazing museum

Well presented museum. Portugal in general and Lisbon in special is the home of the azulejos. As the name indicates, most of these tiles are blue.The museum presents tiles in a chronological way, starting from the ground floor, which is very nice. The panorama on the second floor of Lisbon before the earthquake of 1755 is also very good.

Another one of my favourites. Along with the Gulbenkian this is my absolute favourite in Lisbon. It shows the production process of the azuleijos throughout the ages. You can get there easily by bus, but make sure to get the right busstop to get off the bus.

Pleasant afternoon. They have plenty of antique as well as modern tiles, but without better signage after awhile one wall of time tends to blend together in your mind with other walls. Still, a good introduction to an artform so prevalent in both historic and new buildings in Portugal.

An absolute must!. If you want to understand the excellence of tile design and the architectural concepts that were fundamental in the Portuguese process of creation and historical development, do not miss it!

Spectacular Exhibits in a Former Convent. Aficionados of Portuguese tile will be thrilled with the exhibits at this museum housed in a former convent. Budget at least two hours for a visit, especially if you want to take photos, and don't miss the beautiful chapel or the multi-panel tile depiction of Lisbon before the 1755 earthquake. If you have time for lunch or coffee, the museum's cafe serves good food from a limited menu in its pleasant indoor space or courtyard garden.

Understanding the history of tiles. This is a beautifully presented museum. It gives you a good overview of tiles history. You will take a different look to the tiled buildings after a visit to this museum.
The bar is also very pleasantly located - you will be surrounded by plants.

History and art side by side. A magical place. History and beauty everywhere. The history of "azulejos" in Portugal and in the world. An extent collection that will surprise any visitor. The restaurant is also worth a stop for lunch, coffee, a dessert.

The Highlight of our visit to Lisbon.. I didn't know how interesting tiles could be until I visited this museum. Of course it is set in an equally amazing old convent, where the chapel and other areas have been carefully preserved. But the tiles from the Middle Ages onwards are absolutely amazing. See the changing designs, the changing colours, even brought up to the 20th century. Also a splendid cafeteria in the museum. Had to get to on public transport, but the taxi fare to and from the centre of town averaged out as 5 Euros per journey. Equally amazing!!!
Interiesting way to spend an hour or two.. As you would expect, a unique museum with samples of Spanish tile throughout the ages. Contains exhibits of tiles over several hundred years

From arab times.. You can walk there directly from the Fado museum, and take a bus when going back to centre. Azulejos tile is typically portuguese, as you can see on a lot of buildings of Lisbon. The museum, hosted in an ancient monastery which is a beauty of itself, tell the story of the evolution of decorative tile from its origin to modern times. In my opinion the best of it is the the first part. Nice cafeteria.

A museum full of history. This is an unusual museum, full of history which is presented through the vast and beautiful collection of tiles. We have never seen so many unusual, handcrafted, amazing and priceless tiles. You can see the history of Portugal, its arts and crafts and a whole lot more. This collection has to be seen to be admired and appreciated. I was not keen on going to this museum, but once there I was glad I did.

Tile Art. While there are still lots of buildings in Lisbon with their original tiles, the best way to see what the old buildings looked like is to visit the museum. Get a museum card and enter for free.

Interesting, but surprising. The National Tile Museum is definitely worth a visit, though it's not what I expected. There was a very interesting section on how tile was made, though it is a part of the museum ripe for a video rather than just a series of displays, some (but not all) of which are in English. The museum traces the history of tiles. It is amazing to see tiles that are more than 500 years old that are still so brightly colored. There is a church (annexed into the museum? Recreated?) that is odd because you notice all the gold so much more than the tiles. There are two very interesting sections of contemporary tiles.The gift shop was a HUGE disappointment. They sell almost no actual tiles. We had seen tiles and items made with tiles (picture frames, mirrors, jewelry) elsewhere, but held off thinking we'd purchase at the museum. However, the selection there was limited to non-existent. If you see something you like elsewhere, buy it. Seems this could be much better both for visitors and as a revenue generator for the museum. Very disappointing.Altogether, worth a trip, but I was glad we went in Sunday and got in free.

amazing. Not many people know of this place but it is well worth a visit. The tile work is amazing and unique. I think we got in free with the Lisbon city card. We took the subway down to the closest stop to the place and took a cab there which wasn't expensive at all. Doesn't take long to go thru but it was interesting none the less.
Brilliant Museum. One of the most interesting museum in which I was. The topic are ceramic tiles, which are widely used in construction time ago . Away from the center ...
a great museum. undersold by the guide books this is a great museum in a splendid setting albeit some distance from the centre. It also has a half decent cafe.
The history and examples Azulejos are spectacular. The building is also fabulous, especially the Manueline courtyard. Give yourself enough time to explore and have lunch or a snack in the courtyard.

One of the best museums we visited. This is not your standard museum with statues and paintings. It is dedicated to the history and art of tile making and starts with Islamic designs and techniques used to glaze and cut the tile that was used in the early Moorish architecture. It continues chronologically through the centuries as styles and techniques became more sophisticated. We loved it

Thorough, Educational, and Impressive Collection. The museum was an educational experience as well as thorough in its explanations and examples of tile making. After a while you might get tiled out, but you walk away appreciating the work that went into the museum as well as the tile making process.They have a restaurant with a small menu of items in a pleasant covered area with a pool full of turtles and goldfish. It's worth a stop for a break.

A little gem. Very much enjoyed this museum which hosts an impressive collection of local tiles with good signposting in English. Would recommend the restaurant for a little snack before returning to town. Very polite staff.

Offers great insight into an aspect of Portuguese society!. If any visitors to Lisbon want some insight into Portuguese life, they should come to this museum. It offers a comprehensive look at the art of ceramic tiles, and how the Portuguese have perfected this art. What's interesting about this museum is that it is located in a former convent built in the 16th Century, so you get to look at this beautiful chapel as well! Highly recommended!

Tiles through times. The choice of location for this unusual museum is excellent, the disused monastery boosts an Azulejo and gold-encrusted church, inner courtyard and doorways, there is also a section of unusual and sometimes very bizarre modern tiles, a Lisbon panaroma filling a whole room and some delicate 18th century displays. On the ground floor the touch and learn displays are good to understand the manufacturing process and the artistic skill needed

Both unusual and enjoyable.. This is the only tile museum I have ever visited or am ever likely to visit. I thoroughly recommend people to visit it because it is unusual. It is easy to get to via a short bus ride from the city centre. Buses are frequent. Descriptions of the contents are mostly in Portuguese and sometimes in English. Best to download their free app (using their free wifi) for detailed descriptions. Currently also only in Portuguese or English. Remember to take your head phones. I also recommend their restaurant.
Pop in for a different visit.. There are some very interesting tiles,walls of tiles.The immense work and thought that has gone into these designs is worth a visit The history is fascinating.

Uau. What a great surprise. This museum is set in a old convent. The building is hidden behind a train viaduct and the area is a little bit shabby, but do not let that put you off. The collection is really interesting and didactic and some of the panels have textured replicas so that anyone can feel the patterns of the tiles through the fingers.But the most impressive is the building itself and the gardens that are hidden inside.I've been there when I was a child and it didn't left me great impression, but now I think it is one of the biggest surprises I had in years. Definitely worth the visit.

Loved it -- when we finally got there. This museum is a long way out. Foolishly, we walked from the end of the metro line but should have taken a taxi or a bus. It encapsulates the progress of tile making and design from the early days of Moorish pastiche to current contemporary tile work. The first part of the display concentrates on the making of tiles, which is surprisingly simple once you know how! A mock-up of a tile encrusted chapel on an upper floor shows azulejos (tiles) in place, so it's not just wall after museum wall. The contemporary tile work at the end is impressively creative.

More interesting than you might think.. This was a very interesting take on. The displays of tile were great but what we didn't realize was that the original convent and its sanctuary with two floors of original oil paintings as well as the original gold Catholic detailing was still intact! Well worth it for the azulelos and the history of tile in Portugal as well as other lands- really worth it for the rest! A lovely covered garden where you can take a coffee or a soft drink is an especially nice way to end the trip. We found it easy to get a cab over - about $6 - and cabs and tuk tuks were around for the ride back to our hotel or anywhere else you want to go.
Excellent for people who like certamics, tiles and art. I really enjoyed their displays and learning about this portugese tradition. people who are not interested in ceramics should skip it.

Amazing building.. Spent a couple of hours here looking at the tiles going back over the centuries. The building used to be a convent which has been well maintained with a lot of the original wall tiling mostly intact. There is also an exhibition of modern tiles. Well worth a visit especially if the weather is not very good.

Beautiful!. Not only are the tile works beautiful, but, the building itself is lovely. The central courtyard with garden allows the natural light to brighten the displays of tiles dating from the 16th century up to current works. Also, the cafe has fantastic leek soup, and the prices are right. Well worth the 5 euro entrance fee.
A unique museum. I had never been to this kind of exhibition, Very interesting.It is recommended to visit the upper floor.

An unusual art and tradition. Portugal is practically synonymous with azulejos, or decorative tiles. They are most visible on building exteriors across the country, but are also found lining a variety of interior surfaces, including ceilings, walls, mantles, and even altars (at one point in Portuguese history, churches were the largest commissioner of tiles). While Italy decorated with frescoes, Portugal decorated with tiles! The azulejo is so important to the history of Portugal, there is even a museum dedicated to this art.The Museo Nacional do Azulejo is housed in a former convent, so it is architecturally beautiful, even beyond the colorful tile aspect. It has a traditional cloister and courtyard, and a stunning gilded Baroque church dedicated to Madre de Deus or Mother of God. As a museum, it houses a diverse tile collection, ranging from 15th century tiles to modern tile art. Beyond showcasing the country’s tile heritage, the museum also serves a social responsibility of tile preservation and restoration. If you enter the cloister’s quadrangle, you can see the preservationists at work, sorting and repairing an incomprehensible number of tiles.The museum depicts the various techniques used to make tiles and how these methods evolved over time. Like the technology, the designs themselves changed depending on trends -- from simple Moorish-inspired geometric designs to Renaissance biblical scenes to blue-and-white Dutch Delft patterns to Rococco nature scenes.The museum was the very first thing I did in Lisbon, which proved to be a wise choice over the next five days; it provided me with a much greater appreciation and understanding of the tiles I would encounter practically everywhere!The museum is slightly isolated on the Lisbon outskirts, especially if you are averse to public transit. I took bus 742, which stopped just a few blocks from our hotel (the Sheraton) and dropped me off right in front of the museum. Bus 742 also has several metro connections, including Saldanha and Arroios stations. I enjoyed the ride, as we passed through local neighborhoods I never would have seen otherwise.Entrance is €5, but there are many combination tickets I realized in hindsight would have been financially smart. You can see the various combinations on the museum’s website and pick one that makes sense for you. The museum is also included in the Lisbon Card, which provides access to multiple attractions as well as transit.I wrote about the museum and the tiles around Lisbon on my blog (link in profile) if you want to see a lot more of my photos.

A MUST SEE. Wow, an enormous collection of hand painted tiles ceramic tiles, a unique art form and part of the Portugese culture and heritage. This museum collects and guards a precious collection of tiles first created in the 15th century, that a times takes your breath away with the scale and beauty. Examples range from the 16th century up to the present day. The museum is located in a tranquil location housed in a former 16th century convent with beautiful cloisters and a sacristy panelled in Brazilian wood. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit on a very wet day and spent all morning looking at the displays of tools, the craftsmanship and collection of paintings.The museum has a good café on site where at the end of our visit we enjoyed lovely Cream of Leek Soup with crusty bread and good coffee, This visit is a must see if you find yourself in Lisbon

Interesting, but could be much better. The Museo is in a lovely old building and contains a wealth of tiles dating from the 1500's onward. Exhibits for the most part have English as well as Portuguese labels, and they are arranged chronologically so that there is a sense of the development of the art form in Portugal. As many have noted, there is a sadly untended garden in the cloister center, and while budgeting is undoubtedly tight it wouldn't take that much to weed and water the garden. If the doors are open, walk out into it anyway and look in through the windows at the masses of as-yet uncurated tiles -- it gives a sense of the ongoing work of the museum. The cafe on the main floor has unremarkable food and service but at least has a nice garden to sit in.While interesting, the museum could be so much better. Discussion of tile-making technique and changes, more indication (photos would be nice) of how the works would have looked in place, something to add some visual drama to what (to the uneducated eye) seems like an endless array of largely blue and white tiles.

Great variety - nice view on the eyes. This museum is a bit of the radar on terms of location in Lisbon, and it makes it calmer and relaxed. It isn't very big but holds a very nice variety of azulejos. It's been a pleasure. Also nice to catch it for free every first Sunday of the month :)

Evolution of Portuguese azulejos in a hsitorical setting. Located in the former Convent of Madre Deus, the historical building is of significant interest, besides the comprehensive displays of tiles down the ages.The tile collection features decorative ceramic tiles or azulejos from the 15th century to the present-day. It also includes ceramics, porcelain and faience from the 19th to the 20th century.The exhibition is comprehensive and includes a display of the materials and techniques used for manufacturing tiles. The Convent has some special areas worth admiring such as the mannerist cloister, the church with its remarkable sets of paintings and tiles; the sacristy featuring a Brazilian wood display cabinet and carved wood frames with paintings; the high choir with rich carved gilt wood embellishments; the Chapel of Saint Anthony with an 18th century Baroque decoration to name a few.The best way to get there is by bus or taxi -- the nearest Metro is some distance away -- it was well worth the effort.
Beautiful tiles. When visiting Lisbon and you see all those beautiful tiles on houses one cann't pas this interesting museum full of Old and some new tipical Portugees tiles

Amazing museum!. A must visit if you have the time in Lisbon. A little out of the way, and as others have suggested you can reach the museum by bus or taxi. We had no trouble finding the museum and walked from the city square, a 15 - 20 minute walk. This is a cultural gem highlighting a rich history of tiles in Portugal with an extraordinary chapel. The museum has a lovely cafe, with great coffee and a (sadly unloved) outdoor garden. Be warned the museum shop closes for lunch for 1 hour at 12.30 so if you want to purchase any souviners here be mindful of the time!!!

Love, love, love this museum. Portugal is famous for its tiles, and this museum shows the finest examples to great effect. The building is an old convent, so there is Manueline stonework as a bonus. The exhibition follows the history and development of tiles, with some wonderful examples. The labels are bi-lingual, with some tactile examples that visually impaired people can touch. Make sure you find your way up to the top floor and the 23m long panel showing Lisbon in the mid 18th century, before the earthquake. The restaurant is also decorated in tiles, and provides a charming space for a coffee or lunch.

Comprehensive and didactic. This museum presents an extensive collection of tiles from many periods (up to the present time), displayed with clear explanations and didactic exemplars.We went on a rainy day and enjoyed the visit (although it is a bit far from the city center, and the bus service could be better -- we had a long wait).

Surprising and spectacular. This Lisbon historical place is a bit off the beaten track but absolutely worth the visit. Portugal clearly, is famous for its tiles being a keynote part of its architecture and this place brings it all together. After the third room we visited, I felt it was going to be a bit pedestrian however walking into the chapel, which we didn't even realise was there, just knocked our socks off. Incredible age, beautiful stories depicted in the tile work and set in a majestically decorated religious space. The top floor had some contemporary tile art, not my cup of tea, but lots of young people taking it in.My only downside to this place is that the internal cloister garden, central to the beauty and age of the place us run down and unkempt. This channels really, the current story of Portugal I think, in that the government is pretty broke.Highly recommended visit.

Enhances any visit to Lisbon and Portugal. This museum is situated a little distance from the main tourist areas in Lisbon but is well worth the trip - we caught a bus outside Santa Apollonia station. The displays are very well presented including a whole chapel from the original convent. We also enjoyed the displays of modern tiles. As there are so many beautiful tiles in Portugal we definitely thought we benefited from learning more about them. We didn't go into the café but it looked promising.

Worth a detour to see if in Lisbon. For those who like to go to museums, this will be unlike others you would normally go to. Imagine, an entire museum devoted to tiles. They absolutely beautiful - old an new. A must see if this sort of thing interests you.

A treasure. A bit off center, get to this small but very well presented museum . It presents a few centuries of various schools of ceramics. The museum houses a team of researchers and it is possible to have a glance at their laboratory. The restaurant offers very good meals.

A must in the land of beautiful tiles!. The museum itself is a little more than 32 years old, situated in a beautiful convent (unfortunately must be better care for, it seems there is lack of funds). Amazing history of the tiles, the church, different tiles and a very pretty third floor with the view of old Lisbon in tiles...The café and garden are also very nice. Well worth a visit!!!!

Very nice but a small museum considering the countries link to tiles. We went with a group and the museum was not crowded so you could really look at the amazing tiles. We also made our own tiles, which were not so great!

An interesting museum in a beautiful building. Accessible by bus 42. The museum is housed in a beautiful old convent, which is now a bit dilapidated as funds are lacking. The tiles are very well displayed and there is a café with a peaceful garden. Well worth a visit.

The museology should be improved. This museum has a very interesting collection - in my opinion, better than a similar one I visited in Sevilla, Spain. Nevertheless, the way such collection is exposed is nott very good. The building, including the gardens, require a better conservation; the exhibition should be more didatic and improve the way is captive the public.

Don't miss this quirky museum. If you only go to one museum in Lisbon, let it be this one. A bit out of town, but accessible by bus or cab, it's a real find. Wonderful rooms, fabulous tiles in myriad arrangements. You don't need to spend too long here in order to enjoy it and get a taste of what the decorative elements of Lisbon are all about.

A stunning collection of architectural and artistic tiles, historic and modern.. Located off the beaten track, but accessible by bus, this is a must-see for anyone interested in Portuguese architecture and the history and art of the traditional ceramic tiles which have been used for the last 600 years on decorative schemes. As an added bonus, the museum is housed in the monastic buildings of the Madre de Deus Convent which with stunning opulent chapel interiors created after the 1755 earthquake - worth seeing in their own right. The museum has beenr recently refurbished. The two floors of the museum houses an extensive display of beautiful tiling designs over the last 600 years up into the modern era and has a temporary exhibition space, an excellent café, shop and an outdoor garden area. Well worth the trip out along the river from the city centre. Free admission on the first Sunday of the month.

Exceptional church and wonderful Azulejos. A must when Visiting lisbonne.,the heart of the Portuguese culture. The museum is OK with good places and poor (not maintain enough) and this is a shame. However interesting museum. With a lot of interesting pieces. 5 € for the visit which could take couple of hours depending your interest in such Azulejos
art...art....art. If you want to know a little bit about Portuguese culture this place has to be in your route. Portuguese history showed through tiles.

One of Lisbon's greatest hidden museums.. You have to search to find and get to this museum. It is in a neighborhood that is somewhat rundown and if you don't know it's there, you would not think to look for it. However, it is definitely worth a visit. it starts out with a history of ceramic tile in Portugal from the 13th or 14th century up to the contemporary era. The early material is relatively simple in individual design but wonderfully rich and complex when brought together into patterns. Over time it takes on religious themes and then becomes more secular (the Marriage of the Chicken!). The highlight of the entire museum is on the top floor (it takes a bit of exploring to find it) where there is a 20+ M long panorama of the entire city of Lisbon in the early 18th century, just years before the city was razed by an earthquake in 1755. The detail, artistry, and craftsmanship in this tile mural is beyond exquisite. It is the single best piece of tile work I've seen any where in the world.
One of my favorite Museums in Lisbon. Great Museum that shows the (rich) history of azulejo, which can be witnessed in almost every building and houses of Lisbon.The cafeteria is also good.

Very interesting museum. This museum is located in a former monastery, and already the respective church is worth a visit by itself. The azulejo collection is interestingly shown and explained, you can easily spend 2-3 hours here. Public bus stops right in front of the door, and entrance fee is alright. Also, on the top floor, there is a large panorama of Lisboa before the 1755 earthquake, very interesting as well.This museum really exceeded our expectations and is highly recommended.

History of a Tile. Everyone visiting Lisbon would be surely amazed of all those tiles everywhere around, and National Tile Museum is the place to know a bit more about this beautiful and interesting artcraft.

This is better than an art museum. I have never seen so much tile in my life. There are so many beautiful pieces of tile here that is is unbelievable. There are tiles from centuries past with beautiful designs of all colors shapes and sizes. Words cannot describe the beauty of this place. If you're ever in Lisbon, be sure and allow time to visit this museum.
Good presentation of tile. It's a little out of the way but worth the visit. What you will see here is a nice collection of tile in a historic perspective.

Good museum- good cafe- bus a bit infrequent on Saturday afternoons. We have been here before as we like tiles- it is very good! Nice café in a cool courtyard with a good cross section of cakes, coffees. Bit off the beaten track but well worth a visit

Great place to see unusual art! . Very nice museum. Beautiful azulejo tiles, huge pictures are just remarkable. Interesting details on some works. Oh, and a not-expensive nice restaurant in the museum :)

Spectacular and Informative!. One of the most outstanding museums we have visited featuring an art form that we knew little about but is prevalent in Portugal. The tiles and their history are very well presented and the movie is excellent. The 15th-century convent building itself is worth the visit and the Church is stunning. Enjoy lunch in the lovely garden area.

A must. You will not be disappointed by a trip to this beautifully laid out museum which tells the history of tiles room by room in a lovely setting. There is also a cafe and restaurant in the winter garden serving good, very reasonably priced food. It is very easy to get there by bus from the Santa Apolonia railway station.

Well worth a visit. Fabulous insight into history of Portugal and indeed of tiles - many older houses in Portugal are still tiled outside but sadly, according to our fab tuk tuk guide, unscrupulous traders are removing them to sell them. Museum has cafe too (and garden) with good food.

Great historical facts about tile. Make sure you go on a Sunday as it's free...don't know what the admission price is on other days. This museum is all rooms of period tile work, some very impressive. We thought there would be some artist's there working but no it's just a walk-through, read and enjoy. There's a lovely little restaurant in a garden on the main floor, good rates, good food.

Special place. This museum was one of the highlights of my trip to Lisbon.The setting was beautiful,I think it used to be a convent once.The quality of tile workmanship was breathtaking. It's wonderful that the museum have managed to preserve so much.The chapel there was so elaborate,that alone would have been worth the visit.A great place.

A haven of tranquillity (with a lovely cafe attached!). Having seen so much azulejo tiling all around Lisbon, it was really interesting learning & seeing the history of development of the different styles that evolved. Puts all you see around the city into context.
There is also a delightful cafe opening onto a courtyard covered with shading that served up a delicious lunch.

Very interesting. We went there on a rainy day taking bus n. 742 in Rua Morais (close to the intersection of metro stop Arroios).The entrance ticket is 5€ (free the morning of the first Sunday of the month) and the visit was really worth it.The museum is very interesting, in addition to exhibiting the tiles it also illustrates the manufacture. The collection is located in a charming sixteenth-century convent where, over the centuries, were added some lovely cloisters and one of the most richly decorated churches in the city. There is a panorama of Lisbon in majolica on the second floor, long 23m., depicting the riverfront around 1740, before the big earthquake and which comes from a city palace. The magnificent Church of Madre de Deus with a barrel vault, whose current structure dates back to the sixteenth century, is the result of three centuries of construction and decoration and is full of paintings.Definitely recommended.

Great museum worth a visit. If your into interior design this is a great place to visit. Good displays and information on the Azulejos tiles all housed in a former convent which would be worth a visit on its own. Throughly enjoyed our half day visit. Only downside is it's hard to find, we finally a hailed a taxi after walking around for an hour with no success.

Pretty much what you would expect. It's nice to see a bit of history and how the colours and styles evolved over time, but it's not very exciting! Some nice pieces but I wouldn't call it a must see. It's sort of in the middle of nowhere too, a 15 minute taxi ride from the main part of town where there are lots of nice museums and shops to walk around.

A hidden gem with a lot of interesting displays. The tile museum displays a wide range of tiles both modern and old which were the more interestingly.The size and variety of the tiles tell stories in 'pictures' which was nice to see.

Good tutorial in techniques and evolution of Azulejos. A fairly popular but not overrun museum housed in part in a former church. Great displays of centuries of tile-making with good descriptions (usually PT and EN) of techniques and of other countries & cultures inspiring Portuguese ceramicists. While you could say all of Lisbon is a tile museum, this site was worth a visit.
Not bad. Poor signage to get there--but that's par for the course in Lisbon. Pretty tiles, although some of the roman catholic church settings and religious themed wall tiling are pretty tacky.
Must see . Beautiful museum, including the church. Must take the time to admire both the old title as well as the contemporary. Take the bus, as walking is a bit confusing and probably not very safe.

Beautiful Facility - Good Cafe. There are beautiful tiles all around Lisbon and Portugal so it doesn't seem like you would need to go here, but it is beautiful and describes the technique and history of tile making. Lovely courtyard and surprisingly good cafe.

just fascinating to see how making of tiles has evolved. a most pleasant museum to view items of interest. Fascinating to see how styles have changed and the influence of arabic art and the use of tiles instead of paintings.

A great stop for something different. Tiles, tile and more tiles. Lots of great thing to look at. Incredible chapel inside, breathtakingly ornate! Cool old convent, easy to navigate. 5€ admission, well worth it. Cafe is quite nice and fairly reasonable.
