Nice Museum. Very nice exposition of tiles. I wish there were more history or a more comprehensive informational approach, since tiles have a rich history in Portugal and Lisbon's history but that part is not quite mentioned on the museum.

Best ancient art museum in Portugal. The Tile museum is a low profile museum inside a convent that will impress you.Its a bit off from Lisbon center and the best way to get there is taking a bus at the terreiro do paço or a taxi ( around 5 euros from terreiro do paço).It hosts a huge tile collection where you get to see beautiful panels and leran about the history of this type of craft and the way it has mixed oriental and western traditions.Inside the museum is a beautiful church not to be missed as it has an impressive wood and paint works that will awe you.Definitely a must while visiting the city.

Surprisingly Interesting. A tile museum? Yes, and it was surprisingly interesting and full of beautiful and sometimes head-scratching artifacts. Well worth a visit if you have some extra time on your hands. A bit hard to find but you can do it - we did.

Wonderful!. Amazing, make sure you visit this museum on your trip to Lisbon! Well worth the 6 euro taxi ride! This museum is a little way outside central Lisbon & that's fine as it would be packed otherwise. Beautiful displays & lots on the history of azulejos. Nice restaurant & gift shop too. Highly recommended!
impressive building. The building which is and old convent is worth the trip and the tiles are pretty impressive too.We got a taxi from central Lisbon for about 6 euros.
Very Interesting and Informative. It was a great part of our day tours, guide was very educated and informative. It was a huge learning curve?
Great museum. Nice and calm museum. As it is a bit outside of lisbon you don't see so many people there. I recommend lunch in a restaurant inside.

Interesting Day. We enjoyed our visit to the Tile Museum--it was a rainy day, so we spent a little extra time there. The lady at the front desk speaks multiple languages, but wasn't as friendly as the people in our hotel (be warned: don't ask for help). I enjoyed touring the museum, learning about the history of tile, watching the documentary. They also have some contemporary tile art displayed. Beautiful location, with an exquisite small chapel inside.

Interesting place with a surprise inside. The tile museum is interesting, but the best bit is the magnificent chapel inside that suddenly appears as you follow the route through the building. Food in the cafe, not wonderful, but OK.
Go there!. Fantastic! Not sure what I would find here, apart from tiles obviously. What an amazing collection of astonishingly old tiles and murals. Very, very worth while visit.

Remarkable Collection. I have been lucky to visit Lisbon 5 or 6 times in the last 4 years and for some unknown reason I had never visited this museum. I went on this last visit and can't believe what I had missed. If you love decorative arts, you will love this museum. And don't miss the extraordinary chapel on the grounds - it will take your breath away.

illuminating. Truly, a quite unique museum! It shows history of Portugese tile making through centuries. A very nice ex-monastery building, very beautiful tiles, some are quite salacious. Plan at least an hour and a half to walk through all exhibits. There is a cosy cafe inside, with a winter garden, but I did not visit it, I do advise to go by taxi to and from it, as place is not very convenient for walking to and from the Old Town of Lissboa, if you are not familiar with the public transport plan.

Excellent museum!. The museum has a comprehensive part dedicated to the history of tiles in Portugal, which traces the different production techniques and explains how they allow for different styles. There's also a part concerning the role of tiles in society, as socio-economic markers, religious use and much more. Lastly there's an exhibit of modern tiles, and a changing temporary exhibit. In addition the museum grounds is in a old cloister, and you can see some fantastic chapels and renovated pars of the cloister. The whole thing is narrated via an audioguide which you download as an app. The museum has wifi. This audioguide is very good, and even has text and pictures if you want to delve even further into the history of tiles. Remember to bring your smart phone and a headset! In addition to all of this, I found the staff to be the most helpful and courteous of the ones I met in all of Portugal. They have also focused on accessibility for the blind (with tactile displays and the audio) and wheelchair users. This place is a gem!
Tile tale and tile itis. If you love tile art you'll be in heaven. And if blue is your favorite color ,you'll be in...can I say it?? "Your blue heaven"

Great museum must see. Firstly this is a convent that houses a national tile museum. Tiles are such a big and unique part of the Portuguese decorative language that it would be remiss to not see the national collection if you are at all even vaguely interested. Tiles are covered from early period work though to current artists. The displays are weak in the latter period 1900 till current day ( partly addressed by temporary exhibition) but the display from this era would be worth the trip alone. The chapel from it's previous life is special and seems to be remarkable well preserved. The museum is some distance from metro or tram a bus stop is out the front but for 6 euro a taxi will take you there from the old town centre and is well worth the fair.The shop at this location was very good with artisan signed pieces on sale for extremely reasonable pricing.I did not eat at the well reviewed cafe but it did have a nice ambience about it.Over all a remarkably good experience without the crowds at other museums around the city.
Superb. Hard to get to but worth the. Trip. A very special place with amazing tiles. Plan to take tram or bus and spend two hours

Great museum - poor staffing. After quite a trek out to this museum we were desperate for some sustenance before entering the exhibition. Very disappointing cafe. Beautiful situation with huge potential spoilt by totally disinterested staff and lack lustre service. Our soup was tepid and being British I was far too scared to send it back for heating up. I had seen the staff exchanging glances at some other tourists who were being a bit more demanding of good service. Really a bad experience here. The tile museum was just great. Really interesting although the English translation tailed off on some of the more interesting exhibits. It would also have been informative to have had more details about how this tiles were actually made and glazed. We thoroughly enjoyed the tiles but we're very disappointed with the cafe.

The One and Only. The best place to get to know the evolution of the art of azulejos (tiles) in Portugal. The setting is a magnificent early 16th century convent which would by itself deserve a visit. Do not miss the extraordinary panel of azulejos painted before the earthquacke presenting a full view of Lisbon, unique in Europe. Enjoy a nice meal or a snack in the beautiful restaurant. Easily reached by public bus.

Awesome!. Unique museum worth of visiting during your stay in Lisbon. Here you can learn everything about the Portugese tile industry as well as about the history and use of tiles in Portugal.The museum is little outside of the city centre, it's about 40-45 minutes walking time from the Santa Apollonia railway station so it's worth of taking a bus from there.
Wide range of interesting patterns. Very nice museum with great designs - Interesting to see the designs being used all over Lisbon. Worth adding to your itinerary.

A lesson in Blue. Azul all over the place, not only at the Museum. Best place to learn, enjoy and appreciate the Portuguese ex-libris. Very educative visit in an historical place. A must while in Lisbon.

This should be on everyone's must-see list!. Given that tiles play such an important role in Portuguese society, it seems odd that people would skip an opportunity to learn more about tile work and see the progression of different styles through the years. The museum has three floors full of tiles! The very last set of tiles is a big tile panorama of Lisbon. Very impressive! The museum is only 5 euro for an adult and a reduced student fee and they give you a free app to use with your phone.
Amazing Tile Work. Could not believe the fine work done by Portuguese craftsman when creating the multitude of various designs, and the colors used.

Beautiful way to spend a rainy day. With my student ID card it was only 2.50€ to get in. The building is beautiful & the exhibits are even more beautiful. The history is cool to learn about and even cooler to see later in the streets of Lisbon

Good choice on a wet morning!. Spent an interesting morning here. A really old building and the displays are well thought out and clearly displayed. The huge pre earthquake vista of Lisbon entirely shown in tiles was amazing! The museum cafeteria was excellent and very good value.

Such a beautiful place!. From the outside, it is hard to suspect all the treasures presented in the museum. The different styles of tile are presented in a chronological order. Some beautiful specimen are displayed.A magnificent church rich fully decorated with the finest gold, painting and flooring can be admired.

Really interesting. We did not go to a lot of museums in lissabon. But the azejulo's are important for the history. So we went there with no idea what to see. But it was interesting to learn about the history of azelujo and there was a really great chapel as well in the museum

Inspiring. We enjoyed seeing tiles several hundred years old and through the centuries to present day. The tile museum was quite memorable and felt like we were seeing quintessential Portugal. If you visit, seek out the audio. No museum staff in all the museums we visited verbally offered audio to us and I think that there is much to benefit from using it. We didn't time our visit to have lunch while there but from other reviews, probably should have. The cafe and courtyard looked very pleasant. A highlight for me was to see the panoramic view of Lisbon pre 1755 earthquake. There are probably few surviving visual records of the city from that time. It reminded me very much of what the older parts of Porto look like. Don't miss it as it would be easy to do so. It's up on the third floor.

Interesting museum with nice café. The museum offers a peaceful experience on a really typical portuguese decoration. It is really worth the visit. Exhibitions are nicely planned. The Café is peaceful with free wifi.

Great Little Museum. If you like your design and tiles this is a great place to visit- Museum has a fantastic collection of tiles from across the ages - some stunning. Museum also has a nice restaurant / coffee area as well. Very nice and relaxing place to spend a few hours. A little bit off the main Lisbon track but not that difficult to find.

Always something new to see. This is one of my favorite places to visit, relaxing and just gorgeous tiles from the past and current.Being housed in an old monastery creates an ambiance equal to no other. A do not miss to understand, and appreciate Portuguese history and culture through the ages.Cafe available for light meals as well.Yummy crepes!

One of the best and must see points in Lisboa. This is the most amazing museum to me in whole Europe as I like the tiles very much. They are so pretty and elegant. We got of Metro at Sta Apolónia station and walked about 20 min. to there. It's so beautiful to walk by the sea and many beautiful houses on the way. The museum is really worthy to go. You will have a pleasant mood after your visit so many beautiful ties. Also, please do enjoy at the coffee shop before you leave, it's like sitting in a dream house, I will go back again next time. Another suggestion is you can take but walk to Alfama for other museums or just fooling around later.
Worth the trip. What a great place to see wonderful works in tile from the early days to more modern times. A lot of the tile work is religious but then what isn't?

History of tile building in Lisbon. This little gem in Lisbon is a must see if you are (like me!) enchanted by the amazing and colourful tile buildings in the city. They have a beautiful café surrounded by a garden for a nice spot to chill and have lunch.

A different experience. A bit out of the way, but does worth the effort! The best part however, for me anyway, was the church inside the museum, it is absolutely stunning! Another bonus is the restaurant, not a lot to choose from but delicious and very cheap!

A must! Beautiful ancient convent - tiles & more. visit the place to know if you are interested in tiles and history of tiles in Portugal. Excellent museum cafe with shaddow extremly confortable in hot summer months...

Probably our secnd highlight. Had initial misgivings - a tile factory?! However, what a gem of a place with a beautiful convent chapel which was breathtaking. And vast majority of piece descriptions included English. Nice cafe also

Difficult to get to but worth it. Not easily on a transport route, might be easier from the centre but we had been to the Parc Nacoes first.We walked through some slightly dodgy bits to get there on foot from the metro.Lovely once you get there and nice little cafe also.

Wonderful objects but need better labelling. I have wanted to visit this museum since a visit to Porto many years ago made me fall in love with the blue and white azulejos. I booked my trip to Lisbon mainly to visit the museum and for the most part was not disappointed. The museum is set in a former convent and there are wonderful cloisters and the most lavish chapel all full of tiles as well as plenty of other examples, my personal favourites being those that showed hunting scenes. But there is so little information about them. I became frustrated after 5 minutes that I was not learning anything about the tiles on show so went back to the shop and spent a massive 32 Euros on the guidebook. I am glad I did - it meant I could read more information about most of the tiles on show, spot things I would never have seen otherwise and I also have a wonderful memory of the visit. But some of this information should be on the labels...Oh, and the staff need some lessons in customer service. Really unfriendly lady on the desk and the guy in the shop did not want to provide me with a receipt for my catalogue purchase though one of his colleagues came to the rescue.Thanks to whoever suggested getting a taxi to the museum. Certainly made the journey shorter.

Understand Portugal's love for the Azulejo. Having traveled around Portugal I was able to view different azulejos/tiles all over the country in houses, churches, palaces, monasteries etc.When I came to this museum I was able to understand the art of the tiles even better with perfect examples from the early times up to the present day. There are some really beautiful ones and it is interesting to note how they were made and the different styles.Particularly noteworthy is the very large azulejo depicting in detail (churches,palaces etc) the city of Lisbon before the devastating earthquake of 1755 that drastically changed the aspect of the city center.Also very nice is the church of Madre de Deus, where the museum is located, with beautiful azulejos and gilded wood carvings.
Nice museum. A nice museum for a detailed look into the historic tiles of Portugal. You can also see people working on restoration projects.

Worth your time. This is a convent that is housing a tile museum. The convent itself is amazing! The tile frescos, designs and artwork are worth the trip. It's a little bit of a hike, but check it out!

Portugal"s Crown Jewel of Artistry. Firstly I don't recommend getting bus #794, instead take a taxi, approx 5 Euro's from Commerio Square. Visitors are greeted by a beautiful yet understated building that houses a treasure trove of classic, traditional Portuguese tile. There is a lot of variety from current exhibits of Portuguese artists, who work in furniture and home wares design.Portuguese tile was used to decorate walls telling stories of the country's history with such breathtaking grace. The chapel is STUNNINGLY beautiful...my Mom and I were OOOing and Aahhing at every turn. Be prepared to take lots of pictures. This is definitely my favorite museum in Lisbon. It is a little out of the city center but definitely worth visiting.

worth a long visit. tiles are part of Portuguese culture - here you learn (nearly) everything about them; the museum is well organised in an old monastery and there are a nice little coffee and souvenir shops

A surprisingly interesting a relevant museum you should visit near the start of your stay. I was reluctant to visit but since it was part of the Viking tour and I always find their selectins worthwhile I went. How much interesting can there be about tile. Quite a lot, as this museum showsThe reason this is worth a visit is that tiles are a National Passion in Portugal. One way to know you have crossed from Portugal to Spain is to look at an urban scene. If many of the building are covered in tile, you are still in Portugal; if not you are in Spain.Our experience was vastly enhanced by our Viking guide who was an art history major . I fnot on a Viking tour it is probably worth hiring a docent there is a lot to the story of Portuguese tile.There is a Portuguese tile style and it is worth learning as it will inform what you see as you go about in Portugal.Be sure to go the top level t see the tile mural done just before the 1755 earthquake showing Lisbon literally before the crash.Another reason to see this near the start of your trip is that museum has an option to paint/glaze a tile of your own using traditional methids and glazes.
Lovely museum. This is a gem of a place,installed in a fine building,with a rich variety of tradtional,as well as some modern,tiles.

A calming and inspirational place. It's full of beauty, some of the tiles are really old and are stunning you can get around in an hour if you stuck for time, but to really take in the true beauty leave at least two hours. There is also a cafe. It's behind the Lidls supermarket

beautiful museum, nice cafe. A very nice museum, with a amazing variety of tiles all beautifully displayed in an old connect and its cloisters. Good information about the displays and this history of tiles in Portugal, an essential aspect of getting to understand the aesthetics and history of the city. A very nice and reasonable cafe too. A little way out from the centre, but not difficult to get to and definitely worth the visit.
AN UNIQUE MUSEUM. We just loved this museum . Very important to know this museum to understand the culture of Portugal

Tiles tiles tiles. In as much as you may see more wonderful tiles (azulejos) in all parts of LIsbon, the sheer history of what you see here is a must for history buffs. Always missed this one and am now pleased to say that I have seen it.

Exquisite!. If you are in Lisbon, Portugal make the time to see this museum. It is wonderful. There are tiles from the 15th century along with a whole wall of tiles that were completed before the earthquake in 1738 showing the Lisbon city scape. The colors and detail vary based on who was in power and what was going on over the years. Plan to spend at least 2-3 hours. Take a cab there. And look for the train on the capital of a column. Well worth the time to get there!

Snooooze fest.. Nestled in a notably less than friendly area, this exhibition is the most boring thing we saw on our visit. The building itself is run down, there's a guided tour for android phones only - and the woman behind the desk was decidedly passive aggressive when we asked for the wifi code to down . The tiles are beautiful and the rest of the exhibition staff were lovely, but it's not worth the train ride down, let alone the entry fee.
Worth the visit, although hard to get there. This is a little far from the main sights in Lisbon, but it is worth the visit, especially for its amazing chapel.

Must not be missed. Housed in a beautiful former convent this national collection is magnificently presented through the Covent and its cloisters. A fine restaurant encourages you to spend the day so there is time to admire detail.

Interesting and beautiful . We entered the museum on a Sunday. We wanted to pay but the man said, today I'll make the price. We got in for free and walked around the museum. Especially the older tiles are very special and impressive to see. The museum is great, a little out the center but worth seeing.

Beautiful Tiles and Mosaics. I wasn't sure I'd make this stop, but a friend really wanted to go so I tagged along and was really surprised by how much I enjoyed it. It's interesting to see how vast the collection of tiles and mosaic displays are, and how techniques changed throughout history, the influences, colors, etc. It's far more absorbing than one would imagine, and I'm happy I went. Access to the church is a plus as there are numerous paintings to view, all so beautiful and representative of changing history. A nice experience.

Interesting experience, get to see some part of history.Nice place to spend a part of the day have lunch&a glass of wine. Enjoyed the visit and the day ,if you are interested in museum's then its unique to the country and worth a visit.You will need some one to explain while going through the museum to enjoy the experience.

Beautiful collection!. No Metro stop nearby, but about a mile walk from the nearest one. Worth seeking out to see the beautiful collection of historic and modern tile. The Panorama of Lisbon display is lovely! Small cafe inside with wi-fi. If you like tile, this is the place for you.

Just great (again!). Second visit as this place is just so great. Slightly out of the way but well worth it if your into this sort of thing. Fine restaurant/cafe too - lovely lunch and local wine etc. Recommended all round

Perfect chance to see many tiles in one place. I won't repeat what so many others have written about this lovely place, but will just add that at the moment, the museum's website appears to be offline and various tourist info websites offer conflicting advice re: opening hours. The bronze engraved museum sign at the entrance states that it is open daily from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., latest entry at 5:30 p.m.; closed: Mondays, Jan. 1, Easter Sunday, May 1 and Dec. 25.

Great museum if you're interested in Tiles!. But besides the church inside, which is a very pretty church, the rest of the museum is just tiles! Of course, if you love this traditional portuguese style, you'll have a field day in there! If you're somewhat indifferent, you might get bored of it.
wonderful tile work artifacts of Portugal. Absolutely worth a visit! Really interesting works of tile art, both secular and religious, from different historical periods.

Best value. This is a great value for the price of admission as you get not only the tiles through the ages but a whole church as well. The church itself is fascinating and features a great many paintings well worth seeing. There are also numerous relics of Saints and a lovely old parquet floor. The panorama of the city of seven hills done in blue and white tiles on the top floor is an attraction all its own. Devote a couple of hours to this wonderful display of cultural beauty.
Fantastic!. A must see in Lisboa. Far from the city center, so it'S best to take the bus. Wonderful tile collection!
Really neat. I was very reluctant at first to visit, but my wife convinced me to go. Their collection of tiles and mosaics are quite impressive.

Must visit museum. One of the best museums in Lisbon!. One of the best museums in Lisbon. There is a plenty of tiles on display, different forms and designs. Next to the museum or part of it is wonderful church with walls decorates with tiles. On a top floor you will find a long panorama of Lisbon made from tiles. There is a cosy restaurant within the museum. You must visit this museum. 100% worth it! Very highly recommended.

Great museum. Take bus 728 from Santa Apolonia station, around 4 stops later you will be one block away from the museum. (Beware the distance between the stops are not very long)A great collection of the tiles, the old church within the museum offers some breathtaking decoration. The top floor of the museum hosts the tile display of Lisbon before the earthquake, which is very interesting.BTW, the cafe is great! Excellent soup and roast chicken. Service was great too. A good way to spend half day in Lisbon.

Unique and relaxing. My mother and I took the afternoon to visit this little museum. We really loved seeing all of the different tiles and works of art. I was glad we didn't have my two young kids with us because they wouldn't have enjoyed it as much. It was fun to just wander aimlessly through the corridors and stare at all of the wonderful designs. One of my favorite parts was finding the little cafe. It wouldn't normally be something we would do, stop at a museum cafe for an espresso, but I am so glad we did! It is a beautiful little area with plants all around and a nice covering for a rainy or hot day. We had a perfect little stop and conversation before we headed out to our next activity.

Interesting setting in 15C Convent. Not within easy walking distance of the centre of Lisbon, but worth taking the Azul metro line to Apolina then 728 bus about 4 stops.This is a well set out display of tiles, old and modern with a very good gift shop.It is worth a visit to the cafe which has old kitchen tiles.Don't miss the huge panorama of old Lisbon done in tiles on the top floor.

A must-go if you're into Tiles!. Even if you're not interested in tiles or ceramics, if would be a shame if you didn't go there while in Lisbon. This is what Portugal is known for and with good reason. You will see staircases covered in tilework, murals, portraits, courtyards and beautiful photo ops.

A pure marvel. Not exacly in the centre of Lisbon, this masterpiece is a typical example of the Portuguese baroque style. In the Madre de Deus Convent, the beautiful different portuguese tiles are on display in the right context. A must!!
Very interesting!. If you are fond of tiles, don't miss this museum. And if you have time, do visit the nearby church Igreja da Madre Deus, very impressive!

A very interesting place to visit. Azulejos are a part of the Portuguese culture and this museum offers an opportunity to discover the best examples of this art. The visit includes various floors and a beautiful church. Take a taxi to go there as it is a bit far from the city center. Definitely Worth it !

Out of the way, but worth it!. We almost didn't go to this museum because it's not really near anything else, but we were so glad we made the effort! Fabulous tiles, both traditional and modern. You will see lots of azulejos in Portugal, but this museum has the best of the best!

loved it every single moment of it!. great place with a great story. You'll make pictures and see things You'll never forget. I did not expect it being so interesting and beautiful and yet it surprised me and I found myself traveling in time. Don't miss it.

Decorating with Tiles. Lovely old convent with pictures and decorations made of tile. Most are blue and white, a few yellow. These are the old, authentic ones. There are a few modern displays and have more color. Large atrium. Walk around it, go in and out of the open doorways and enjoy all the tile pictures on the walls. Small cafe with an outdoor garden. Worth the trip.

Interesting museum about tiles and lisbon. I went there when the admission if free. I think the first sunday of every month is free. It was nice to see all tiles and how they used for even decos and in churches. At the end of my trip I made a new association between Portugal and sardines and tiles. Nice visit on other days as well.

Visually pleasing and educational. Housed in a former monastery, this museum provides lots of interesting information about the process and history of tile making. The displays of various tile creations are nice to behold. Highly recommended, even though it's a bit out of the way (but easily reached by bus).

Very Disapointed. I thought that this museum would be more interesting and maybe have someone making titles. It is not very big and not in the best part of town. I asked the bus driver if he knew the museum after sometime looking at the map he said yes, then forgot to tell me!!!! So a long walk back!!!

Take the bus 759 to visit, ask the driver, where to get out. Nice place to have a look at thousends of tiles from 16. to 20.century . Highlight : Lisboa relief ( before earthquake )Make a stop in the little restaurant: We ordered 1 crepe C/Bola Gelado ( "US size" ), 1 mousse de Chocolate Case2 Cappucinos and a bottle of water 1/4 l and paid only 12.30.The service was excellent and friendly as the waiters in the museum ( entrance: 5 E for 2 persons + 65 years).

This was a fantastic museum.. The tile work is amazing. The history of the tile for decorative use in Portugal is very interesting The museum was fantastic. Our tour guide from the cruise line was amazing. We painted our own tiles. This was an optional tour for us but sure as heck worth the price.

Spectacular... well worth the visit. This museum tells the story of the azulejo - the ubiquitous decorative tile seen all over Portugal from the time it was brought to the country by the Moors, through its development as an art form across the sixteenth to early nineteenth centuries. From the early figurative tiles to geometry to art-works to the kind of "statement" (look for the set commissioned by the merchant telling his life story), it's all there and it is beautiful. Only the last leg after about 1850 when industrial production meant that it ceased to be an art form is in any way disappointing.(One other small point: the French-made documentary shown on the last stretch is like all French documentaries: too wordy and too long, but that's just nit-picking).Decent cafe downstairs serving good food at reasonable prices (€10 buys a main course and a coffee). Bus service from Santa Apolonia station stops right outside. I think it cost €5 for entrance, which is a steal. Just go.
Really beautiful artistic site. This is fantastic - it is wonderful to see the historical development of tiles and the influences from different cultures
Portuguese tiles galore. Well worth a visit! Beautiful displays, from traditional to contemporary. The chapel is magnificent. Nice gift shop and restaurant. Bus 728 stops right at entrance.
One of my highlights of Lisbon. As well the building with its beautiful rooms as its collection are worth the trip from the center. Gorgeous!

Finding our inner artist!. We were on a private tour, with Viking River Cruises. Our guide gave us a wonderful historical review of azulejos tile in Portugal, harking back to the Moorish/Arab period in the country. Housed in a former convent, Madre de Deus, one learns about centruries-old tile making traditions. The super cool part was painting our very own azelujo tile. Don't miss the original/expanded chapel in guided baroque style.

Lovely place for pattern lovers. This museum is a bit hidden and out of sight so I recommend to grab a taxi to go there. I really liked this place, you're gonna love it if you like pattern design, tiles, graphics etc. The building itself is also very impressive and it has a courtyard where you can dine too.

Fabulous Museum. Although it is a cab ride away from the center of Lisbon (5 euros) this museum is a must-see. The museum is set in a former monastery and showcases the history of the Azulejo (tiles) in Portugal from the 16th century to contemporary times. The displays are gorgeous, especially the incredible, opulent chapels. Plan on spending a couple of hours there.

If needed this is the place to go to be convinced that Tiles is a full art.. This place is not well located but in walking distance from the nearest Metro station.The museum is slightly decaying from the outside but worth the visit . You will find the most outstanding collection of tiles I have ever seen . This is simply spectacular . Don't miss the Lisbon panoramic view .. The visit is designed around the evolution of the Tile art and techniques over the centuries. Very well done. Don' miss the museum cafe, this is a very lovely place

Worth trip!. Although this museum was located a bit far from the center, about half hour walking distance, no metro, and few buses. It was worthwhile to a trip there. Amazing thousands of different tile patterns, colors, and applications. No miss the panoramic view of Lisbon before the earthquake in 18th century, the view was delivered with tiles! No miss the museum cafe, nice setting, gardens, drinks and very good price!

A well designed exhibit that shows the local art form through the ages. If you've enjoyed, or just studied the tiles at multiple castles, monasteries, and churches throughout the country, you still will learn from and enjoy this thoughtfully designed and displayed museum. The restaurant in the museum is also a great place for a light lunch. If Lisbon is your first stop in Portugal, seeing this museum early in your trip will enhance your enjoyment of subsequent stops in castles, monasteries and churches throughout the country!

Lot of information and make your own tiles. This was included as part of our tour of the city and found it a very good museum. Very extensive examples of ceramics and tiles through the ages. We even had the opportunity to paint our own tiles which were glazed and returned to us later in our cruise.
Beautiful!. This museum is quite unique and worth a visit. Great display of vintage tiles and also some modern ones. Beautiful church within the museum also.

Beautiful. Went there... central Lisbon.... a MUST see! The tiles in Portugal are everywhere... facades of buildings, inside apartments, churches, museums, the metro stations, etc.... stunning..... ART meets Culture!

What a collection of tiles throughout the ages. See tiles from hundreds of years ago right up to modern day ones. You will be amazed at some of the picture tile designs. Some of the colours are so vivid and rich many depicting scenes from the bible, but the blue, yellow and white patterned ones are also stunning. It is all housed in an old monastry so a great building to look at as well. The cafe was good with plenty of choice of meals and snacks

Loved this place, a must if you like art/tiles/chruches. Gorgeous collection, informative, and one of the most elaborate and beautiful churches I have seen. There is a great courtyard cafe where you can get some sunshine an a bite to eat. If you are into 16th and 17th century art it is fantastic as well.
unique tile museum. A unique museum installed in a ancient monastery, Has the richest collection of azulejos you can find in Portugal . Well worth your visit.

Quite interesting but more information required. This could have been so much better if there had been more information available. Not only was there inadequate information on display, there was no guide leaflet or anything else unless you wanted to buy a whole book in the gift shop. The tiles were quite interesting just as objects to look at and a surprise was the unbelievable ornate, gilded and opulent monastery attached. I don't think I have ever seen such amounts of gilding! We went by taxi and came back on the bus which stops nearby. A member of staff explained that they will be working on the information side so hopefully this will improve.

Stunning!. One of the most striking aspects of my visit to Lisbon, was the beautiful design of tiles across the city. So I had to visit this museum, and was not disappointed. It's quite a way out from the city-centre so I took one of the many tuk-tuk taxis which was an experience in itself (it is accessible via public transport though). The museum is a must-visit. It is not expansive which means you can fully appreciate what's on offer without the stress of knowing you're never going to see everything. With beautiful exhibits and fascinating history of tile design in Portugal, it's worth visiting (and is just €5).There is a cafe and garden for refreshments on offer too.

Unexpected gem. Our 20 year old daughter was insistent that we come here and ate we glad we did. Yoy don't have to be a time lover to enjoy this place. The blue tiles are gorgeous - I bought a fun espresso cup and saucer with a beautiful tile pattern (BTW espresso in Portugal is better known as bico!).
A most interesting museum. This is a must see for anyone interested in the tiles that you see everywhere in Portugal. The tiles are beautiful and colorful.
Tile lovers must. Very well organized and displayed tiles, azulejos, from the 13th century to the present, especially interesting for artists and architects

Breath-taking and interesting. This museum came highly recommended to us by our hosts in Lisbon and they were not wrong. Housed in a former monastery and church, the museum takes you through the history of tile-making in Portugal and (in October) had a wonderful temporary exhibit of contemporary tile-art. The garden cafeteria is lovely, a really lovely spot to eat lunch, or enjoy a late afternoon coffee and cake.If you are 65+, admission is half-price (but you need a copy of your passport for proof of age).
If you like tiles. The museum is a little far from the center but worth the trip. Buses go there and taxis are cheap. An amazing collection of tiles which is what the country is known for.

Excellent displays, history, venue. What a great museum and we are so glad we visited. Set in an old Monastry not far from the centre of town this museum has excellent displays and very detailed information. The church of the Monastry is spectacular as well and would be worth a visit on its own. The displays have tiles from the 14th century through to contempory and you can also watch staff work on restoration and preservation of tiles. Has a nice cafe. Quite reasonable price for entry and cafe. Bus 794 will get you there from town

Very special place for special art.. There are some fantastic tile works in this museum, and the old monastery where is located is a perfect location to host the location.New (modern) tile works and ceramics look mostly pitiful in comparison to the old master works This happens a lot when museums make the mistake of hosting both old and new works. You end up with the feeling that you could do better than the modern "artists".

Out on the tiles. This museum features all key styles of Portuguese tile making - from the early post-moor days through to modern times. You can't escape tilework in Lisbon, and this museum has a variety of decorative and figurative examples. Much of the figurative work is a bit primitive with faces and animal shapes lacking proper proportion, particularly some of the religious-orientated work.Some of the best tiles are part of the structure of the former church that houses the museum - although much seems like it was an add-on. Make sure you go to the top floor to see the 16th century panorama of Lisbon made from hundreds of tiles.

Fabulous tiles and great cafe. I loved the tiles in the church and the others on display, especially the panorama. We also ate first in the Iovely café and really enjoyed that too. We took short taxi rides to and from and it was worth the effort.

Good for an afternoon. This is a very relaxed museum, in a rather different part of the city. It was good time to spend in the afternoon they have a nice outdoor cafe and some interesting collectables.

Monastery turned museum. The museum is located a bit far from central Lisbon, but it is easily accesible by bus (for example 759 from Rossio will take you there in 10 minutes). It gives you an insight of the evolution in the use and production of tiles, from ancient times to the present day. As it is located in an old monastery an interesting part of the visit is the church, chapels and cloister.I didn´t like much the fact that there is no clear signs to the exit. It looks that once you get to the end of the exhibition rooms you have to undo all your walk to reach the exit again. I would also add some lockers in the entrance, or a cloakroom. Being a national museum it would be a positive point.

The best tile museum I've ever seen. OK, so it's the only tile museum I've ever seen, but it's hard to imagine a better one. The building is superbly suited for the role, with the original cloister and a number of chapels remaining, and the selection of tiles is amazing, starting from the 15th century right up to contemporary tiles. They start with Moorish influenced geometric tiles, and then flow through religious and various types of secular tiles. Don't miss the huge panoramic of Lisbon on the top floor created in 1755. Another nice feature is various points where the manufacturing and artistic techniques are explained and, unusually, while it loses its way occasionally there are explanatory boards in English almost throughout. I know a tile museum sounds a little esoteric, but if you have any interest in history, art, or construction technologies you'll enjoy this superb little specialist museum.On a practical note, we went on a Sunday and it was free, so I assume that this is the norm. Also given that it was pouring down we took our car and had no problems parking outside the museum.

Off the beaten track but worth it. After a week in Spain going from El Greco to another masterpiece, it was time for a change of pace and this was perfect. Not only the tile work but the entire museum (part of a church) is special. Great place to spend an hour or so.

Amazing. I loved this place - it was amazing to see all the tiles and combinations made up. There are people there working on restoring old tiles - you can watch thru the glass - must be like a huge jigsaw puzzle for them. There is a lovely cafe on the premises where you can catch up with a meal or cuppa - it has a great feel to it. Very peaceful.
Interesting. Nice place but hard to get to. It's a hike to get there. I think you can take public transportation.
Nice, but not essential. I liked this museum, but I didn't think it was great. If you don't have much time in Lisbom, I wouldn't recommend it.

If ceramics interest you, you must visit.. Wonderful collection and housed in a lovely old building. The visit would bore people who do not have an interest in ceramics as its room after room of them. The service in the cafe was terrible, we ended up walking out. Easy to get go using public transport and all the tour company buses go.

Worth seeing beautiful . A bit out the way but I had a metro card that got me free travel on buses, if money no issue get a cab, even though taxis are cheap I was in a tight budget. It's tucked away behind a Lidls but close to bus routes. Lovely inside after faffing about with buses I got there an hour before it closed and granted I did not read everything due to time but got loads of lovely pictures. The internal monetary was awesome, there is a pretty garden cafe so get there earlier to end with a drink. An amazing tree by the entrance too (just saying) if you appreciate tiles you will love it here.

Out of the way but worth it. This is about 2 miles out of city center so I suggest you take a taxi but you will not be disappointed with the museum. It tells the history of Lisbon through its art and tiles. If you are into art it will take about 3-4 hours of the day and it is worth the time. I highly suggest it.

Fascinating explanations enhance subsequent visits to sites with azulejos. We found this very worthwhile as much for the explanations of techniques as for the exhibits. It was definitely a good idea to start our time in Lisbon here

Worth seeking out. Very good museum showcasing importance of ceramic tiles in Portuguese culture. Lots of beautiful exhibits from all eras - explanation and signage could be better but it doesn't detract too much from the experience.
By public transport catch bus 794 from near the waterfront and ask driver to put you off at Museu de Azulejo (Tile Museum)

Chicken Wedding - Do not miss!. This was an interesting investigation into the history of tiles in Portugal. There are a lot of old murals (including the Casamento da Galinha) dating back hundreds of years and an explanation of how the tile was made. There was also a stupendous little chapel that has been preserved on site that is worth a visit on its own.
Worth the trip.... Nice place to look round. Go at lunchtime...we were too early to eat but the smell of the food was amazing and the prices looked very reasonable!

Unexpectedly enjoyable. The tile museum is somewhat out of the city centre and appeared somewhat drab as we approached. However, once inside, we could do nothing but marvel at the magnificent tiled church and well presented display of tiles in the museum. We were more impressed by the church than we were by the Cathedral and Jeronimos Monastery. We almost did not visit but we were so pleased that we made the effort.

Stunning place. As if the tiles weren't enough we got to see the most beautiful chapel. Totally unexpected. There is a lovely outside area to eat and drink in. Shame the souvenirs in the shop were so expensive.
Wonderful museum!. Great museum, wonderful tiles. I love the restaurant/café with it's own outdoor garden! Well worth a visit, and actually my second visit!

A Treasure Not to be Missed. Don't let the unusual nature of this museum discourage you from visiting. Portugal is known for its heritage of beautiful hand painted tiles. You can see them everywhere as you walk the streets and ride the trams. A visit to this museum will educate you about what you're looking at and offers close up views of some of the most remarkable examples of tile artistry.

Beautiful display of tiles through the ages. Wherever you go in Lisbon, you will catch sight of tiles, indoors and out. This museum, in a church and cloisters, traces the history of Portuguese tiles from Moorish times to the present day. Don't miss the (not too well signposted) panoramic view of Lisbon before the 1755 earthquake, all in tiles, on the top floor of the building.One criticism, however. The lighting is poorly arranged, shining so brightly on sections of the tiles that you can barely see them (and photos are ruined by the reflective glare). I thought this might be a ruse to sell more postcards in the shop - and would gladly have bought cards of my favourites - but selection of these is also poor. You will have to buy the (expensive) guidebook if you want souvenirs.

Excellent museum set in an old Convent but out from the centre. Magnificent selection of ceramic tiles including a tile panorama of old Lisbon before the 1755 earthquake. Museuem set in an old Convent which includes a gold smothered baroque chapel

Portuguese Tile Museum. This museum, located close to downtown Lisbon, within an old convent, is well worth a visit if you are interested in the beautiful tiles of Portugal. We took a cab from downtown for about 6 euros. The tiles date back many centuries and depict some interesting happenings in the country. There is one long panorama view portraying the City of Lisbon before the earthquake of 1755 (located on the 3rd floor). The convent part of the museum is also worth visiting with many beautiful artifacts. The gift shop was well stocked with interesting and unusual items to purchase at reasonable prices. I know I will revisit this museum on my next visit to Lisbon. You can check in out on the internet to get more information.

One big WOW!. Be committed to get to this place - an old convent with absolutely exquisite azuelo tiles throughout, that serves as a backdrop to a history of this motif. Room after room of beautifully crafted and assembled montages of various tile applications and many restored rooms demonstrating the use, and beauty, of this building material. As this was a convent, the chapels and other places of worship within are magnificent examples of baroque design and genius. The museum is located along the waterfront in an area best reached by a 10 - 15 minute cab ride from Praca Commercio. If you are a admirer of Portuguese tiles, this is a "must see" on your itinerary.

Good if you are into decorative arts. Firstly, take the 759 bus from Rossio square to the museum, and use your viva card. Then eat a healthy lunch in the museum cafeteria (very good) spoilt with a beer in the courtyard. Then tackle the museum.It is a lot to take in, and although useful to see how tiles gave changed over the centuries, it takes up a lot of your time. After a while one set blurs to the next! However, its an interesting museum, and the Lisbon panorama is a must see.Too dull for children, quite interesting for adults. Most areas are accessible with some help. Cafe reasonable prices. Local area not pretty to look at. Lidl is nearby!

Tiles, tiles, tiles.... Room after room filled with ancient to modern tiles, beautifully displayed. Wonderful experience, would be enjoyed by older children, young adults and those on the older age group.

Excellent museum in and old building a church. If you like old tiles, this is a great place with many amazing tiles. The collection is quite large with mostly older tiles and some modern exhibits. The building is old and there is even a church as part of the museum. The most impressive thing was the large panoramic tiles of Lisbon in older days. The entry fee was only 5 Euros.

Very good museum, if it interests you. We were taken to the Tile Museum as part of a city tour, and spent about 45 miinutes being guided through the exhibits. The tiles are beautiful and the history is interesting. For me, it wasn't a "must see" and not one of my favorite things, but if you like museums and/or want to know more about Portuguese tiles, it is very well done.

Great for Those Interested in Hand Painted Tiles. My wife and I visited the National Tile Museum during our visit to Lisbon in mid-September. It is located in an old convent not far from the city center. It is a very tranquil place and the hand painted tiles with some dating back several hundred years are exceptional. The venue is accessible via local bus or by a city site seeing bus. We had lunch at the museum in an open air courtyard area which was very calming until a couple of tour groups arrived just before we were leaving. I especially enjoyed the numerous gargoyles on the exterior of the structure. The gift shop also had some nice things not just the typical touristy stuff and was reasonably priced.

Two sites in one! Old convent building and storey of tile both!. The tile museum is housed in a former convent and the building is an architectural jewel, and would be worth visiting even with out the tile. Well curated, it explains the development of tile manufacture, as well as the social and societal changes reflected in designs and pictures seen on tiles. Nice cafe and clean nice restrooms.

A must see museum!. This is a great place to visit considering the use and history of ceramic tile in the art and architecture of Portugal. The museum is beautifully arranged and you don't get 'museum coma' walking thru the various rooms. The site is an old convent and school, an intersting building to see. The entrance price is very reasonable and it is easily accessed by bus from city center... a 5-10 minute ride.There's a great restaurant on site with delicious food and a place to sit in an outdoor court yard and relax during your visit.Very interesting and colorful.

If you are tiled of Portugal you are tiled of life.. Located in a stylish 16th century convent this interesting museum has beautiful examples of azulejos spanning the entire history of decorated buildings in Portugal. The star attraction is the 36m long panel of pre-earthquake Lisbon.The museum cafe is has a lovely outdoor area with fish ponds.

Wonderful glimpse into Portuguese history and art. Set in a beautiful majestic building, this museum offers a rare look at Portuguese tile, mostly centuries old. A wonderful museum to walk through, take your time, and enjoy.

Uniqueness!. After your visit, you'll admit the uniquness of this museum whether you enjoyed it or not. You might not find any other museum that lookalike! Personally, I loved the museum. Very well organized! You know exactly where to go and what you've already seen. Not a small museum, it will be worth your time and money but also not needlessly long. And forgeting the museum itself... There is a SUMPTUOUS AND MAGNIFICENT church inside the museum... Might even be my favorite one in PORTUGAL!!!!! + The staff was super nice! Great job!
Off the beaten track .... The museum is located a little further than the usual tourist sights, but we found the attraction well worth the visit.

Background On Those Blue Tiles - Azulejos. Everything you ever wanted to know (and more!) about azulejos from their primitive beginnings and uses to the latest styles. Requires a bus ride to get there, but it's an easy one and takes you by the Olympics stadium. Go by the Hop On- Hop Off bus lines and try to sit on the upper level for the best views.
Definitely Worth a Visit. This amazing presentation of the history of Portugal's tile is beautifully presented in a former convent. The chapel is not to be missed!

Tiled disappointment. After reading the great reviews on here I was somewhat disappointed. The tile museum was ok but the tiles displayed were nothing special. I got more of a WOW factor when looking at the tiles out on the streets of Lisbon. It wasnt a wasted trip as I was impressed with the building itself. The restaurant in the courtyard was fantastic and very relaxing atmosphere with great food and service. However there wasnt any tiles here. A few tiled areas on the walls would have been nice!!

A Stunning Museum. If the many tiles (azulejos) you see around Lisbon interest you, I suggest you take the time to make your way from central Lisbon upriver a mile or so to this fabulous museum. You proceed from one fantastic exhibit to another and see the intriguing history of this characteristic Portuguese art form. One could spend hours in the room displaying the massive tile work depicting the view of Lisbon with its marvelous detail. This is an absolute "can't miss" Lisbon sight.

We felt obliged to visit this one.. Interesting Museum, and wasn't initially on the list of sites we'd planned on visiting, but on seeing all the tiles on buildings around Lisbon, you start to almost feel an obligation to visit this Museum.Beautiful collection, but have to admit we did start to slowly speed up as we worked our way through the Museum, as there are only so many tiles that can astonish and take your breath away.... Lots of detail to photograph and enjoy.Definitely recommend it.

A unique museum!. This is really a Portuguese museum and about a traditional hand made work very Portuguese, the (blue) tile. Just enter and you will be astonished with the beauty of the genuine tile work that still covers many walls in Portugal.

A morning well spent...... A perfect morning spent here with friends on a week long trip. Portugal has such a long history of tiles so if you are interested then please go and visit. Its free with the Lisboa card - 72 hours.It may not be the easiest to get to, bus only but still worth it. Then spend some time in the nice garden have a coffee and a friendly staff. The coffee is not over-priced for a museum at all and again, the staff is really polite and sweet.

WOW. It's a bit far from city center and hard to get transport but worth the extra long walk or taxi fare. One of our best visit in a museum. The place looks great and seeing people work on old tiles and trying to assemble pieces is really cool.

History and Beauty in Traditional Setting. Don't miss this museum, especially after admiring all the fabulous Portuguese tile in the metro stations, on the walls of buildings and in the shops. This museum has easy to understand displays of the evolution of ceramic art from ancient times to the present. There are examples of tiles in all different styles from all time periods. On the top floor is a panorama in tile of the city of Lisbon, saved after an earthquake. There is a small coffee shop and a lovely courtyard for refreshments. The gift shop is tiny but exquisite. We took an affordable taxi from downtown to get to the museum, and it was well worth the trip. The museum building itself is beautiful and wandering through the halls brings an aesthetic delight at every turn.

Tile Museum is beautiful and gives history of tile. wonderful exhibits through the history of tile making and art, not near Lisbon center so need to take a cab or hop on hop off bus tour. worth the trip.

Breathtakingly Beautiful!. Anyone who likes ceramics will love this place ...and if you don't there's something wrong with you and you should get help. It's fantastic, so many beautifully patterned tiles and bonus, a lovely cafe set in a pretty garden. What's not to like?

One Sunday afternoon at The National Tile Museum!. To hear many people talking about the National Museum of Tile, aroused my curiosity to visit it. So one of these days I jumped to see what it really like!... At the beginning I found not so interesting, but along the way the stories were developing, becoming an increasingly interesting and educational visit.
Can't be missed. Something exotic, ancient and unique. The baroque adjacent chapel just outstanding. Far away from the city centre, but worthwhile
Portuguese history. Portuguese history cannot be telled without the Portuguese tiles. As you will see in your trip to Portugal, they are everywhere. Go and see this beautiful space.

Don't miss if you are in Lisbon. One of the most remarkable things in Portugal generally and Lisbon and Porto in particular, is the widespread use of ceramic tile, both in geometric patterns and large scale "painted" scenes. It has been said that what the decorative art of fresco is in Italy, azulejos (tiles) is in Portugal. Whether you go to Sao Bento station in Porto, the university chapel in Coimbra, or the Arab Room of the Sintra National Palace you will see masterpieces of the art of decorative tile. In addition, many homes, churches and businesses in Portugal have elaborate and beautiful tile facades.The National Tile Museum provides a fantastic venue for starting to learn about and appreciate tile art. It has many wonderful examples of tile installation, most salvaged and saved from locations where they otherwise would have been lost. There is also considerable technical information about the hows and whys of Portuguese tile as well as historical background. Also on the premises is a restoration shop as well as displays of modern tile artists' work. It is really an enjoyable and valuable experience and an aid to appreciating Portuguese culture.Highly recommened

Interesting. To get to this museum u can take the metro until Santa Apalonia and from there a bus.The museum has many different kind of tiles (Azulejos).....mixed coloured, blue/white with several kind of designs...floral, showing scences from the life, modern. Everything from different periods of time.The most impressive tiles collection, for us, was the city view of old lissabon.
Excellent. I had the chance to recently visit this museum one of the best in the world on the Tile heritage. In the same building you may also visit the beautifull Monastery of Madre de Deus.

Azulejos means tiles!. Visiting this museum presupposes an interest in tiles, and not just for bathrooms! The setting in an old convent is lovely and the tiles are very well exhibited. The sumptuously decorated baroque church was an unexpected delight. Definitely a highlight of our visit.

Museum?. This is not a museum as such, you do not get the history of the tile but you do get a few ideas to decorate your kitchen!. After the 6th or 7th room all the tiles do seem to become a blur but the illustrations on the tiles are fascinating. If you are taking a camera there is NO flash photography. The garden by the cafe is worth chilling out in as there are many fish and a few terrapins in the small pond to watch!. The easiest way to get here is the Metro to Santa Apolonia and then the bus No 759 or 794 to Igreja Madre Deus, the bus stop is right outside the tile museum.

National Tile Museum. Beautiful tiles on view in this museum. Take the bus though as the nearest metro leaves you with quite a walk to get there. Have coffee in the courtyard cafe but don't bother with lunch.

If you like tiles. It was as we entered the eighth room of the Museu Nacional do Azulejo that we realised that we were in fact completely surrounded by tiles. We were three quarters of the way through the museum when we could no longer feign interest. We later realised that Museu Nacional do Azulejo translates to National Tile Museum (This was not mentioned in our Lonely Planet guide). As you can perhaps tell, we have absolutely zero interest in the area.Despite this, the museum does have some brilliant and beautiful tiles exhibited but little to no contextual information is displayed and so we left with no more knowledge of the history and origins of the tiles than what we had begun with. If you do happen to appreciate tiles then you may well enjoy the Museu Nacional do Azulejo with its impressive collection, but we couldn't help but wonder if our Lonely Planet guide was being sarcastic when it said that you hadn't visited Lisbon unless you'd visited this museum.(We apologise to the hardcore of the tile appreciation society for any offence caused, but a trip to Topps Tiles would probably be cheaper)

Nice for lunch and to help you plan kitchen tile design and splashback. This museum is a bit out of the city centre but there is a good bus system . The restaurant and restaurant garden are particularly nice . Some of the nicer tile displays are actually in the restaurant. The pond is full of turtles. The museum is informative on the history and manufacture of the tiles.

you will never see anything similar. Tiles are very much in the Portuguese tradition, this is a unique museum set in an old convent from the 15th century already with 2 cloisters and an incredible small church covered with tiles to which were added in the baroque period paintings and ornate wood carvings.

A great surprise!. The Museum is located in an Convent with a magnificent chapel and a little church! One of the most rich decoration I have seen in Lisbon. This was a great surprise for us since we were not aware of the museum building history. Other great surprise was the Museum per se!! Magnificent tiles collection. And very well displayed with good didactic too.
It is inside a beautiful old convent. You will enjoy learning the history behind all the tiles you see everywhere in Lisbon. The museum is interesting and has a nice café.

Going here really helps you appreciate the beautiful tiles of Portugal!. I was here on an outing with Viking River Cruises and really enjoyed the museum and learned a lot. I have a blog and wrote a post about the museum here http://blondebrunettetravel.com/national-tile-museum-lisbon/

Great find!. Spent a wonderful afternoon here. Very interesting, very beautiful, well displayed. Provides a better understanding of the history of tile making in Lisbon. Suggest joining a tiur if ne is available. Nice coffee shop. Gift shop - fair.

Magnificent jewel of a museum. A wonderful display of tiles and their history in relation to Portugal, dating back centuries in a beautiful monastery. Although out of the way, it is about 25 minutes walk away from Santa Apolonia station and well worth the walk.We stayed for a meal in the beautiful garden restaurant, which was very reasonably priced. Definitely recommended if you are interested in tiles.

A wonderful collection. A wonderful collection, well organized by periods beginning from the 1500s. On the 3rd floor there is a beautiful composition from before the 1755 quake, picturing all Lisbon's major buildings, its almost 100 feet long and amazing.

The most beautiful azulejos. The museum is situated a bit far from the center but is really worth a visit. You will learn about the history of Portuguese tiles, the azulejos, and see how they are made throughout the ages.
Buy a combination ticket together with Pantheon to skip the line in the latter.
Excellent!. It is one of the museums to be visited.The colorful tiles and ornaments are worth seeing.Don't miss it!

A delight. If you love tiles this is heaven and it is also excellent if you are interested in history (fabulous pre-earthquake tile panorama with funny little donkeys and masses of churches). The cafe is worth a visit - for the tiles!
Nice bit of history . We loved the museum and it's collection especially the top floor full Lisbon map. It is best to visit with the Lisbon card.

Beautiful Tile Collection. When visiting portugal and Lissabon one of the most enjoyable things you will see everywhere are the mosaic-works and tiles everywhere in the city. When you want to see and learn more of the history of Tiles in Portugal the Tlie Museum is a must. Located outside the citycentre, so grab the bus or taxi. Ask bus driver where to get of, he will certainly tell you where to get of. From there it is short walk to entrance. Museum has a really large collection of tiles and is still working on preserving more works and restarting complete mosaics. The building is also a cool get away on hot sunny days. When we visited in may 2014, we suddenly bumped into the first lady of turkey who paid a quick visit at the museum. Some of the works made me think of dutch 'Delfts Blue' porcelain. Except for old historic works there is also more modern tile-art to be seen. Although not in the best neighborhood we explore the streets around museum afterwards and shows some other scenes besides the touristic lisboncentre streets.

The good and the bad. The good: interesting, quite comprehensive overview of tiles. As it is part of an old convent, you can visit the old church decorated opulently with tiles and gold, paintings etc. The museum has a very nice cafe with a shaded outdoor courtyard. The bad: getting to the museum is a mission. On the website it only cites bus lines (the numbers) but not where to get them - so very useless. We decided to take the metro until Apolonia and then walk. Not very advisable. We followed the street under the highway next to the harbour - which did not feel particular safe - until the Lidl and then turned left and before the railway left again. Nothing is signposted - so we had to ask. Back we took a bus to Apolonia which was much easier, but I would advise people to take a taxi. Overall it dd not seem that the museum has a great interest to help people to find it. The book/gift shop was disappointing too. Every touristy shop in town has more postcards of Azulejos than the museum.

Really cool museum!. It was cool to learn about the history of tiles and the amazing work that went into making each one. It's a nice size and interesting varied exhibits. I found this museum really interesting!

Unexpected surprise. The Museu do Azulejo was a good surprise I wasn't expecting. You can understand the history of tiles in Portugal and visit a beautiful palace/monastery altogether. Thumbs down to the ticket lady who was a bit rude and the screening on one room that had the video of the director speaking in French without translation to Portuguese

Loved the Tile Museum. A beautiful museum filled with historical tiles. Everyone in out group enjoyed this museum, even if they weren't art lovers. Make sure you look at the church too. We didn't eat in the restaurant but it looked like a great place to relax. The gift shop was a little disappointing.

Quite disappointing - not a great experience. It was one of the firsts museums I wanted to see in Lisbon, I had great expectations. Maybe this is why I was so disappointed... It's not impressive, the tile collection it's not that big (especially considering that this is one of the most important Portuguese traditions and decorative elements), the staff is pretty stiff, the information in English is quite limited and it offers you nothing experiential. And the building itself... looks so depressing. It's very deteriorated. Inside the Museum wasn't very clean either... It's not near a metro station, but the bus 794 has a stop right in front of it. It's pretty close to the Water Museum (which is very interesting), so I recommend a trip to both on them in the same day. With Lisbon Card you have a Free entry, otherwise the ticket costs around 5-6 euros.
Hidden Gem.. We were not expecting so much beauty and such a big museum. Old and contemporary azulejos, amazing panels, church, stairs, cloisters... Including a wonderful terrace cafe. Will be back.

Hidden gem of Portuguese History. Tile is part of portuguese culture and history. This museum represents tile evolution very well and deserves a visit even for lisboetas. I went there saturday morning: few people, free parking just in front and time to see it. 3 floors showing the evoltion of tile with the following highlights: free visit to Madre Deus Church which is just amazing how gold combines very well with beautiful tiles; Madere Deus Crib just a beautifull masterpiece very well conserved and for last Lisbon before 1775 major earthquake widest Panorama is amazing. This time we even got to see Pritzer Prize Siza Vieira exibition on tiles and other works. Mandatory once in Lisbon, despite being a little bit distant from city center, but the building and exibition deserve the visit. I will come back for sure. The shop itself has very nice things to be as gift or for yourselve. No abusive or unsipatetic employes.

Terrific tiles. While this museum is a little off the beaten path it is not that far perhaps just a 6-7 euro taxi ride from city center. If you like tiles this is wonderful as it has informative captions (in both English and Portuguese) for the exhibits which are organized chronologically. All Portugal seems to be an exhibit of azulejos but the museum explains the different kinds and techniques. The museum shop was a little disappointing but the cafe has a lovely cool relaxing courtyard worth a stop for refreshment.

Beautiful collection. This museum was just a nice way to spend a morning. I took the 794 bus from Rossio and the bus driver showed us the stop - I met a fellow traveler going to the same place. I got there when it opened and it was very quiet and I felt like I had the place to myself. The tile exhibits were impressive and they had decent explanations in English for most sections. The chapel inside was just beautiful. I wasn't expecting it and it was just really impressive. Overall it you like tiles, it is a nice way to spend an hour or two. They also have a nice cafe inside in a covered patio.

undiscovered treasure of Lisboa. A wonderful gathering of tiles from different epoques and styles. It's interior church and patio are breath-taking as most fascinating monuments from Spanish Alhambra.

Beautiful Collection. I really enjoyed this museum but to me, the highlight was the chapel inside. Lisbon has many beautiful Churches, Cathedrals but in my opinion this one was just amazing. The combination of dark wood and the blue and white tiles were the most beautiful I ever seen. The altar had very intricate woodwork and the choir room with all the saints encased in wood boxes were very different.

If you're into that stuff you'll love it . This place is a bit far from other attractions and museum , it's near the national pantheon (Santa apologia metro ) you can take the 794 bus to madre dues street. Be careful because on hot days this bus only goes one way. There are other buses that can take you to different metro stations tho.This wasn't really my thing but I enjoyed the visit and wanted to see the famous Portuguese tiles. I loved the stands for blind people to read and feel the tiles that impressed me a lot!!!

FABULOUS CHAPEL IN THE TILE MUSEUM. The tile museum itself is quite fascinating. The range of artistic expression from medieval to classical to renaissance to modern is astounding. But the tile museum is not the best part. Adjacent to the museum and in the same building if I remember correctly is the most astonishing baroque chapel I have ever seen anywhere. It actually outdoes the Jeronimos which is vastly superior in size. The extent of the detail upon detail will leave you absolutely breathless.

Beautiful tile collection not to be missed!. This is a great museum with a fantastic collection of tiles. The building itself is beautiful, located in the former Convent of Madre Deus including a very ornate chapel. We had lunch in the cafe which was pretty basic but quite cheap. There is also a nice shop with a good selection of postcards. There are many museums in Lisbon but this one is really worth a visit If you're at all interested in the decorative arts.

out of the way but worth it. the tiles from portugal are just beautiful. this museum does a beautiful job of presenting them historically. the setting, an old monastery, is beautiful. a bit out of the way but easy to get to w aa 5 euro cab ride from rose.

Worth a visit. We got a taxi as it was a bit out of the way, taxi only cost less than €10 each way.
Beautiful selection of historical tiles. I wish there was a bit more information in English about the tiles but it was enjoyable nonetheless.
The cafe is set in a beautiful courtyard which is very peaceful.
Best place to visit. Great conservation of this 16th century building, with impressive architecture! More than impressed to visit the place!

Tile Museum with a twist!. This visit was an added excursion to our trip that I didn't expect. It is a beautiful old building refurbished to exhibit tiles, porcelain, clay, glazed, old and new. We were also able to create one of our own to experience how they were hand-made with painstaking skill and artistry.
Limited appeal for us. This museum was not bad, but less interesting than other European national museums. Mostly paintings and sculptures of a religious nature

I loved it! . Ok, I love tiles so it was a great place to visit. Wasn't expecting the museum to be part of a beautiful old church. Stunning. No need for a tour. You can get the metro, then a bus (2 stops) and pay €5 pp for entry. Cafe was reasonably priced too.

My favourite museum in Portugal. I've been planning to visit this museum dedicated to azulejos or typical Portuguese tiles for the whole summer, and today I finally did it. The building in itself is worth visiting - it's an old monastery with really beautiful cloisters, also perfect if you're in the company of very active children (like I was today - see below).There was a vast selection of tiles from about 1500 to your days, plus temporary exhibitions. It was just breathtakingly beautiful! While I was admiring the artworks, my kids were running in the corridors and cloisters, and the personnel didn't seem to care; but then again, most Portuguese seem to be very child-friendly (having lived three years in Germany, I know it's not the case everywhere!).The entrance fee was next to nothing - the family ticket only cost 5€. There's also a reasonably priced coffee shop/restaurant, serving quiches, salads, and crepes.

Museeum. Kind of boreing place but it was fun to se some kind of tiles and pictures of tiles. I was there with my boyfriend, The straff were wery rude and wanted us out at exactly at 18 pm when they closed.

Tile-tastic! Best Tile Museum...Ever!. If you visit one tile museum in your life make it this one! Haven't had such a cracking day since it was 3 for price of 2 at my local Tops Tiles store!This is a walk away from the last stop on the Metro Line (Santa Apolónia on the blue line), as it was hot we took the easy 794 bus from in front of the train station. It goes right by, look for a massive church tight on your left, the entrance is through a area with big palms and nice plants.It's in an old church, and accordingly some of the museum is a church. There was lots to look at, it took a decent amount of time to get around, and to be honest I preferred it to the Gulbenkian art gallery. There is a really nice cafe-restaurant attached. Loads of bathrooms dotted about the place.It cost €5 to get in, though it's worth checking if they do free entries on Sundays (lots of the museums in Lisbon do). Outside and along is the massive Port with cranes, crates, trains, if you want something to look at.

Visiting Azulejo will find 3 good places to see. The Azulejos of Portugal were on my place to visit in Lisbon.I don't know if there is a fee to pay because we get Lisboa cards and pay nothing.I wanted to start visitng the museum with the last floor where you will find a room sorrounded with Lisbon from above- of course tiles images- I was very impresed- do not miss that floor!Every room and space there was a joy, unbelivable!Then, we visited the chapel and spend a long time there, admiring it- this was the second placeAnd after all these marvels we had a very nice break in the garden- nice coffe, good lemon ice cream, ginger ale and pancakes.So, 3 in 1

Azulejo Treasures in a Beautiful Setting. Beautiful. Simply beautiful. The work exhibited and the building itself. The chapel inside is one of the most extraordinary rooms I have ever seen. Quiet. No crowds. Very informative. Takes you through the exquisite art of Azulejo chronologically with a final floor dedicated to contemporary tile work. The cafe outside was in a lovely, peaceful patio/garden. Our Lisboa card got us in (get that card if you go to Lisbon!)

Very interesting look at the Azulejos of Portugal.. Nice museum with a lot of variety of exhibits. Shows lots of styles of the tiles of Portugal in all different settings and includes some modern tile art. Many exhibits on how the tiles are made. You also see some beautiful architecture and woodwork. I actually loved seeing the huge amounts of tiles that are being restored.
don't miss the Tile Museum!. Interested in either art or history - this museum set in a fabulous old building has both. Excellent display and explanations.

Dont walk there, too far. We tried walking, take the bus (didn't realise how far it was and thanks to trip advisor on my phone it got us completely lost, thanks trip advisor! Museum Ok, really nice café to chill in

worth a visit. If you are fascinated with the beautifully colored and rendered tiles seen all over Portugal its well worth spending a couple of hours at this museum. It is a bit off the beaten track but easy enough to get to. There's a great gift shop and inviting restaurant at the museum.

Decent visit, interesting building too. A very interesting building with a fairly comprehensive history of azulejos! We liked the material on how they are produced (more could be done on this though) and a good sense of how the artwork has developed into the twentieth century. We lost a touch of interest halfway through, in part because the tiles of the c17th-c19th become less distinct from other European art, but contemporary work at the end was also interesting.A bit of a trip out - I might not recommend for a 2-3 day Lisbon break but worth it if you have the time.
