Hidden gem. Lovely collection of tiles, with historical backgrounds and beautiful displays. Well worth your time
Nice place. We walked there from praça do comerçio- quite the hike!! But it was worth the visit. Didn't learn as much because we visited quickly but it was beautiful.

very interesting and unique museum! The venue is also very interesting, as it used to be a monastery.. The collection was very interesting and quite unique. The staff quite helpful and the restaurant very nice, under the trees.Wheel chairs are available.
Worth a visit!. Didn't expect to learn so much from tiles! A 10 euro entrance fee for two people. Worth the time out of your stay in beautiful Lisbon.

If you like "Azulejo", go for it !. Azulejos are a national treasure for Portugal.
The museum has an awesome collection from different eras and places.
A must to visit if you like them.
Tip (if you come by car) : Put your car on the Lidl parking.
It's free for 2 hours. Enough time to wrap up the visit.
The history of the traditional tiles!. The best place to know about the history of the wonderful tiles that cover the outer walls of so many buildings in this marvelous country

Wonderful collection of historic and contemporary tiles. Fabulous museum -- a bit out of the way -- but worth the trek. Beautiful collection of historic tiles. Immersive rooms decorated with period tiles ringed around a central courtyard. A gallery for contemporary pieces as well. I was able to borrow a wheelchair from them to bring my grandfather all around too, which was great.

Stunning!. Housed in a wonderful old convent with a very ornate chapel.. Large shady courtyard. The tiles were absolutely stunning. They dated from the 15th century and were beautifully displayed. On the top floor was an extraordinary panoramic view of Lisbon as it was before the 1755 earthquake, all in tiles of course.
Old tiles. It was worth seeing the history of the tiles and the importance of this technique to the history of Portugal. They were beautiful and stunning!

Worth the visit. We decided to walk there from Santa Apolonia station but the route was a little more complicated than we thought involving walking over the bridge. I'd recommend just getting the bus from Santa Apolonia or Restauradores, it is quicker and less hassle! The bus stops right outside the building too. Beautiful tiles which also shows the history of azulejos. My favourite was the azulejos showing the panoramic view of Lisbon on the top floor, showing Lisbon as it was prior to the 1755 earthquake. You can spot some of the landmarks that remain (Castle, Convento do Carmo etc.) but also many that no longer exist. Absolutely fascinating! The courtyard was very nice and looks like a nice place to sit and have lunch after your visit, but we came in the late afternoon and the cafe was closed. We spent an hour looking around.It's definitely a bit "out of the way" from the center of the city, but if you really want to learn more about azulejos/see some beautiful examples, I would 100% recommend coming here. I didn't manage to fit it in during my weekend trip in March as there was already so much to see, but now I am here for a few weeks this July, it was easy for me to make time to go.

What a surprise of great gem. This museum is located northeast of outside of Alfama area, the public transportation is not so easy, need to ask locals which bus to take or check the bus map; there are more buses at the main road can reach close by, only take 5 minutes walk to get the museum. The building is hide behind a railroad wall, hard to see it on the street, may need to ask locals.Inside the museum display different period of tiles and ceramic decorations from Moors through Spanish influence and the development of Portugal's own style. The museum connected to a stunning Baroque decoration church.

Amazing azulejos (tiles)!. Beautiful tiles showing the fascinating history of Portugal, including art works from the current century. The displays are all well lit and presented and we spent much longer on our visit than expected. The jewel in the crown is the original, if partially repaired, panoramic view of Lisbon before the 1755 Earthquake. See if you can spot the remains famous landmarks!

National Tile Museum: Horrible Woman at Front Desk. We were just at the tile museum and had the most ABUSIVE experience with the front desk receptionist. It was a woman who was horrible, hostile and aggressive. I have travelled the world and have never had an experience like that in a place that is a tourist attraction and especially from the first face you see when you enter. I truly hope she is not there in the coming weeks as she is either mentally ill or was a jail warden in her last life.

Nice Building - Shame about the Rude Receptionist. The building is quite charming, the tile collection nice enough and the chapel beautifully decorated, that said, our experience was coloured by the rude, bordering on aggressive receptionist. This is a shame as everywhere else we had received warm welcomes, finding people friendly and helpful.

Something different. I went here on a recent trip to Lisbon and it was great. Something a bit different to the typical museum and the actual building of the museum is beautiful as well.
Easy to reach by bus.
Just too beautiful. Beautiful, beautiful! Don't forget to visit the top floor for a panoramic tiled view of olde Lisbon.

Well worth a visit.. I very much enjoyed this museum that provides a history of tiles and tile making in Portugal. It would have helped if more of the description were in English as well as Portuguese, but I got enough information. An added bonus was the very ornate chapel used by the nuns of this former convent. I had a lovely lunch in the courtyard. A very enjoyable 4-5 hour activity in total.

Fantastic tile displays and Lisbon panarama. I love historical hand painted tiles, so I really enjoyed this place. It is in an old Baroque convent. Great panarama of Lisbon made with tiles on the second floor. It's just off the waterfront past Alfama district from town. Nice gift shop.
worth the time. A tour into a very old artisan art dating back to the Arabs. Azulejo (tile) derives from the Arab word Al-Zuleich.

an oasis of quiet - unique. Not only are the exhibits beautiful, but the actual lunch served was one of the most pleasant restaurant sites we had -- so relaxed and beautiful. The whole setting is very special, quiet, and designed to allow you to really focus on the artwork of the tiles… a very refreshing change from the intensity and the crowds of the churches

Great for tile and mosaic lovers. This is quite pretty but only if you like tiles/mosaics...plus it's a bit of a hassle to get there but the taxis in Lisbon are cheap. If you have lunch in the peaceful courtyard, it's cheaper to order at the counter and carry your food out to the cortyard. Also be aware that the lovely gift shop closes for siesta time as I sadly learned the hard way...so plan accordingly..

Portuguese History. Excellent well laid out displays and friendly staff. Interesting setting in beautifully adorned religious building. You can see restorers working on future exhibits. Great cafe in cooling courtyard. Would have been 5 star if the shop hadn't shut for lunch!

Overall interesting, worth a visit.. A really interesting building, with an ornate church, and some really impressive pieces such as the huge view of Lisbon before the earthquake. Very pleasant to walk around, lots of interesting pieces but also quite a lot of ordinary looking tiles that you can see on the outside of lots of buildings. Worth the entrance fee for the special pieces mentioned above, and the church. Staff were not overly friendly, more interested in pointing out when the shop closed than which way the exhibition started. It's not that difficult to get to either.
beautiful. I love azulejos. They have plenty of them there. Everywhere. So, if deciding whether to visit or not, the question is: how do YOU feel about azulejos?

Interesting Museum. I was very interested to learn about the history of tiles in Portugal because one sees so many beautiful examples of tiles all over Portugal. This museum does not disappoint. It goes from the origin through to modern examples. There is a lovely cafeteria to have a bite to eat. There is a bus that takes you right there.

Exquisite collection of tiles from the centuries. To truly appreciate Lisbon's tiled homes and businesses, visit here to get a sense of the history of the tiles in this area. The museum includes an exquisite church as well. Understated older facility filled with treasures. You will not be disappointed.

Worth a visit!. We didn't have high expectations before we arrived but were pleasantly surprised by this lovely museum. Spent a very pleasant afternoon wandering around the museum. Lovely courtyard cafe featuring terrapins was an added bonus! Well worth a look - good value.

Interesting and beautiful museum . A must go when you're in lisbon. Takes about 20 min bus ride from the city centre. Entrance fee is about €2.50 for students. Beautiful painted tiles design throughout the museum.

Lovely museum. This museum is a bit off the beaten track, but it was a quick cab ride from Rossio Square, and I took the bus back to Rossio. As a great fan of tile, particularly Portuguese tile, I thoroughly enjoyed the museum. It is housed in an old convent. The building, especially the chapel, lends atmosphere and provides a lovely setting for the chronological presentation of the development of Portuguese tile. There is a contemporary exhibit of tile as well. I happily spent about 3 hours wandering through the rooms. a pleasant lunch area with courtyard is available for a break.This museum won't appeal to everyone, but it is nice for those who like tile and/or appreciate Portuguese history.

What a treat!. If you are into decorative art or if you are simply amazed at the tile work throughout Lisbon, you will enjoy a visit. Very reasonably priced. A bit out of the way but on a city bus route and close enough in for a quick taxi ride.

Worth a visit if you are interested in ceramic tiles. This place is out of the way and you will require some effort to get there but well worth it. The tiles are magnificent and give a history of Lisbon. There is also a variety of tiles to see and appreciate. The church is simply stunning, both upstairs and down. The tiles in the cafe shop are a treat.

Worth a Visit. It's a bit out of the way, but well worth going to. The different methods of tile making through the years was especially interesting.We went by bus and had no trouble getting to or from. The people were helpful and the cafe was good as well.

Must see museum in Lisbon. A short taxi ride from the city center sits this museum of the history of tile work in Portugal. Very extensive and impressive collection. On of the highlights includes a spectacular church full of , not only tile art, but other amazing works. A must see museum in Lisbon.

A must see. Many lovely historical tiles to see but we especially liked the early 18th century display depicting the city as it was before the 1755 earthquake. Worth a visit for this alone, but there is much more. It's a bit difficult to find. Look out for Lidl - it is in the road just behind it. If travelling to or from the museums at Belem, such as the coach museums, the 728 bus goes all the way.
maybe not that famous but absolutely worth the visit !. really educational and a surprise at every room, including a church and other amazing rooms ! a pleasure for the eyes !

Great Choice. After visiting the Maritime Museum, we hopped on bus 728 and went out to the Tile Museum. It's about 15 minutes from the city center. Nice ride along the water.This being our third visit to Lisbon, we decided to go out to this museum.The museum is wonderful. There are many rooms to explore. The colors are beautiful, and knowing many of these are made by hand made it even more fascinating. All types of designs and patterns, and an interesting chapel as well. It will take at least an hour to give this museum a good walk through. Take your time and enjoy!

Not in the centre. A lot of tourist doesn't realize what they miss, when they not visiting this museum. It is a little far, but you take a bus, or a cheap taxi and you are there in 15 minutes from city center. And then you wonder. What kind of tiles are here around this is unique. Tilse from the 16.-17. century, and modern ones - amazing. The 30 meter wide Lisbon panorama tiles are unforgettable. And on the top of the museum - there is a chruch with such ornaments that you just stand and you can't even breath. It is simply wonderful. If this is your program, take 2-3 hours.

Fantastic Museum and church. I took advantage of the fact that government run museums are free of charge on the 1st Sunday of the month to visit for the 1st time the Tile Museum. The museum exceeded my expectations, i had no idea it was that good. I especially liked that large panoramic tile of the City of Lisbon before the earthquake but also the church that is located within the museum grounds which i had no idea existed. As a Portuguese national i'm a little embarrassed it took me this long to see it. Duration of visit : minimal of 90 minutes.

So glad we went; just a fast taxi trip to get there. This was absolutely the best thing we did in Lisbon. It was soooo lovely - relaxing and not crowded. I was a little worried that the presentation would be too academic, but it was just one beautiful room after another.

Awesome insight into Portuguese tradition. Admittedly I knew very little about Portugal and its art before visiting. I'd say this museum introduces so much to anyone with my level of knowledge (or lack thereof). The collection is gorgeous and vast, organised by century and style. You can also see tile restoration being done.It was a little difficult to get to, but worth the extra effort.

Worth the Visit. As a fan of Portuguese tiles, this was a must-do activity. Take the bus from Restauradores and arrive in 10 minutes. The museum will take 1 - 1.5 hours to explore. More if you are detail-oriented. Look for the 'chicken wedding' tiles--very interesting. My favorite part was watching the workers repairing historic tiles on the first level.

More extensive collection than I realised. It's a bit of a tricky one to get to. We got the metro so far and then tried to find the bus stop for the correct bus to get to it and couldn't and ended up walking quite a distance. In hindsight, I'd have got a taxi after we got off the metro. We did catch a bus from the stop outside on the way back.It was a much bigger collection than I'd have thought and the large panoramic tiled scene at the top was really interesting and impressive. There were tiles from the 1600's and 1700's in really good condition. There were also some modern pieces which were works of art. I'd recommend a visit.
History and evolution of the tile industry. How tile was made, evolution of themes, colors from ancient to very modern times and utilization. Take 2 hrs to visit every part of the museum.

If you only visit one museum in Lisbon, this must be it.. Located in a middle age monastery a little out of the centre towards the Expo area, the huge museum impresses you already at the entrance.It tells the reason for the Portuguese tile tradition, the reason for the blues, the production techniques and Portuguese history in beautiful mural arts.The truly impressive church alone is well worth the visit, but then again, don't miss the cafe and the shop.My favourite section is the top floor with modern tile art and a 30m display of the Lisbon city line before the earthquake and tsunami disaster.

Great Place to Visit - Make Your Own Tile. A thousand years of history in one museum that is well laid out and fun to visit... and you can make your own tile! What more can I say, fun, educational, entertaining, and a great value.

Very interesting museum. I went to the tile museum with very little expectation and it blew me away. The intricate work on the tile exhibits is fantastic. I highly recommend a visit and spend some time there. You will not be disappointed.

A must if you're interested in the culture. A bit out of the way along the river but you can hoof it through the Alfama, past the military museum and along past the station, up the overpass path, turn left over the tracks, first right and about 1/2 mile. Again we got reduced entry. Take your time. You can get tiled out but there are good displays of the history of tiles in Portugal and the techniques used through the years for production. Also when we were there there were modern tiles with varied designs including some with Escher type optical illusions -really!The old convent church (that's where the museum is) is lovely and the art works well preserved. There is a very airy and light tea room serving drinks and fairly substantial snacks. Allow 2-3 hours for the visit. Afterwards when you leave cross the road and go left under the bridge then right. Brings you back out onto the main riverside road right by a bus stop where you can get right down to the Monasterio

Wonderful tiles and a great cafe. The displays of tiles are wonderful, from geometric Moorish patterns to huge elaborate painted scenes. The building itself it also very interesting. We particularly loved the inner cloister, with its intricate stonework and lovely tiling. We also enjoyed the cafe in the large leafy courtyard, which is quiet and relaxing, and served a tasty, good value lunch. The only drawback it that some of the translations into English were obviously not done by a native speaker, and were sometimes incomprehensible! Also the museum is very low profile and hard to find - it's just off most city maps which seem to stop at Santa Apolonia. Best to look it up on Google maps. Coming on the the bus from town, there is no visible sign and we went past and had to walk back, asking people. If you go past Santa Apolonia Station and then go under a railwaybridge, get off! The museum is just back into town from the bridge, on the right going toward the city centre.

A Few Hour Trip. We took the bus from the city center and arrived at the Tile Museum. The Museum has very old tiles all the way to present day. The tiles are beautifully painted and it has a beautiful chapel in the Museum. We had small coffees after. Cheap to get in!
Amazing History. Well organized. Each room you walk into is a period in history. The tile work is amazing. Leave yourself 2-3 hours to explore the museum.

Worth the trek out of central Lisbon. This museum was much more interesting than we had expected with good explanations of the different techniques used in tile-making of different periods and plenty of impressive tiled panels to look at.We took the bus (as explained in the Rough Guide) to get there, but caught a taxi back - easy to do as other visitors were arriving in taxis. The courtyard cafe was a lovely place for lunch - sandwiches freshly made to order.

A History of Decorated Tiles. In the cloisters of a church (also worth a visit - Madre de Deus) this well-curated display of the art and style so typically Portuguese should be on all itineraries to Lisbon. The Lisbon panorama display is outstanding, as are the bright colours and stunning patterns of the 16th Century tiles. Well worth the visit - take a Tuc Tuc on the return journey which follows the Tram 28 route through Alfama district.

An important and beautiful piece of history. see traditional and modern tiles, learn about their significance in Portuguese history, and see a beautiful historic church all in one stop. Highly recommend.

A must visit when you're in Portugal. You will notice beautiful artworks that you've never seen before as well you'll understand the evolution of the tile from white & blue adding the yellow & than all the other colors. Enjoy

Wonderful display of beautiful tiles. Azulejos (Portuguese tiles) are a fixture of both medieval and modern buildings in Portugal and adorn some of the most magnificent monasteries and castles. The Tile Museum is housed in a 16th century convent and covers the azulejo spectrum from early fifteen century to modern times. The exhibits are outstanding, the museum a must see visit in Lisbon.

An interesting museum with room for improvement. Quite an interesting museum with a plethora of tiles from different periods of time on display. Not being a true 'arts person', I still quite enjoyed it. Make sure not to miss the huge panorama of Lisbon tile set on the wall on the top floor. A nice cafeteria/restaurant with inside as well as outdoor seating in the 'court yard' can be found on the ground level.@ The museum: What could potentially enhance the experience even further is a bit of work on the information signs pinned to the different objects;- make the information signs bigger and use better material for them- use some nice font face and increase the size of the fonts- some more information in english (and possibly french as well) would be greatThese measures should be quite cheap and easy to implement - and would even further enhance the experience for the visitiors of this museum.
Interesting. It was interesting to see the history of decorative tiles that are so significant in the country 's history. They have a great variety of tiles from various stages of history.
Great for the person who loves the Portuguese tiles. Brilliant facts on how the tiles are made and a great selection of tiles of various styles. Not for those who find art and history boring.

Lovely and intetesting museum. Somewhat off the beaten path so-to-speak, but well worth it. Bus will drop you nearby and follow your map for the short walk there. Also a good spot for simple lunch in a garden. Turtles in a fountain/pond!
Well worth the visit. Reachable by bus if you get information first. Tile is important to Portugal and this museum shows excellent examples.
Breathtaking and amazing. Worth the trip from the centre. This should be on your must see list. 3 floors of treasures. Plus a beautiful cafe and shady garden to rest after your tour.

take your time.... I am a fan of Portuguese tiles, so it was a must for me to visit the museum. I liked it a lot.The only minus - some explanations nxt to tiles are only in Portuguese, as I speak very little Portuguese, I could only guess, what is written there.

Much more than tiles.. An amazing convent with baroque chapel and of course the tiles are stunning. We used Yellow Hop-on Hop-off buses, good and ticket includes lift and trams. This museum is Stop No 6 on Olisipo route.
One reason for the trip. Amazing and beautiful - history and many examples of the tiles over the years. Can be reached on one of the city tours or the bus. Well worth it.

Beautiful and interesting collection. This museum I would rate as one of Lisbon's best and demonstartes the great art of Portuguese tiles in one convenient location. I would rate it as unmissable if you are a museumgoer and interested in the arts in Portugal.
Who Knew?. Not pretentious, but informative. They taught us about the history of Portugese tile making. It is also friendly to those with disabilities. You are best served taking a taxi to get here.

By all means go!. You might think your interest in tile is limited but if you enjoy beautiful art in a magnificent setting trek over to the "off the beaten path" location and enjoy the surprise. Lunch is offered in the cafe and is excellent!

Simply Amazing. I was surprised by the vast collection of tiles. From almost the very beginning to modern artistic work. The chapel is jaw dropping. Learned a lot in the process and really was so surprised by the breadth of material and information.

If nothing else go to see the frieze of Lisbon pre-earthquake. It's an interesting museum to visit , set in an old convent ( the choir & chapel are breat-ta kingly ornate) There's plenty of information about tile making ( especially on the audio guide) and (as someone who's not a tile specialist) you can see how the techniques evolve over the centuries.It's a pity that the garden has isn't looked after - unfortunately full of weeds smothering the roses - perhaps the gardener is off sick.The star piece is undoubtedly the frize of Lisbon before the devastating earthquake - it has pride of place on the top floor & is well worth looking at even if you don't use your entrance fee for anything else! However there are some other lovely little gems to look out for. And the cafe is pleasantly cool & green & you can watch the terrapins in the ornamental pool

Beautiful tiles in a lovely old convent. Really worth a visit to see a vast collection of mostly Portuguese tiles. The Panoramic view of Lisbon before the earthquake in blue and white tiles is the highlight!There is a lovely little shaded terrace at the back of the museum for refreshments after you are finished looking at all these beautiful tiles...
not to be missed. excellent………a real must in Lisbon….best thing with bacalao…stay there as long as you can…..it's great….

Surprise. This is a little out of the way but such a fabulous museum. It showcases in an old convent the tiles, both old and modern and in various formats. The cafeteria/restaurant is in an enclosed garden and well worth a sit down, especially in hot weather.

Interesting experience. We were on a tour and were taken here as an option. It was 44 euros with the tour, not sure of the price independently. The tour was very interesting, and at the end we were invited to make a tile ourselves which was then eventually returned to us on our River cruise. It was a unique experience, and the display of tiles, Portugese vs Dutch was fascinating. Would recommend to anyone interested in this medium.

A Nice Experience for those Interested in Azuelos. If you are interested in Portuguese tiles, this is a good museum (if not--don't go.) Housed in an old convent, it displays lots of tile work and explains the various production processes, styles, etc. You can catch a glimpse of staff working on the restoration of tile works as well. The chapel here is stunning.
Fascinating Morning. Good value (5 Euro) and fascinating low - key exhibition of tiles through the ages and cultures. Well worth 2-3 hours of anyone's time

I loved this fabulous museum.. Wow, this is a real hidden gem. We were on a small Selection Tour on a rainy Sunday and many sites were closed. Our great guide picked this museum because it has so much of Lisbon's history portrayed and illustrated through the azulejos. Oh, and it was open! The tiles, for which Portugal is famous, are beautifully displayed in an old convent building, complete with cloisters. I was impressed with the detailed stories and history portrayed in gorgeous works of art. If possible, fit this great museum into your itinerary. You will not regret your decision.

Well Worth a Trip Out of Town. A bit difficult to reach by Metro and foot but plenty of buses stop outside.Formerly a convent but few original features remain.Despite this I enjoyed my visit. The tranquility of the museum was a welcome respite from the bustle of LisbonThe Ideal restaurant, just up the hill from the entrance fed me well and inexpensively on sardines!

Superb museum!. Really wonderful visit, loads of different azulejos displayed, from small pieces to real scenes. There is a film in French/Portuguese that was very interesting but unfortunately too long (52 minutes) so we watched only a part of it. You also see them manufacturing the tiles (no photos unfortunately there). The bus 794 stops just in front of it, you can catch it in the street opposite the Casa dos Bicos. The museum shop is small and quite expensive, we did not buy anything there.
Well worth a visit. The museum is very interesting and well worth a visit. Also well worth a visit is the restaurant. We had a lovely meal in a great setting and the staff were fabulous.

Loved it!. Not the easiest place to find, but most rewarding once there. The most fabulous collection of tiles and interesting history, all set in a stunning building. After exhausting,ourselves walking round we enjoyed an excellent lunch in the café where the staff, and in particular the restaurant manager, were absolutely delightful.

The 'before 1755' display of Lisbon is amazing. Whilst beautiful, the tiles are an interesting way in learning about Portugal's history. The display of Lisbon of how it was before the 1755 earthquake and tsunami is fabulous
Fascinating. Tremendous beauty here, and a hidden gem that I won't spoil. We learned a lot about Portugal, and its history, but we mostly looked and admired. So glad we did this.

Worth a visit. Beautiful museum situated in an old convent building dating from the 1500s, this museum tells the story of Portugal's famous tiles from beginning to end. I highly recommend you get the audio tour as the display information is minimal and you learn so much more through the audio guide. Seniors pay half price and the museum is closed Mondays. There is a delightful cafeteria/dining room with an outdoor garden that is a wonderful place to relax and have lunch part way through your visit. Don't miss the Baroque chapel. It is a bit outside the city proper but cabs are frequent, accessible and inexpensive. A true gem of a museum!

Fascinating collection of tile. I'm super intrigued by all the tile in Lisbon, and enjoyed visiting this museum. The church that houses the museum is amazing, and some of the original interior is still there. It is incredible. I especially enjoyed the tile panorama of Lisbon that is on the top floor.
Spectacular. Nothing had prepared me for the beauty of this museum the quality of presentation , colours and variety were all wonderful.

Never though a tile museum could be this good!. I have to say I was a bit sceptical about a tile museum but it was only 10 mins on the bus from the town centre and was free (1st Sunday of every month) so gave it a go. I was really surprised on the variety of tiles and the amount of time we spent there. Definitely quirky and specific to Lisboa.

Hidden treasure. We expected tiles...we got far more! Amazing selection of different tiles from throughout the history of Portugal but then we turnrd upstairs and found even more incredible sights...a full chapel with the altar all in gold. A lovely young man was there to explain it all to us in perfect english...he was so knowledgeable about the relics, the misericords and the figures made in former centuries. Wonderful sights and such a great commentary from the young guide. Then there was the cafe! Sumptuous cakes with very good service in a lovely setting...a room with tiles and artifacts from the past. Easy to get a taxi outside back to the hotel which only cost £5 up to Eduardo VII park.

Excellent small museum. This museum is somewhat out of the way on the eastern edge of the city. It is about 6 to 8 blocks from the nearest Metro stop, and the walking was not particularly relaxing because of disappearing sidewalks. Nevertheless, if you have any interest in or appreciation of tile, don't miss this museum. It is enjoyable just for the pleasure of seeing marvelous examples of tile of different styles and from different times. If you want to learn about the history of Portuguese tile, that information is there too. Finally, the restored religious building that houses the museum is beautiful.

A must see place in the land of tiles. Although a bit of work to get there, for us, bus and walk, it was very well worth the effort. The tiles from very old to very modern are well displayed and very clearly visible at a comfortable height. The colours and motifs are very interesting as you see the decorative tiles as part of religious and housing decoration. The chapel is also an incredible example of art. Within the convent walls, you will see fascinating architecture with lots of arches, colourfully tiled stairwells, etc. After our viewing time, we enjoyed a coffee at the lovely outdoor patio where they also serve lunch and snacks. When is Lisboa, you must go if you enjoy the colourful tiled buildings you see everywhere.

Second only to the Gulbenkian among the museums of Lisbon. This is an unexpectedly interesting and beautiful museum. It has a wide range of tile works, dating from the 1300s to modern works. They are arranged in settings that make them easy to view, and are provided with good explanations in English. There are exhibits explaining the different processes used for making tiles through the centuries, along with examples illustrating the differences in form, style, and type of decoration. Most of the exhibit rooms have ramps making wheelchair access easy, and there is a lift to the second floor (although you do have to ask at the ticket counter to use it). The personnel in the museum were very helpful and courteous. The easiest way to get there is by taxi. It cost about six Euros from the city center. The taxi leaves you off at the entrance to a courtyard. You can catch a return taxi by flagging one down at that same courtyard entrance. The restaurant was quite good, and very reasonably priced. They had veal lasagna the day we ate there, and it was quite good. You can see the museum in an hour, but allow two if you really want to enjoy all of the tile exhibits. Walk the three major neighborhoods of Lisbon, visit Belém and Sintra, visit the Gulbenkian, but then by all means visit the National Tile Museum.

Tiles Galore. Again housed in a former religious establishment the tile museum houses displays from the very old to very new. There is a massive display of pre-earthquake Lisbon that is interesting. This is done in traditional blue tiles. There is also one (pictured) that is more colorful and I found more interesting. The chapel of the former convent is magnificent. Tile musuem is well worth a visit

Great place for history and ceramics. Not to be missed is you are art type and enjoy ceramics. Well presented exhibits and large variety. Seniors over 65 remember you ID (passport or licience) will do

Fascinating Art!. we used the hop on hop off to reach this out of the way museum and we are glad we did. Beautifully preserved early works of tile and a gorgeous chapel that shouldn't be missed. Only disappointment was the gift shop closed early so we couldn't purchase a tile from here.

If you have the slightes interest in tile - don't miss this!. This museum is a real gem! and the beautiful old chapel is an extra bonus...(be sure and go upstairs!) I know, there is so much to do in Lisbon, and this is a bit off the beaten path (taxis do come by however, just be a little patient) but really worth a visit. You can get through the exhibit in two hours if you are pushed for time...The only drawback is that there is very little English translation available to explain what you are looking at....so you are going on chronological dates much of the time but you will still get a good sense of things.

DO NOT MISS!. OK, Lisbon is the 'Tile City'. Museum is well worth the taxi fare. Take proof of Over 65 to get senior discount; copy of passport will work. At front desk, ask for audio guide; we provided passport #, when signing audio guide log. When you leave the museum you will have an appreciation of the history of tiles. Make sure you visit the chapel; an eye opener! Just wonderful. We had lunch at the courtyard café; reasonable & good food and service. Wife and I rate this museum #1 on our Portugal & Spain visit. ENJOY!

History of a typical Portuguese decoration. Wherever you go in Lisbon, you see tiled surfaces everywhere, on historic buildings, metro-stations or bridges. This feature goes back to the middle-age and the arabs. The Tile-Museum is located in a former monastery near the riverbank and shows beautiful examples of tiles of all stiles and epoches, also several of the large tile-paintings. The restaurant besides a well-planted courtyard has a very special atmosphere. Negative: Some inscriptions are notz bilingfual and only in Portuguese, which goes for many museums.

Worth seeking out. Got a bit lost tiring to find this place. Lovely peaceful setting including courtyard cafe and beautiful church. Felt we had the place to ourselves and enjoyed the great variety of tiles on display.

Pleasant surprise. This is a gem that's a little out of the way, but worth the effort to get there. The museum is located in a former church and monastery and has extensive exhibits on the history of tiles and mosaics in Portugal as well as modern pieces.

1h interesting visit. It's a very interesting museum, not very big, worth planning for a 1h visit. If you visit various palaces in Lisbon and Sintra, maybe you can skip it though. Alternatively, a great way to dive into the story or azulejos! There is a bus stop 4-m form the entrance.

Beautiful, a great visit. I had such a great time at this museum, on my short, 3 day visit to Lisboa. This was such a beautiful, well-done museum, and such a low cost to visit. I loved seeing all the exhibits and artwork, tile is a very beautiful art form and a form of storytelling dating back thousands of years! There were many pieces that you could tell had been worked on for hours to restore, and some in original form. There was also a sort of cathedral, church (?) onsite that was quite beautiful to tour.

Beautiful . This museum is a bit of a walk from the centre of town, but worth it. A relatively small museum, but a huge variety, all housed in a beautiful former convent, including an astounding chapel. It's an interesting art form, and very important in Portugal, so definitely worth learning about.

Best attraction in lisbon. This is a brilliant museum....housed in an old monastery it has a fabulous collection of tiles...beautifully displayed ....it has a fabulous cafe and courtyard...the museum has access tho the most stunning church you will see anywhere...there's a display of tiles depicting Lisbon in the 15C before the earthquake....this panel was found in the basement of a church

Gorgeous!. My family stayed in Lisbon for nine days during the first week or so of April. Out of all the places we went to, the National Tile Museum was one of the many that left an impact. The colors were bright, and the tiles were all rich with art and history. It is definitely worth the visit.

well worth finding. This museum is housed in a former convent in the district of Xabregas, Lisbon on Madre Deus street. The following buses go to the museum 718,742,794. Its quite a long way from central Lisbon but worth the effort. If you dont read Portuguese maybe it is best to hire the equipment, as not all sections are translated. As well as showing the finished tiles and panels there are stands which explain the early techniques used and these are not translated. The tiled panels are beautiful and the choir is richly decorated with gold leaf.Dont leave without a visit to the cafetaria in the former kitchen - reasonable priced, home-made food with attentive service.

Learn about Portuguese Art. This was a cool place to visit to learn about Portuguese art. It wasn't very expensive either. It wasn't overwhelmingly amazing, but it was still really cool. I had a good time and would recommend it. It's small so don't plan to stay too long though.

Art through the ages. This museum has tiles from many different centuries and in many different styles. The processes for producing the tiles are explained in detail, and the museum is also attached to a beautiful church that has paintings from the 1700s. If you are interested in art, or tiles, or just like to look at pretty things, this is a great way to spend an hour or two. There is a cafe and gift shop attached, and adult admission is only 5 euro.

birthday and family trip. This museum was the last on our list. We were glad that we did make it as the collection was just amazing. All the tiles and palaces/sites we'd seen came together in this museum. The techniques and colours and history all made sense. Beautiful displays of ancient and contemporary tiles.

So much to see for just 5 euros. You can happily spend half a day here, marvelling at tiles through the ages, seeing how they develop through the centuries, and looking at their intricate designs. Gorgeous artwork. And a very nice courtyard garden in which to lunch or sip a glass of vino if you so desire.

Great intro to tile. This museum gave us a terrific introduction to Portuguese tile. We spent another three weeks in the country -- including Porto, Braga, Guimarães, Cascais, Sintra -- and all the tile we saw in situ in those places made much more sense to us. Very decent cafeteria too.

Must See for Art & Design Aficionados. Azulejos are the signature national art form in Portugal and this is the place to explore their history and see terrific examples. The museum is off the beaten path from many of the tourist attraction in Lisbon and is best to get to by taxi; it is close to Alfama district and is good area to parley into a day. The museum is pretty big, so allow a couple of hours to explore. There are several galleries, so the information map from reception is a great resource and guide. Don’t miss the top floor that has a wonderful panoramic tile mural of Lisbon that was completed just prior to the great earthquake in 1755. I’ve been to Lisbon a couple of times, and this is my favorite attraction.
Interesting, if you can't go to Sintra.. The tiles are much better viewed in real historic buildings, but this is a good place to see a lot of tile in one place.

Interesting one of a kind museum. The National Tile Museum is the only one of its kind in the world and it was very interesting to see how this art form was incorporated into the architecture of many of the buildings, churches and palaces in Portugal. Especially impressive was the panorama of Lisbon created entirely in blue & white tiles.The museum is a little out of the way but easily accessible by a short taxi ride from the center of the city. The museum is part of an old church that is one of the most beautifully decorated in Lisbon. There is also a small café where you can have a light meal and sit either indoors or out in a small garden.
very unfriendly. i went there with friends and the receptionist was just unfriendly. the exebition was ok. not more to add.
Too much fun!. come, spend some time and find all the funny faces you can!! Lovely tiles and a fun few take your picture here cut outs.
History!. Great examples of tiles throughout the centuries and how they developed. Exhibits are on a grand scale (in all respects!) and show the skills and artistry that went into this work.

Out of the way but surprisingly striking. When I told my husband I wanted to visit a tile museum he joked that it was to get bathroom renovation ideas. This is not that kind of tile...The museum's downfall is that it is not near a train stop. We got off the train on the water side and ended up having to cross a major highway bridge to get to the right side of the road. Lesson: if you take the train use the underpass to exit on the town side, not the water side. After a long walk to the tile museum we were rewarded with a well laid out, manageable museum. There are 3 floors around a central courtyard with well labeled signs to go into different rooms as you circle around. The chapel is a surprise and a delight. My previously grouchy husband admitted that the transit hiccups were worth it when we reached it.

Fascinating history!. At first I was skeptical of a museum dedicated to tiles and it's history, but my fiancee convinced me to go. Wow am I glad she did, and I realized how little to nothing I knew about tiles and the fascinating history of such beautiful work. The museum and the church next to it are well worth the time to see the evolution and beautify of tiles. It gave me an appreciation and better understanding of the tile facades on the buildings all around Lisbon. So much so that I bought some to bring home!You can take public transport to the museum and church but we walked there from downtown. It's not a hard walk and you get to see the parts of Lisbon where people actually live work and play, away from the tourist traps.
Azulejos Museum. Beautiful museum located in a convent wich explains the history of azulejos and their evolutions. Worth seeing as it is definitely a strong part of Portuguese culture.

Weekend in Lisboa. Here you can have a nice overview and history of tile making in Portugal. A timeline from the middle ages to recent is covered and even workshops are available to make your own tile.

Tiles are just tiles - right? No.... This is a fascinating museum showing the development of tile making and the way styles have changed over the centuries. I particularly liked the modern section. We were here as part of a tour and I'd have liked longer to look around. The cafe in the courtyard looked very enticing but we didn't have time to try it.

A remote but quiet place to enjoy the azulejos. As the museum is a bit remote, you need to take the metro to Santa Apolonia first and then the 794 bus to the Rua da Madre de Deus stop.But because of its remote character the museum is not overcrowded and you can take your time and enjoy every exhibit.

Ceramics Like You've Never Seen Them! Who knew???. A lovely and atmospheric museum offering a superb introduction to and celebration of the fine art of Portuguese tiles. The modern contemporary exhibits are engaging and of the moment, w there are unique historic works that can be seen nowhere else.
A must visit!. A must see on you visit to Lisbon. Inside the museum is a beautiful church also and the tiles have been restored to perfection in places.

Much, much better than it sounds. Set in a beautiful cloistered courtyard this place provides a good illustration of what good design can do - some of the colours and designs on old tiles just work so well. A real bonus is the cafe - really friendly staff, great ambience and top value for money - we enjoyed a great light lunch here.

Really cool and different!. Portugal is all about tiles. It's a must see museum especially for people who like looking at something out of the ordinary. The tiles collection is beautiful and picturesque. It's a little bit difficult to reach but once you are there it's worth it. If you spend more time in Lisbon it's good to know that every first Sunday of the month it's free of charge!

Highly recommended, great musuem.. The museum is located a little outside of the city center. We actually walked it from Alfama, took us about 25 minutes (not the most inspiring walk - but during the weekend you pass a nice flea market on the way). The museum is located in a great building and the church itself is one of the highlights. We really loved the collection. A different kind of art, a nice change from the standard "painting" museums you would visit during a city trip. You will need about 1,5 - 2 hours to see the entire collection, and afterwards you can drink a refreshing beer in the lovely garden. Don't miss it.

Serene Ceramics. A short bus ride out of the city centre gets you to the Museu Nacional do Azulejo, housed in a quiet and peaceful converted convent. The route through the museum is designed so that each room tells the story of when they were introduced to Portugal and how they were made, also how they developed over time to reflect the Portuguese personality. Tiles on display date back hundreds of years giving you a real sense of their history whilst the modern exhibits bring the development of this beautiful and practical artform right up to date. The setting is delightful too, with cool cloisters and a large chapel highly decorated in gold. There is a good sized cafe with an outside seating area in a shaded courtyard which was also cool, peaceful and relaxing.

Worth the stop. Plan 2H. Tourist bus stop just the other side of the street.Be sure to reserve at least 30 minutes for the Madre Deus Church accessible from the Museum. Gorgeous with relics of several saints.

Gorgeous gem. I found this museum a gem. One of the great beauties of Portugal is the tile work and this museum presents a gorgeous array of styles and different traditions. From the capricious and whimsical and fun to the terrific Geometric both of old and modern traditions. All housed in a lovely old building, nice book gift store as well.

Tiles, Tiles, and MORE Tiles!. Honestly, I never thought I would be interested in going to a tile museum. We were encouraged to go by other visitors, and I'm glad we did. It only takes a few minutes in Lisbon to realize the significance of the tile in the city's architecture. And at this museum one can view a multitude of tiles (or azulejos as they are known in Portuguese) and learn a bit about its place in Portugal history. The museum is housed in the Madre de Deus Convent, which has one the most beautifully ornate chapels I have seen, comparable to any in Rome!I think you can enjoy the museum in less than two hours.We ate at the cafe and found the food to be quite enjoyable. Interestingly enough, the bathroom in the museum are practically tile-free. Several of us thought that was funny, as typically it's a common place for them.

Great museum; worth the trip. This museum is located outside of the central tourist area of Lisbon but it is worth the trip if you are interested in decorative arts. The museum is housed in a former monastery, the remains of which becomes an important part of the museum experience. The museum presents the history of tiles in Portugal and has some beautiful pieces.
Excellent museum. This museum is a bit out of the way, but it is worth your while to visit. It has a wonderful collection of historic to modern day artful tiles and an exquisite gold encased chapel.
must see if any appreciation of tiles. Tucked away in a neighborhood this museum one of a kind.Anyone with a passing interest in tiles will love.

Worth searching out. A tile museum sounds boring. This isn't! No metro station nearby so a taxi or bus is required. We used the 794 bus from the city centre and were there in about 10 minutes. Set in an old convent the museum displays tiles dating from around 500 years ago to present day and ends with a panoramic display of Lisbon before the great earthquake. The church attached to the museum is also quite stunning. We spent 2-3 hours visiting with two teenage children without hearing 'we're bored', so can't be bad!

Not as boring as it sounds. This museum is set in a stunning 16th century convent with a truly amazing church and is full of the most beautiful tiles old and new. It shows the history of tile making and how the designs have changed over time and the different techniques involved to make them. It's a really informative museum full of stunning ancient and modern tiles and with a panoramic landscape of Lisbon pre earthquake completely made out of tiles. We did the free audio guide in English and got a lot more out of the museum doing this.
A must!. This museum shows the history of Portuguese tile through the ages. It's a relatively small museum and you need to either take a bus or taxi to get to it. Exquisite tiles!

Must do.. This museum is unlike any other I have ever seen. An old gilded church where tiles are meticulously restored and reconstructed by hand. Every turn was breathtaking. Tiles from several centuries made me want to tile my whole apartment. Unfortunately, I am renting. There was a movie on the 2nd floor that--though in French--inspired me to visit (and notice the tiles on) several of the metro stations, including Campo Grande. Unfortunately, the salesman in the gift shop was not very patient with my friend, who could not decide quickly enough for his taste between several of the exquisite painted fishes he had on offer. However, we did not let this dampen our experience.
a part of Portugal history. it´s a must . Don´t forget it even if you don´t love tiles ...the best collection in the world So many designs so many colors, at least see some rooms ...

Tucked away. This is a fascinating museum if you like Portuguese tiles. I love blue and white as color combinations. Some of the older, classic designs are complicated and feature animals. I prefer modern, more abstract, almost Japanese tiles.

Interesting. Worth a visit. The lisbon panorama tiles are particularly interesting and the church is nice. Theres an attempt to explain tile making but it is confusing rather than enlightening. It is a long way out of the city centre but is served by buses
Tile Museum. You won't see a tile museum like this anywhere else. Quite a stunning collection in a lovely old building. Tiles as a work of art, reflecting different styles and cultural influences.

A day on the tiles. This place is wonderful. An old church with tiles added, never seen anything quite like it. The day we were there the curator was very helpful, and really added to our understanding and enjoyment. Lunch was good in the cafe too, with a good healthy selection

Do Not Miss Visiting this Museum. Portugal is famous for its decorative tiles (azueljos), and this museum highlights some of the best. It's a great way to learn the history of this art and there's even a hands-on area where you can create your own. One large tile depicts Lisbon before the earthquake. The setting is in the 16th Century convent of Madre de Deus. The convent's chapel is a Baroque wonder to behold. Decorated in paintings and (of course) tiles with its ceiling and choir in carved wood with rich gilt embellishments. It's easy to get to the museum by taxi. Entry fee is 5€ and half price for seniors. And rounding it all out is a very nice restaurant.

Travel through the timeline of tiles. It is hard to believe that such an interesting and extensive collection can be exhibited just on tiles! This museum followed the history of tile making and design, from Islamic patterns through handpainted religious scenes and secular motifs. There were some stunning examples of all types. The church, which features much gilding as well as azulejos (tile) friezes, is very grand and impressive, and the museum is housed in rooms off the cloisters. The culmination is the panorama of Lisbon, handpainted on tiles, on the second floor. There is also a good cafe/restaurant on site, with azulejos friezes of a smokery and kitchen, which serves good coffee and food - a necessity as you will want to take your time on this visit!
Very interesting museum. Great way to learn about Portuguese tile. Small but with a great collection of tiles from many countries. Having a guide to explain the differences was very helpful.

Tiles tiles and more tiles. Lisbon is well known for its tiles and this museum is dedicated to all things tile. They are actually really beautiful and some buildings in the city are completely adorned with these ceramics. It is nice to go to a place dedicated to the history and the heritage that has made Lisbon so well known for its tiles. It's worth seeing if you're in the area. Im tried to enjoy it for what it was and my wife ended up getting a framed tile to go for our walk back in NYC!

Fabulous historical museum of tiles. If there is one thing you need to know about Portugal, it is its history of the "azulejos". Beautiful setting in an old Convent. The museum takes one through the history of how tiles arrived in Portugal through how the locals starting using them in their own unique way, through Lisbon's glory days, to the more modern expressionists. Highly recommended!

CERAMIC HEAVEN. The National Tile Museum is quite a long way from other attractions, and not very convenient to public transport, although it is next door to the main train station.Once there the collection is incredible, extensive and it explains quite well the story of tiles. The building housing it is a lovely place, and grounds quite cool, and calm in the hot sun. There is also an excellent internal cafe.Worth making the effort to see

Not to be missed. This is a bit of a way out from other places of interest, but worth every moment. The tiles are something to behold but the chapel is the most stunning place I have ever seen. It is magnificent. Do not miss the experience. We also had a very delicious lunch in the restaurant. Delicious food at a reasonable price. All home made.

dont miss this!. An amazing display of tiles, beautifully curated and displayed. An easy taxi journey from the centre of Lisbon. Well worth the visit if only just to see the building itself and the Madre de Dios chapel, with its ornate baroque decoration and tiled walls. It also has a very nice cafe. If in term time get here early (opens at 10.00 hrs) to miss the school visits.
Fascinating!. Best museum of tiles I have ever seen. Loved watching staff work on tiles in the workshop area. Worth the taxi ride to get there.

Azulejos out the wahoo!. Lovely tour takes you through the history of the Azulejo and tells you about how even though they are not original to the Portuguese, the people of Portugal made them their own by using their own style of painting and decoration. Many fine examples of original works exist here, along with examples of more modern interpretation. Quite enjoyable.

Amazing collection. Collection spans the history of this art form. Outstanding building, exhibits and even the cafeteria for lunch worth the visit. Learned a lot and saw things never would see in one place anywhere else.

Beautiful museum, a must for Lisbon. Tiles from different centuries are exhibited, starting with the first Portuguese tiles produced after models from Holland in the 15th century, baroque tiles, and finishing with an selection of tiles produced in the 20th century, you get a clear impression about this wonderful decoration element. The museum is placed in a convent and the richly decorated church can be visited as well. The museum's restaurant shouldn't be missed; it is decorated with tiles representing all sorts of food.

Don't expect anything unexpected. Well, this is what its name says: A tile museum. And they have lots of tiles from multiple epoches. But, in the end, I personally found it very boring. So I would only advise this museum to people who really know that they like tiles.

Great museum, even netter cathedral!. This museum was simply great and definately one of the highlights of Lisbon! Azuleijos are a big part of Portuguese tradition and although you can see a couple when walking around the city, this museum will really show you what they were all about. Throughout the rooms you will get to see how this art evolved from a very Moorish style when it arrived in Portugal, to its becoming of a very important part in portuguese culture.My favorite part of the museum was, however, the cathedral within it (the museum used to house monks and nuns). It is simply breathtaking and completely unexpected. Although it is not at all big, I spent a good 40 mins inside just trying to take it all in. Absolutely beautiful, and my favorite memory of Portugal.*Note: Getting here was somewhat difficult for us as the museum isn't close to many other tourist attractions; also, for some reason nobody seemed to know about the museum when we asked for directions which made it even harder to get there. After a half hour of searching we went into another museum where they finally helped us hail a cab and told the driver where to take us. This museum needs more advertising!
Best museum we saw in Lisbon. Others were predictable municipal institutions, this was something specially Portuguese and in a brilliant setting for the subject
Amazing Museum!. If you love tiles like me, come here! You can see several types of tiles thru the years, even some Dutch! And the church inside is beautiful! Worth a visit for sure!

Impossible To Find, Hard to Forget. First of all, Lisbon public transportation does not provide any information to get here. Yet, I will try, take bus 794 from city center, starting at Terreiro Paço and get off at Igreja Madre Deus. There is no sign (A faded, almost invisible one, is not a sign). The bus stop is in front of the museum and the Igreja, which is part of the museum, I think.About the museum,If you want to learn how a tile is made, there is sufficient information.If you want to see century-old tile works, there are plenty.If you get bored by ancient broken tiles, there is modern art, made of tiles, of course.If you have not been convinced to make the trip while in Lisbon, that is because my words are as dull as clay. Surely after a visit, your writing can make mine a beautiful, colored, and blazed tile.

Can't miss if you love tiles. This place was an old nuns house and a church, so it's architecture is beautiful and the church decoration is an amazing representation of the barroco style. Also, you can learn the history of the tiles in portuguese culture, from the arabic invasion to these days. Don't miss the Lisbon panoram in tiles, on the end of the visit.
Better than expected. We went for free on the first sunday of the month. It's a bit out of the way from the main sights but it was very interesting to see the tile art change through the years.

loved it!. this is a completely adorable place, despite its location (pretty far). A huge collection of all kind of tiles, big and small, geometric and floral, etc.., with a few explications. It's worth to visit and spend there some hours :) ps in the attic the enormous tile panorama of old Lisboa (even before earthquake 1755) which is so interesting! don't miss it

A must see in Lisbon. Everywhere one goes in Portugal, the blue tile can be seen. The Museum offers so much of the history behind the use of tile and should definitely be on your list of places to see in Lisbon.

A must see!. Not only are the tiles from ancient times incredible to see,but the building itself is of historic import.A picture of life in Lisbon through the centuries is seen in the wall size tiles-truly amazing.

A Little Treasure. When we approached I thought we'd arrived at the wrong location but we were pleasantly surprised. The building is fantastic- an old convent. The chapel and choir loft are breathtaking. We loved the tile exhibits. Don't miss this attraction.

A most pleasant surprise. The museum shows the evolution of ceramics over the past 5 centuries. It is a museum within a museum. Unfortunately, there is little explanation on techniques and no plan of the museum is provided. The small cafe is worth a stop. It is very peaceful.

Don't miss this despite it being a bit out of the centre. This was our third museum due to it being an intermittently wet day and one which we visited late-ish in the afternoon. I'm so glad we did and would definitely recommend it. The museum building is amazing being a historically important artefact in itself as well as providing a light and airy space to wander in. I learnt a lot about this ancient art and marvelled at the excellence and precision with which tiles were made in the past using basic, traditional methods. The technicality of how to produce different types of tile design is explained, with examples of how those techniques are applied, arranged in a timeline of the history of tiles, their uses and the significance of their patterns, in Portugal. The exhibition rooms and passage through them give a clear idea of how important tiles were for religious and secular purposes. Uses ranged from decorative - demonstrating status, wealth, etc., to narrative, particularly Biblical stories in a religious context, then to some which are quite obviously subversive having a satirical message or conveying political propaganda. Moving on to the modern displays I was particularly impressed at how versatile 'tiles' - or the tile making technique - could be artistically. It could give a whole new appreciation, when travelling the city and seeing houses or even whole blocks of flats clad in tiles, of the work involved to achieve the look.

Beautiful and fun place to visit. The National Tile Museum was a beautiful place to visit. We were here as part of a Lisbon sightseeing tour. The breadth of the collection of tiles and the history of tiles in Lisbon presented here was amazing. We had an opplrtunity to make our own tile which was a fun and fascinating activity.

Fascinating view of Portuguese art and history. A little off the beaten path but well worth visiting. Be sure to visit the beautiful chapel. The tiles that tell personal and family histories were especially interesting.

Excellent presentation. Excellent explanations. Don't miss the top floor.. It is common knowledge that azulejos (tiles) are one of Portugal's "things not to miss".The 16 to 18th century period is my favourite but many artists continue producing contemporary tiles, some of these being remarkable. That's why, when you visit this museum, you should not disregard the temporary exhibitions. The one we saw last week was really good.The ground floor explanations through multi-lingual panels are brilliant and give you great insight to better understand the birth and evolution of this form of art.The museum being situated in a former palace, the visit is far from being linear. Take the time to explore around as you will for sure find rooms that are worth visiting.Don't miss the top floor 23 metre long pannel representing 14 km of Lisbon before the terrible 1755 earthquake and tsunami.

Surprisingly good!. The fiance is a tiler so thought it would be fun to go. With the Lisboa card we got in for free. This place took me by surprise, the building it's located in is phenomenal and is an art form in itself with a breathe taking church style room with amazing tile work. I learned a lot and would highly recommend it as it is such a big part of the Portuguese culture and history.

A don't miss. Absolutely beautiful--how else can you describe a sea of tiles, mostly blue? No tour needed--lovely shop--you can eat there too, though we didn't. Also loved the CCB (?) modern museum and ParisemLisboa for linens.

Beautiful with unexpected surprise. What a fantastic place. From the outside you don't pay a Pennie, get inside and will find richness and art in all their senses. You don't only get to see the fantastic work of Portuguese artisans, but also a Church that blows your mind (and eyes) with all the arrangements, paintings and exquisite details. I totally recommend a half to full day visit while in Lisbon.
Beautiful. Well worth the visit. To see the detail put into tiles, i.e., pottery and glaze, was an example of beautiful artistry.

Interesting and informative. A great way to learn about the history of tiles in Portugal. A little more info on the tradition of tiling the outside of houses would have been nice though. We caught the bus there and it was no problem.

One of a kind . One of a kind experience. The museum tells the story of tiles from the beginning till the final result, the way of production from dirt to finished tile and from the time they were first produced until today. A visit that every one that visits Lisbon must not miss!!!

Night on the tiles. This is hidden gem. Charting the history of Portuguese tiles sounds boring but this was anything but. Set in a former chapel and cloisters, the displays were amazing, as was the chapel itself. There was a modern display of marine clay art which was outstanding. Great way to spend an hour and the cafe is worth a visit, too.

THE HISTORY OF TILES IN PORTUGAL. A fantastic museum that no one talks about, but is a must see in Lisbon. Unbelievable the history of tiles in this country and the beautiful works of art done with them .

Excellent Museum for spending some hours on a wet day. This Museum is a small, but excellent Museum with examples of tiles through the ages. Portugal is known for its tiles and this Museum shows tiles going back centureis and up to the present day contemporary work. We were impressed with the display throughout an old Convent, which in itself is worth seeing. It is not an inexpensive Museum and we spent some hours here on a wet afternoon in Lisbon.

An absolute delight. Bit of a trek out but worth it. Arrived mid morning on a Sunday in time for a late breakfast. The cafe and its terrace is an oasis of tranquility - a great antidote to the grime and bustle of Lisbon. Fresh croissants and a tea limon and coffee provided the perfect start to the day. The museum is fascinating and a wonderful space to wander through. It would have been nice to have a kids trail or something similar but they became more engaged as we ventured through the rooms. Well recommended.

wonderful place. great to see the panorama of Lisbon before the earthquake; a thought -provoking installation of modern ceramic artwork by Sylvain Bongard ; wonderful details to discover throughout the museum.
excellent. Worth visiting for a new look on old tiles. Far away from center, difficult to find. Or take hoponhopof bus

The highlight is the chapel inside. Since this museum is called "Museu Nacional do Azulejo", I had expected of lot more INFORMATION on this subtle work of art that is so typical of Portugal. Indeed, there are some beautiful tile panels, but very little written content. I was blown away, though, by a chapel I didn't know existed inside that featured beautiful tile panels in addition to dozens of huge renaissance paintings. I wish I'd gotten some kind of museum guide to those incredible paintings, because there was also very little information about them there (only the names of the artists responsible, nothing else). Also, I thought some of the staff were a bit rude. The man responsible for selling the tickets complained TWICE about breaking my 100 euro bill - what was I to do? I had run out of change and had to break that bill somewhere. And a woman inside called my attention in a harsh way when I suddenly stepped on a wooden path instead of using the designated carpet.

Unique museum. I have never seen a tile museum, so this appealed to me because it was unique. The tiles were wonderful and the museum is in an old convent so there is a very elaborate church inside as well. I would definitely recommend it.
Over-rated. What I saw here, does not compared to what you can see in Sintra - in the National Palace and in Porto at the train station. I was disappointed.
worth the trip. the museum is in a beautiful old building. The exhibits are informative . There are some galleries devoted to modern tiles. the courtyard is a good spot to rest and have a drink.

Beautiful museum&collection.A learning experience.. Liked everything about the building which is an old monastery,and about the collection which is beautiful as well as a History Course in Portugese Culture.

YES Azulejo!. Liked everything.
Disliked: it was advertised as "free on Sundays", and they told us it was changed to "free on the 3rd Su of the months"...

Wow! Make sure you don't miss this museum. This was an amazing museum. They had beautiful tile that was both traditional and contemporary. Every neighborhood in Lisbon has a museum of some type. This is one you won't want to miss. It's a great place to spend an afternoon. The building is beautiful, they have a lovely place to eat and a wonderful gift shop. Don't forget your camera.

Delightful. Our hosts reminded us to go to the National Tile Museum which is housed in an old convent. We spent the whole afternoon browsing around the exhibits and meditating in the inspiring chapel. The exhibits have tiles from the past few hundred years all the way up to an exhibit of modern tile work by a contemporary artist. Can remember names but the website is sure to list info. The old convent is easy to reach by public transportation and costs only 5 Euros. Well worth it. Only sad thing is the courtyard garden which made me wish I had my clippers and gloves. So glad we took the time for this very special place.

worth a visit. This place is not in the same area as most of the tourist attractions but I really enjoyed it. You have to like looking a tile and if you do this is world class tile. Individually or combined into scenes that were like paintings, there were many lovely pieces. There is a big panorama tile piece of early Lisbon (not sure on the dates) that you should be sure to see. It was towards the end of the self guided tour up some stairs.
A must. Even though the azulejos collection is unique, the retablos of the church are worth the visit. The panoramic view of Lisbon before the 1755 earthquake is a masterpiece

Nice surprise. Do not overlook it.. We went to the museum with a so-so attitude and ended up very impressed. It is more than just "tiles" as you will see. What they have done with some of the exhibits is fantastic. The museum is both artistic and historical at the same time. There is too much to describe adequately. All we can say is that it is well worth the visit.

History of Tile. Just outside the city center and easily accessed by bus is an interesting museum on the history of tile. The museum building itself is interesting to see. You can see the restoration work going on as you walk around.

Never Seen So Much Tile. The Tile Museum was the whole point of my Sunday in Lisbon. And it was a welcome respite from the Sunday rain storm that had rolled in during the night. Thankfully first thing on a Sunday it wasn't too crowded. The tile display and the Monastery the museum resides in were just lovely. My only disappointment was that the famous panoramic tile display of the city of Lisbon was squeezed in this little room on the third floor and just wasn't well done at all.

Very special. Do not miss this excellent museum that displays a large collection of tiles from various periods in history, including a large panorama of Lisbon before the earthquake of 1755. The museum is housed in a former monastery and has a pretty Renaissance cloisters. It's a bit out of the way but well worth the effort to get there. Excellent gift shop.
Make your own tile at the workshop!. This is a nice museum--not large, but very "detailed" with all the historic tiles. Be sure to sign up for the workshop to make your own tile!

don't miss the 3rd floor. this out of the way museum is worth the effort. part of the building still functions as a church and I was lucky enough to visit on a Saturday afternoon while a wedding was being performed; the beautiful sanctuary is visible from behind a glass wall on second floor.tile making, tiles thru the ages; an exhibit of contemporary tile artists all spectacular and on the 3rd floor a room sized panorama of what Lisbon looked like before the 1755 earthquake and tsunami devastated this beautiful capitol city.
for tiles' lovers. If you are a tiles' lover like me, you will like this museum a lot. Don't miss the chapel, it's absolutely amazing! If you walk, it's about 15 minutes for the train station.

Interesting but expected a bit more. This was a good place to tour, but I thought it might be larger. I found the modern area was almost more spectacular than the older tile pieces on display which surprised me. The chapel inside the museum was very impressive however, and a complete surprise to us! So overall, well worth seeing and the admission price. Also, has a wonderful little garden cafe area where you can get a snack after touring the museum or just for a little rest.

Gorgeous museum. Best thing in Lisbon for me - nothing like it in the world. This museum tells you about the history and heritage of the hand decorated tiles that are so prominent in the buildings and architecture. The museum includes an old church where you can see the tiles in the main bit of it and all over the walls, It's an amazing - if you do any museum, make it this one.

Unexpected wee gem. Went here because it was a stop on the yellow bus tour and reviews had been good. Only 5 euros and a fascinating insight into the art of tiles! The chapel and chapter house are impressive and the more modern examples of tiling art are also interesting.

Beautiful. Lovely museum that doesn't take alot of time to enjoy. Garden snack area that is very inviting. The azulejo of Lisbon city (top floor) before the great earthquake that transformed the city (1755) was very interesting to see after having done a good part of Lisbon on foot during the 2 previous days.

Brilliant place and such a suprise. I wasn't expecting to enjoy the place as much as I did despite the great reviews. The museum is a little way out from the town centre so a bus or taxi is advised to get there. Once there the place is really well laid out, has good information nice people to answer your questions and the history is fascinating. There is also a section that displays modern tile and pottery which is excellent Part of the old church still remains which was absolutely stunning so take a camera for some wonderful photo's. The café serves great cakes and coffee, tea etc etc. and is well worth a visit.

AMAZING MUSEUM IN OLD CONVENT. the museum is well worth the entrance fee .In addition to the history of the tiles the chapel is stunning.We thought that the temporary exhibitions were world class and provided a rich contrast to the permanent show

Must see. A highlight of our time in Lisbon. The exhibit by Sylvain Bongard is phenomenal. Glad prices weren't on the pieces, but would have loved to by one. Luckily staff english wasn't good enough to help me purchase. Actually the cashier was rude when I snapped a picture of Bongards book, just to catalog the name, geez. Anyway, very good place to visit, not slammed with people.

Very nice exhibition . This is a very well done exhibition of Portuguese tiles housed in a former convent. In addition to the beautiful tile from around the world, there is a wonderful chapel and choir loft. We thoroughly enjoyed the 2 hours here. The cost was 5 euros. Very nice cafe. We took the 792 from Rossio but the 794 from the Commercial Square goes there also. The 792 returns by a slightly different route at night so read the schedule carefully.
Outstanding Museum. This is a truly beautiful place with gorgeous tiles everywhere and a sumptuous chapel. We spent hours here. No crowds.
Suprised Me. Went at the behest of my wife not expecting to be blown away by the beauty of the exhibits. Colors and intricacies of the works are amazing.
Brilliant. Once a convent, now a tile museum. It should be on everyone's itinerary.Amazing , the rooms, the pictures, the chapel, we loved it.

The tiles were marginal.... The surprise of the museum is that it's in a beautiful building, with very nice gardens. The main attraction there is, without a doubt, the church and the chapel. Of course the history of the tiles and the tiles themselves are also beautiful and interesting.

Tile Museum. This museum is a real delight for anyone interested in the beautiful tiles of Portugal. The building is as interesting as the tiles within. It has a terrific cafe for a snack after feasting your eyes on the beauty of the tiles of this country. It is easy to access by bus 759 but the bus leaving the museum is on another street. Ask at the desk where to catch the bus. The museum is about a 30 minute walk from the commercial square.

Fascinating, not to be missed!. We went here with some friends that were here for the day on a ship last week. Beautiful tiles, great history of the progression. The church and chapel alone are worth the price and the visit. I would plan at minimum two hours.

Best museum. A must see if visiting Portugal. Azulejo tiles are such an essential part of Portugal and this museum gives a great historic overview. The museum is not too large and can easily be visited in 1 hour and 30 minutes without rushing.

Nothing but Tile.
