I am usually a big museum goer but was traveling with a friend who is not so enthusiastic so chose this as my only museum visit during our 3 day visit to Lisbon, it was such a treat! Seeing the beautiful tiles throughout the city, I was intrigued to learn more. The museum display beautiful tiles whole giving the history of Portuguese tiles without being overbearing. It a relatively small museum that can be done in a couple of hours. It has a cute cafe to grab a drink, coffee, or bite. The gift shop has beautiful gifts perfect for souvenirs for family and friends back home.It's a bit out of the way though we walked from Bairro Alto. It's a nice walk, but taking the tram or bus may be a better idea unless you'd like a walking tour of the city ! My non museum going friend enjoyed it as well! Definitely worth the trek!
Very interesting. Great historic collection of tiles in an interesting setting--check out the relics in the upper choir chapel. It also has a rather nice cafe, so it's a good place for lunch.
tile heaven. wonderful place, beautiful tiles and ancient church, amazing collection, loved the shop and the area to eat is like a rainforest

Beautiful tiles but..... we took the 20 minute tour and there were some beautiful tiles but it was very, very hot and truthfully it was hotter inside than out. I would not do it again but the people who run it are very proud of it.

Beautiful tiles, interesting history. The Museu do Azulejos displays some remarkable tiles in a beautiful setting. A former convent converted into a museum, it exhibits the evolution of tiles and tile-making in Portugal. While the location is not walking-distance from the town center, the stunning tiles from the 12th century to contemporary work displayed in the museum are worth the taxi fare and €5 entrance fee. Closed on Mondays.

This Isn't Your Grandma's Kitchen Countertop. What a nice surprise this museum is. In an old convent just out of the city center and easy to get to by bus, this was a collection of Portugese old tiles and tile pictures as well as an outstanding exhibit by 2 ceramic artists of today (Ceramic Persian rugs folded or gathered up to look surprisingly real and a display of ceramic, "raku glazed" I think, underwater creatures and objects that really impressed us since we both scuba dive). In addition, the building itself is a gem and a "photo op" just waiting to happen (read other reviews). We nearly took this stop off our list of things to see, but so happy we went. A nice change of pace from cathedrals, art museums, and tapas restaurants.

Well worth the trek!. The museum was one of my favorite attractions in Lisbon. At only 5 euro for adult admission, it is really a bargain! We came here with a group of adult family members and a toddler. We are not tile fans per se, but we all greatly enjoyed our visit. The tiles are beautiful and elaborate; just allow your eyes to feast on the rich detail and colors. The church inside the museum is breathtaking. There were very few other visitors when we came on a Tuesday in August, so we got some great photos. Flash is not allowed inside the exhibits but the lighting was good, so our photos turned out well. We spent about 2 hours browsing and then had lunch in the museum restaurant/cafeteria, which we were also very pleased with The restaurant/cafeteria has indoor and outdoor seating, and serves a variety of entrees, beverages, and snacks at reasonable prices. The gift shop is on the smallish side, but I found some pretty jewel boxes (<$30 USD) to take home as souvenirs. I also saw some gorgeous platters which were reasonably priced but too large for me to transport home. We spent about 4 hours at the museum – time very well spent. The location of the museum is rather remote, but we took a taxi from the Baixa Chiado Museum and pre-arranged for a taxi pick-up from the museum. It is worth the trek.
Tiles Tiles and more. This place is under rated. Lots of old tiles making up pictures. More than I expected. Easy bus ride to get there and nice patio for snacks and drinks. Well worth the time.
worth it…and free first sunday morning in the month. the best bit for me is actually the building; cloisters and astounding chapel! Tiles also interesting enough!

for tile lovers. If you want to visit a museum that represents something unique and Portuguese to the core, then you have to come here. I'm not some tile fan, but this was interesting and beautiful. The museum is set in an old monastery and you have a nice relaxing garden to have a drink after your visit. It's a bit out of the reach, frankly, we got here by tuk-tuk (you have them all around the town, they make an interesting sightseeing ride, very bumpy and exciting ride), and went back to the center by bus, but got on the wrong bus, but luckily the driver helped us to find the right bus back.

It was unusual and worth it but only if you like these sort of things.. It was a bit harder to get to and we weren't sure how to get there with the bus but in the end it wasn't too hard to find. The place is nice with lots of different tiles from different areas. It is unusual and that is why we chose to go there. I am not sure I would go again but am glad I went the first time.

Wonderful Museum In a Convent. Not all of our little party wanted to visit the tile museum but we are all glad we visited. We found joy in both the tiles themselves and in the building itself. The building was an old convent and very well preserved chapel was incredible. In a number of ways it reminded us of the Sao Roque church only smaller. We loved the fact that it had a choir on the second floor that opened into the upper area of the chapel. It provided great views.As far as we could tell, the tile collection was fairly complete. We saw tiles from all the main eras of Portugal and that ranges from the Moors to modern day. If you want to understand Portugal a little better then it's worth it to visit. Portuguese people continue to use tiles in their building to this day. (look at the new Oriente area to see that.)We were glad we visited.
Nice but... NIce but nothing special. A bit out of hand to reach but nice collection of tiles. Cheap, specially if you have a student card, even international

Oasis of silece. It is situated outside the city center and the location it is not conveniant. It is very intersting if you want to learn more about "azulejos".The church inside the museum is beautiful decorated. And the entire place is like oasis of silece, because not many visitators come here.
Wonderful. A wonderful collection of tiles through the centuries. This museum isn't top of the list for most travellers, but reconsider your plans!

Lovely museum with historic and modern tiles. I had never been to a museum dedicated to tile before. Their collection is splendid in its variety, aesthetics and historical value. There is a magnificent piece with tiles on the top floor that showcases the city of Lisbon before the earthquake in the 18th century which is not to be missed; it gives you an idea of what the city looked like in those times prior to the destruction and reconstruction led by the Marques do Pombal.

Amazing Pleasant Surprise!. We were looking for something to do one morning before departing Lisbon. Our concierge recommended this museum. We jumped in a cab and thought the driver must be lost, however he took us right to the door. What an amazing place, with a history of tile throughout the ages. When we found out the museum was a former convent and there was a chapel in the museum, we were blown away. There was an unbelievable display of what current artists are doing with tile too.

Wonderful. Lost to see hear-allow at least two hours . Ask directions from Tourist Office as it a little off the beaten track but easy enough o access via bus (20 minutes from city centre) once you know where you are going.

An excellent surprise!. I had some time in the city and thought of visiting some actractions off the beaten track and I am very happy that I decided to visit the Tile Museum! It has an impressive collection of tiles and a lovely chapel inside, definitely worth the visit.Tips: if you go on the first Sunday of the month the visit is free (until 14.00, I think). Also, I think it might be useful to use those hop on-hop off buses if you are a turist and don't have a car.
amazing collection!. Overwhelming collection of tiles and murals! Took an entire morning to just walk through. Photos remind us what we saw.

A gem of a museum. Housed in a former convent, this is a very interesting museum which displays not only the history of Portuguese tile-making, but also an ornate chapel, the Madre de Deus, absolutely full of paintings and an original cloister from the16th century. Surprisingly engaging (my children, aged 10 and 7, were appreciative of many tile panels) there is perhaps not as much information offered in English for a deep understanding, but the artistry on display is enough to amaze. Of particular note is the tiled panorama of 18th century Lisbon, which shows the city before the devastating earthquake of 1755 that we had read about in our travel book. Fees were very reasonable, I paid 5 euro, but the kids were free. A nice day out was capped by a visit to the cafe/restaurant, which even out of some selections of food, held more tiles of kitchen scenes and opened onto a courtyard where we sat in a tranquil and lush garden.

One of the best museums.... One of the best museums in Portugal, and one that is more directly linked to the Portuguese soul, history and creativity: Azulejos (Tiles) are simply a part - an important one - of Portuguese cultural tradition and heritage.

Spectacular!. My wife is more of a tile fan than I, but we were walking around Lisbon and happened upon this place so we thought we'd give it a go.Excellent call!Set in a lovely building, the highlight was, without any doubt, the (sadly temporary) exhibition "submerged art" by Sylvain Bongard - not tiles, to be sure, but amazingly detailed, often scary, always interesting art that one might find in the sea - from fishes to heads, tin cans to a watch. Ending November 2nd 2014, if you've been thinking of going but haven't yet got around to it I'd say, without hesitation - now is the time!

Tile Museum great for tile enthusiasts. This museum had the story of Portuguese tiles both in words and in tiles. A highlight was the mural of the city painted on tiles that was created before Lisbon's big earthquake.

It's a unique museum for Lisbon. It is a unique museum that is likely only to be found in Lisbon or elsewhere in Portugal. The tile exhibition is very well done and interesting. The museum is located on the outskirts of town, but well worth a visit.

My favorite museum in Lisbon. I am an art lover and fell in love with Lisbon's tiles at first sight. I find it fascinating how some cultures paint on canvas etc. but in Portugal it is the hand-painted tiles which are free for everyone to see in Lisbon's neighborhoods. For 5 euro you can see this converted convent that is beautifully decorated with originals from hundreds of years before. There is a lovely cloister in the center where you can have a coffee or lunch if you get tired. If you are into art and history, this is a must see!
a very nice museum located in a wonderful palace. if u loves tiles, ceramics u will love this place.located in a wonderful palace with a very nice church too.
So many tiles. I didn't know a culture could be so in love with tiles. Especially murals made of blue tile. I associated blue tile with holland, but the portugese went wild for them.

azulejo heaven!. If you like tiles (azulejos) and ceramics, it's definitely worth a visit. Housed inside an old convent, it's a spectacular building which also has a very, very ornate church inside--- with tiled walls, of course! Would be good if they could explain more about the history of tiles and why they are so prevalent on and in buildings in Portugal, which was explained to me on a walking tour that I took. The gift shop could be much better. Easy to get to by local bus from near the ferry station close to Plaza de Comercio.

Who'd have thought it would be so interesting?. It's a Tile Museum - how interesting can it be?Very interesting is the answer! It's hard to find. From the town centre you need to take either the 728 or 759 bus from Praca Comercio (near the arch) - watch out for going up and over the bridge at Xabregas (not over a river) and the bus then turns left away from the Tagus. Press the Stop button as soon as it turns, get off and stay on the river side of the railway, walking back towards the city - the museum is the second building on the right.The history of the tiles is pretty impressive, the examples are stunning. There is also a room dedicated to a huge fresco of the skyline pre-earthquake, and when we were there also a temporary exhibition by an artist who works in glazed fired clay made in a similar way to the tiles.The only slight downside was that we went for a quick bite and drink in the cafeteria afterwards. It took almost an hour for a cheese toastie to arrive, despite there being 4 staff and only about 8 customers. Disorganised to the extreme! So go elsewhere for your culinary needs - but do get to the tile museum if you can, it's far more interesting than you might think!

Impressive display of Lisbon tiles. Spent 2 hours there immersed in tiles of the last 500+ years. Includes room dedicated to panorama of Lisbon before the 1755 earthquake. Can eat drink and snack in peaceful courtyard. Slightly hard to - accidentally got off the bus at the right stop, but even then walked up the wrong street. Might be best to get a taxi from the centre of Lisbon.
Loved it. A bit out of the way, but a must-see if you like tiles. Great museum shop. Turtles in the pond at the on-site cafe.
One of the best in Lisbon. Definitely worth to visit. The building itself (monastery) and exposition are both good. Place with relaxing atmosphere. A bit unconvinient to reach (bus, taxi or walking).

A city of tiles. With all of the beautiful tile facades dressing the buildings of Lisbon it seems only fitting that one spends a little time learning about the history of tiles in the area. I lovely museum - particularly for the set up, arrayed around a series of courtyards. A museum that you might want to spend an ambling hour.
Good but small.. Beautiful setting in a former convent. Very interesting tiles. Small so you only need and hour or two.

Nothing square about this museum!. A ceramic artist's dream! Felt like I was in tile heaven! Beautifully laid out and a perfect combination of past and present pieces. Portugal is known for its tile work, and this museum shows why. A bit out of the way, but well worth the visit.

A museum that has a lot to say!. The museum provides you with an audioguide that gives you very detailed infos of everything in the museum. It is a beautiful place and the Church's walls are amazing. It was an afternoon well spent

Let's travel back to the encient time!. I love history and I also love anything left from the past. I am glad Portugal has this museum to preserve all the beautiful Azulejo tile dated back more than a thousand years! You will learn a lot about tile history and about Portugal. This place is definitely worth a visit.

Very nice museum to see the history of azulejos. This is a very nice museum to see.You will see how the use of tiles as a docorative art has evolved.Lots of nice tile decor art from the history untill the modern time.There was also exhibit of ceramic art with occean theam. Very nice sea life made in ceramics.Also we visited the cafe. It was very good experience. Atmosphere was frendly and nice. Food and service was good too.All the family liked it. For smallest the tour was a long one.

Surprisingly fun. Ok so i thought my boyfriend was having a laugh when he suggested the tile museum but actually it was quite interesting, there are tiles everywhere in Lisbon so to learn about the history of tiles was actually cool.
Disabled accessible. Unique attraction, well laid-out with both ancient and modern examples of ceramic art. Lifts and ramps to make wheelchair access easy.
great museum, a little bit out of the way. This is a wonderful museum, located slightly out of the main city centre but easily accessible by bus. Lovely courtyard, well worth the visit.

Your eyes will hurt but in a good way. So many tiles! This place is a little bit out of the way but worth seeking out if you are remotely interested in Portugal's most distinctive art, the azulejo (tile). You can see the evolution from the Moorish style to what we have today. Honestly, your eyes start to feel a bit numb after a bit. Good thing the museum has an awesome courtyard where you can take a break.
Fascinating place. As a tile enthusiast this is a place I really enjoyed. The rest of my family did as well. Well worth a visit.

Hidden Wonder. OK - not hidden. Right on the #742 bus line but out of the tourist district. Well worth the visit especially if you marveled at the exterior & interior tile of Lisbon's buildings. Everything from the sacred to the profane is included within the broad collection to enhance one's appreciation of five centuries of Azulejo. Fee charged but free to Lisboa card holders.

Go for the tile, stay for the food. Had a great tour of the museum. Fascinating variety of tiles.But let me tell you about lunch! The museum cafe is a treasure. Neat as a pin and with a cool and inviting covered courtyard. Our wait-person was Ricardo. Ricardo spoke excellent english and had great dining suggestions. We were welcomed. The salmon salad was perfect.Go for the tile, stay for the food!Take a taxi. The bus is not that much fun.

Easy to get to from cruise ship port. There is a public bus that goes along the main road outside the new cruise ship port that takes you on a short ride to within 3 blocks of the museum. The museum is housed in a 16th century convent, which is beautiful in itself with gorgeous tile covered walls. This is a fascinating stop that will only take you about 3 hours including transportation. One of my favorites.

Fabulous museum. this was one of my favorite museums in Portugal and I recommend it wholeheartedly. The collection is beautiful, extensive and very well documented and translated for the anglophone visitor. The opulent and gilded Madre de Deus Convent which houses the collection is worth seeing on its own. There is a large Lisbon cityscape completed in 1738, before the earthquake, which provides a record of the city at that time. The museum is just slightly out of the way but definitely worth the small detour.

Take the bus to get here; not thrilling, but interesting. If you want to learn about the history of tile-making in Portugal, this is the place to see it. A very nice, well organized museum that does what it is set out to do: show off tile work. Definitely not a thriller, but it offers quality pieces and information that helped me appreciate all the tiles I saw around Lisbon and Sintra. An enjoyable place, especially if it is rainy!

Very interesting,. While this place is a bit hard to get to (20 minute walk from the metro) it was worth the trip. I learned so much about the history of tile making. The audio tour was free and very informative. If you're a technophile, you'll find the audio tour gadget interesting. It's a small cylinder that you laser point at the different display numbers and it automatically starts on the right lecture.The displays were beautiful. There is also one of the most beautiful churches I've ever been in.Lastly, stop by the cafe. There's eating space outside in a tranquil courtyard.

Not much more exciting than it sounds. Tiles are a big deal in Portugal; you see them in all sorts of places that wouldn't make sense elsewhere -- in churches, covering whole sides of houses, ... -- but in Lisbon it's just the done thing. Hence the tile museum, and undoubtedly browsing here is definitely to connect with something more genuinely Portuguese than the oceanarium.But, existing excellent reviews aside, it is just tiles. If you're not into tiles, chances are that you won't be blown away. I found several of the 20th century works most appealing, and was amused / bemused by some of the stranger and larger earlier frescos -- why would you go to the effort of making such a thing with tiles?! But after half an hour I was dawdling to pass the time, and overall didn't stay more than an hour. Unfortunately the explanations of the history and technique (at least the English ones) are limited to the first room and then you're on your own for tile after tile after tile.The building is the real star: the old convent has lovely stone collonades and cloisters, and the church and upstairs chapel and choir are quite remarkably ornate (and tiled, of course). Worth going for that alone, I think: if you want to visit one Lisbon church before going to the oceanarium, this is a pretty cool one... and you get to see some quite silly satirical tile frescos, too.
Nice tiles and more. It was nice museum with a very nice tile collection. You can easily access it from the city center. Inside there is a very nice church and quite unexpensive cafe. Recommended.

amazing azuleijos. It is a very pleasant museum to experience in terms of layout and the collection is stunning, hard to single any one thing out. The chapel is truly spectacular. The little museum restaurant has the best shrimp croquetas in the world.

Nice tiles. This is an interesting display of azulejos. However, I'm probably not knowledgeable enough in this field to fully appreciate the beauty of the tiles. For me, the highlight of this museum was the gorgeous chapel. Entry is not that expensive (free with the Lisboa card) and it doesn't take that long to visit. If you're not spending a lot of time in Lisbon, this is probably a place you can skip. But if you're looking for something to do in a longer stay, it's a nice way to spend an hour or two.

beautiful art. The tiles are amazing. It helps you to appreciate this art form that can be found of course, on buildings and churches. But it was good to see it in historical perspective and to learn more about it.The only down side is that the gift shop does not mail tiles home!

Tile-icious. We were pretty skeptical about this place, but we went for the laugh and were pleasantly surprised. ?5 entry (?2.50 for students), a bus ride from the centre. Walking not advised in the heat!It was fairly interesting, showing a side of Portuguese art and culture we hadn't appreciated before. There are some beautiful pieces, both medieval and modern. A well-thought-out museum with a lot of variety and that ends before it gets boring.Highlights were the Lisbon panorama showing the city as it was before the 1755 earthquake, and the turtles in the garden area. Not a must-see, but a good way to spend a morning.

Awesome museum!. This is a really neat and unique museum with a beautiful and extensive collection of tilework. The first-floor cloister is particularly impressive. Note that you can walk there from the metro, but it's about a 20-minute hike and takes you up a pedestrian path on a highway bridge, so not for the faint of heart. On the way back, buses run regularly to Terreiro do Paço.

Must see in Lisboa. The name tile museum doesnt do this place justice. It is really a museum that provides a glimpse into the art and culture of Lisboa. Well presented displays in an amazing setting, it held the attention of my wife and me as well as our 8 and 4 year olds for more than an hour and a half. Plus, it has an excellent little cafe with outdoor, shaded seating.
Interesting in a part of the Portugese design.. This museum gives you an insight of the famous Portugese tiles that decorate their buildings, for instance.

A great introduction to Portuguese tile. We toured this museum on our 1st day in Lisbon. It was easy to reach by public bus. Despite the holiday weekend, the building was fairly empty and we were free to wander and enjoy the exhibits. The tiles were just gorgeous with outstanding colors. It was a great way to start our travels here; we went on to visit many churches and learned a lot about what we saw from our tour here.

Miles of tiles. They are open Tuesday to Sunday. We went on the first Sunday of the month and even then it wasn't too busy. It took us about 90 minutes to get round the museum, once we had found it! It isn't really signposted at all, so do take a map with you or find directions out from the hotel concierge before you go, or ask the bus driver where to get off the bus. The website is http://www.museudoazulejo.pt/The Chapel is a must-see and the exhibitions of tiles extremely interesting. It's worth the trip a little out of the centre to see (we took the 759 bus from Restauradores and it took about 20 minutes to get there). There's a nice little restaurant and courtyard where you can enjoy a spot of lunch or refreshing drink after all that tile gazing. The shop contains some interesting books but not much else, so don't expect to find many post cards of what you see - take lots of pics yourself instead!

On the tiles. Well worth a visit, especially if you have time afterwards to snack in the delightful courtyard cafe. In a rather rundown area and with striking but easily missed exterior, this monastery museum can be reached by public transport - it you do, make sure you get off at the right spot. Interior contains all and more you want about tiles plus beautiful chapel. Don't miss the panorama of Lisbon at the top!
Beautiful. What a tribute to craftsmanship and artistry. The tiles are breathtaking and the chapel is not to be missed.

A Lisbon MUST!!!. You haven’t been to Lisbon or Portugal until you’ve been to this museum. The museum is in a magnificent 16th Century convent (very convenient 15 minute 1.5 Euro bus ride from Cascais Sodre), a Manueline cloister with web like vaulting and a gold smothered baroque chapel. It is a MUST. It possesses the entire spectrum of tiles from the early Ottomans. Add to that a sublime vine-clad courtyard restaurant and fountain with a good lunch menu.
Tile, glorious tile. Decorative arts overload at this wonderful, colorful museum. A must see in Lisbon if you have even a passing interest in tile. Lovely restaurant and courtyard for a drink.

A delightful visit. I was thinking this might be a ho hum place to visit, but no. The varieties and all ages of tiles were really fascinating. I was very pleased with the displays, techniques, and colours. Come in the morning and take a seat in the garden restaurant to finish off your visit.
Amazing. The Tile museum is in an old monastery, with the most amazing church, the variety of tiles is amazing for anyone with an interest in art or design this is a must visit.

Amazing. The building is so wonderful the collection is almost a secondary treat. But make no mistake, the collection is spectacular - from ancient to contemporary art. Not to be missed and not too busy, either. We loved it!

we think is a must to see museum. there is no other museum of this sort to be seen anywhere and the tiles showed are unique art works very interesting - not to forget to check the coffee shop that has nice tiles works.The museum is a closter that the walls are very rich of art works in tiles.

Beautiful, unusual museum. Housed in a former convent, this is a remarkable and unusual museum as others have noted. Worth taking the bus to a less-traveled part of town to see the varied tiles (ancient to modern) and enjoy the building itself, which is much fancier than I expected. The cafe was also one of the better museum cafes I've eaten at. A recommended stop in Lisbon for sure.
Beautiful history. Wonderful visit to the history of Portugese tile. Marvelous old building. A little out of the way but worth the trip. Good stop for on and off sight seeing bus.

Off the beaten path. The museum is away from the main part of town, but well worth the trek. We enjoyed reading about the history of the tiles and the fact that it was not crowded. We were able to take our time and look at everything at a relaxed pace. There are some stunning displays. The area next to the cafeteria is a nice place to sit and relax after the visit. Friendly staff
great specialised museum. This is a specialty-type museum, so if you enjoy azulejo art, please go there and have very good time viewing the many interesting exhibits.

Gorgeous azulejos in a stunning setting.. A visit to this beautiful collection of azulejos is a must if you love the decorative tiles of Portugal. There are both ancient and modern tiles on display, huge friezes and small pieces. The setting is absolutely magnificent, with large white gallery spaces in between the most ornate chapels I've ever seen. The peaceful shady courtyard is a wonderful place to relax in and enjoy.

Awesome....not to be missed!!. Have always loved Azulejos and thus a museu d'azulejos kept me spell-bound for may be a goos three hours with a collection of pictures.The best part was the audio system in English so I could do all at my own pace.....it is a live history,treasure trove of a collection...all in one.The origin and evolution of Azulejos....The Cloistered convent is so very beautiful....would have loved to walk that aisle as a bride!!With the audio system in English...it was so informative with the flexibility to switch off if it got too much.Every piece outbeats the other.....good to see a mural of Lisbon pre-earthquake.After the long meandering....the cafe is very welcoming and we had a great lunch there...excellent veg soup and a bacalhau preparation wiith spinach! Great way to spend the day with family, kids, friends. Keep up the good work!!

Lovely, colourful display in an impressive setting. After having seen different churches with beautifully coloured tile decorated walls, we decided to visit the National Tile Museum as well. Off the beaten path, but easily accessible by bus (794 from Terreiro do Paço or 742 from near Saldanha), set in a beautiful old convent, it turned out to be a charming little museum. The entry fee is very modest (5 EUR). The collection is quite small, we finished the visit in one hour. The old convent is quite beautiful, you can walk through the cloister, closed with windows, through which you can easily see piles of tiles being classified and curated, I imagine. During the tour you also get to see one or two chapels and a view of the church from the top, all beautiful.  There are different sections classifying the tiles, motives and patterns by historical periods, from islamic and gothic tiles to 17-18th centuries and then contemporary period. Most tiles come from palaces and churches/convents. They have beautiful big panels and virtually paintings on tiles, from the simple ones with blue on white faience to the more coloured ones, representing religious scenes, floral or textile motives, maritime, courtly or hunting scenes, sometimes covering entire walls. Don't miss the great panoramic view of Lisbon before the great earthquake of 1755. In blue and white, straddling over an entire room, it depicts the countless number of palaces, churches and convents, with little explanatory notes on their subsequent fate and current status that made Lisbon centuries ago. It is worth a visit if you're into ceramics, although I think it could improve the story behind the painted tile as fundamental element of the portuguese identity, it could offer more information and there is room for improvement in the small museum shop.
A special place. The setting was very special. The exhibit was beautiful. The tiles were very diverse. I was a nice place to have lunch.

Unmissable. The importance of the tile in Portuguese architecture is given its full context and explanation in this delightful and well laid-out museum. Off the beaten track, but easy enough to get to by bus, and worth the effort: where else can you see tiled altar frontals covered with elephants? The church and cloister are also quite remarkable.

A ceramic treasure trove. An amazing collection!!!!A must for ceramic lovers and even if you're not it is a great historic record.I especially appreciated the pots and tiles on temporary display dating from the 17 th century .We got there using the MET and a local bus but it is also on one of the yellow bus routes.It has a shop and a really nice cafe.
Afternoon at the tile museum. History of ceramic tiles in PT from Moors to present day. Beautiful artistry. Well worth a side trip.

Old tile museum. Took a taxi to the museum from our hotel, the Tivoli Lisboa. Neat old part of Lisbon. The museum is in an old religious retreat I think. Not particularly impressive. The contents however were grand. There are two floors of tile samples to see, from 500 years ago to relatively modern. You can watch the curators catalog and clean tiles saved from old buildings. Typical museum material. I think my wife liked it more than I did. Pretty inexpensive to visit. If you like seeing the old tiles on Portuguese buildings, go to the museum.

Only museum of it's kind.. While visiting various locations in Lisbon we could see tiles every where.Tiles on the buildings, tiles on road side pavement etc etc as if Lisbon is a city of Tiles. Finally when we visited this exclusive Tile museum we realized we have never seen anything like this before. An extra ordinary collection of Tiles. And the guide also told us about how they are made and their history. A must see in Lisbon

may well be my fav museum ever. This museum is way, way, way over the top!!!! An exquisite collection of Portuguese tiles displayed in a an equally as exquisite historic convent. Nicely laid out as to awe without overwhelm. and extremely well lit to really highlight the pieces. A great book/gift shop with strikingly different options. Definitely a must!!!

Worth seeking out. While not on the beaten path, this collection of tiles is worth finding. A fascinating explanation of how the various kinds of tiles are made, and a wealth of tiles to look at. In addition, a fabulous, opulent church is also a great visit.

one of the few must spots in lisbon. for those who appreciate art and tradition, and have a sense for beauty, it is a must visit, it gathers the beauty of tile painting from all over portugal, from ancient to modern. we really enjoyed it

Should not be missed. It has the most wonderful collection of tiles which has been expertly curated to provide a fantastic collection. Tiles are synonymous with Portugal and this is well worth a visit

Exceded Expectations. This museum is away from most of the old city center attractions but well worth a bus ride to get to it. It has tiles from before the 1755 earth quake as well as modern designs. The real surprise is the chapel. Do not miss it.

Fantastic! Pleasant surprise!. This attraction is included in Lisbon Card, I expected to see only the traditional Portuguese tiles inside this museum, but during the visit you will discover also a beautiful church, before part of a centenary convent, completlly adorned with colonial Brazilian wood, gold and frescos.Really amazing!

A good wet weather alternative.. The most impressive part of this is the opulent church with tiles walls and decorated in gold. Some interesting modern tiles too. The walk to it is through a relatively poor part of town but not threatening in any way.
Must see. This is a terrific museum. Well worth the visit. Don't miss it. The tiles are excellent. Great chapel too.

Wow!. We were debating whether to visit this museum or not, not being museum people and are glad we did.What was stunning was not so much the tile pictures but the church 'Igreja de Madre Deus', which is accessible from within the museum. It's incredible. The collection of tiles were also nice although you got an overdose of it here. I particularly liked the tiled staircase from the 1st to third floor (best way to find it is from the third floor, past the panoramic tiled view of Lisbon) and the cafe with the tiled bar area.

World of secrets. The experience starts with finding the museum; somewhat away from the city center. A neighborhood with little tourist interest. In fact it is good because when something beautiful is next to something uninteresting, the first looks more beautiful. Inside the visit allow us to go through the tiles history - we learn to like even more this decorative art. Unmissable two parts of the former convent, the church and the coffee house. The first is a true baroque Portuguese example; the second is the old kitchen of the convent and opens doors to a very nice interior garden.

Very enjoyable. This Museum was recommended to us by a local person and We really enjoyed our visit, The church alone is worth the visit as its so beautiful. The craftmanship that went into making all the Azulejo (tiles) is amazing, We enjoyed a lovely lunch in the courtyard cafe and it was a wonderful oasis of calm for a few hours.

One of a kind?. One of the unusual museums on Lisbon. Many aspects of tiles, but for me the greatest surprise was the location of the museum within a church/monastery and the incredible still existing decorations there. Note that the museum can be hard to spot from some angles as the elevated railway line is just in front.

A Special Place. For tile painters and artists a really special place or for anyone interested in the wonderful Portuguese style of tile painting...esp. the portraiture so common in Portugal. Be SURE to see the historical panoramic view of Lisbon before the quake upstairs...simply amazing. Fro em it was the best of Lisbon since I paint tiles myself.
Who knew. Who knew you could do an entire museum on tile and it was worth the visit. Unique. Very interesting. And I enjoyed seeing the influence on the lie art from Asia and Holland.

More interesting than I imagined. Costs 5 euros to get in. The museum is quite extensive and I believe it is worth it. I now want to make and paint tiles and stick them all over my house. The bus 759 stops right outside. The small courtyard in the centre of the museum has a pretty fountain and roses.

An eye opener. I never knew tiles could be this interesting. The museum tells you about the origins of the tile in Islamic art, as well as its role in the identity of Portuguese culture. Plus the tiles are varied and very pretty. Not so easy to find, you have to get the 795 bus from Praça Figueira to the crane/arch intersection. It costs €5.
Unmissable. Tiles from all eras & themes. Restaurant in courtyard was very reasonable for Lisbon, service was good and food excellent. Terapins heap in pond was also good sideshow

A small and beautiful delight!. Since Portugal has such a history of beautiful tile works, which you see all over the city, this is a nice place to go learn about the different types of tiles. You can also find some antique tile stores in the center of Lisbon...we bought an old one for 150 euros and we have it on display at home.
Very Nice. This place is little out of town but worh the visit... Take the bus 794... I took it from Santa Apolónia after visitng National Pantheon... and bus stop is right next to the tile museum...

If you are interested in tiles this is for you. Many places to visit in Lisbon, but tiles are an important part of history and culture of the city, and this is a must if you want to go beneath the surface

Tile, tiles and more tiles (and a wonderful chapel). This gem is a good walk from the nearest Metro station but well worth it. Every kind of tile you can imagine plus an OTT chapel with a wonderful atmosphere. Take time to have a coffee in the courtyard cafe before you start the long walk back.

Well worth the trip off the beaten path - a hidden gem!. Full disclosure: it can be tricky to get to. We took the local bus but got off at the wrong stop and were stranded in suburbia until a few nice locals took pity on us and told us walking directions in broken English. Lovely spot in an old convent which means courtyards, an out of this world chapel, and tons of wall space to display gorgeous tiles! I recommend eating lunch at one of the tables in the courtyard filled with lush plants, flowers, and a fountain.
Beautiful tiles!. If you love tiles, you will love this museum! The chapel is beautiful with its tiled walls! Tiles are everywhere!

This museum is a bit out of the way but worth it.. We walked here from the Santa Apolonia metro station and it was a bit of a haul. Better to take a bus which drops you at the door. The tiles in this museum are simply out of this world. On the third floor are azulejos that reflect what Lisbon looked like before the 1755 earthquake. We really loved this museum and although a bit out of the way, it's very interesting to see how azulejos are made and the many different shapes and designs of these little pieces of art.

awesome. This place is fabulous! Unbelievable tiles. Interesting cafe to have a snack or lunch and fun to watch the ladies working on old tiles. The original monestary is the perfect place to see these wonderful tiles.

A must see museum in Lisbon. A bit difficult to get to but there are at least 3 buses that you can take from Alfama/Bica area to get here. People who are older than 65 get a very good discount. The museum is in an ancient palace, beautiful building and the history of tiles in Portugal is displayed very well.

Museum/Gallery. This museum was a lovely thing to do on a hot Lisbon afternoon. It was very manageable in size and had a lovely courtyard cafe with reasonably cheap food. The artwork on the tiles was beautiful, really this museum is an art gallery as well! The only negative was that there wasnt as much information on the tiles as I would have liked.

Many, many tiles. Due to our long-winded guide, my group of 27 spent 3 hours in this museum when 1 hour would have been sufficient. When most of us got bored, there were wooden, large tile images into which one could stick one's face thru openings so we amused ourselves by taking photos of each other. Our favorite tiles were the 20th century tiles at the end of our tour. Nice museum and important to your understanding of Portugal but you only need an hour here, plus bathroom and shopping time.

Hidden gem. A great place to look at beautiful tile and art. Several cutouts where you can go behind, insert your face, and have a picture taken so you look like an old timey portuguese person. Kind of fun. Can't say I learned much about the history of portugal here though. Wonderful peaceful cafe. Great place for lunch. Can get there by bus fairly easily.

Beautiful building and collection. We loved this museum - it's in a beautiful building, and the collection is stunning. There's a lovely cafe and courtyard and a nice museum shop too. Highly recommended.We walked here from our hotel in Chiado, but it was definitely a hike. (A good hike, but a hike!)

A Lovely surprise. I wasn't expecting to enjoy a visit to a tile museum - I mean how interesting are tiles? But it was a wonderful surprise. The space is beautiful as are the exhibits, there is a great canteen and garden and a delightful, very ornate chapel. Definitely worth a visit. we

History in images. Portugal is rightly famous for ceramic tiles. Art, handicraft and history unite in the museum's display, especially the long mural recording Lisbon's earthquake, fire and tidal wave. On the downside, the museum presentation is uninspired, dated, not usefully informative. Access not that easy. For history/applied art enthusiasts.

Worth the detour. This is the place to see outstanding examples of the art of azulejos. The museum is in a former convent which features a chapel with splendid tilework. There is also a spectacular tiled courtyard, part of the original architecture. Other rooms have been outfitted with nice displays, ranging from early Islamic designs to 20th century examples. I was there on the first Sunday of the month, and there was no admission charge.The museum is not within walking distance of any other attractions. There is a bus line that passes within a block of the museum. Be sure to tell the driver that you want to go to the tile museum (museo azulejos), and he will let you know where to alight. There is very little signage to point the way. From the bus stop, cross the road, go under the railroad trestle, and stay to the left. The entrance to the museum is down around a curve, near a crosswalk. To get a bus back to town, you need to walk back out to the main road that runs along the waterfront (only a couple of blocks from the museum). There is a big Lidl supermarket on the corner. You will see a bus shelter on the main road. I found that Google directions give precise, helpful instructions. Just click on the icon for public transit and it tells you bus number, number of stops, and the name of the bus stop for your destination. Bus stop names are on the shelter and/or signs adjacent to the bus stop.

A Real Gem!. This is a one-of-a-kind museum housed in a breathtaking 15th century convent. Tile "pictures" have been collected from all over Portugal, some from convents when they closed. The vibrancy of their colors is startling after so many centuries of wear. The museum takes tile to a level where the artistry is emphasized, prominent and celebrated. This is a very special art form indigenous to a few countries including Portugal. The combination of the azulejos, the ancient building and the courtyard garden and cafe makes for a lovely visit. This is a real gem not to be missed by anyone interested in art and architecture.

Worth a trip. This museum is a little off the beaten track, but worth the effort to get there--bus stop is close by.It's worthwhile even if you just visit the chapel here. I also found the information on tile making at the beginning of the exhibit very useful, but I lingered too long which meant that I didn't have as much time as I might have liked to see the rest of the museum.
Great museum. This is a charming museum detailing the history of azulejos in Portugal. We loved it. Easy bus ride from Chiado.
An unexpected gem. An excellent museum, we had plenty of time to wander around and absorb the beauty and the history of the azulejos. This was a real treat.

amazing tile collection. It was nice visiting this place you get to see the different styles and designs made on tile from 100's of years ago to modern day.I do not recommend this place for children and it may bore them to death!

A hidden gem. This place is amazing and a great history lesson but a seemingly secret in the cultural scenario. Its installed in an old convent and tell the story of the tiles and its relevance in portuguese culture a must see

Outstanding and important Azulejos museum. This great museum of tiles is found in an ex monastery building. The collection and the explanation is most important to understand the existence of these tiles-Azulejos in Portugal all over.One can say " A Portuguese is born in a hospital full of Azulejos, prays in churchs decorated with Azulejos, takes the metro in stations surrounded with Azulejos on the walls, listens to music in Fado restaurants among Azulejos and is buried in a cemetery with walls and gates made of Azulejos".
Fab. Loved it and bought some beautiful tile for my kitchen! Definitely worth your while! Take the tram and enjoy!

Not as good as I thought. Was expecting to see a full range of tiles - from traditional to colourful different textured ones. Was disappointed - the building was nice but exhibitions a bit clinical.Tile museum in Ironbridge in the UK much better

Magical. Fascinating place in a great location at the convent. If you want a museum that reflects the history of the city, this is a good one to visit. Easy to get to by local bus and reasonably priced entrance.

For those who appreciate tiles. It is out of the way, there's nothing really in the surroundings which seems sketchy too, but it is worth the visit IF you're into art, tiles, etc. Otherwise skip it because you'll find it boring. It is, however, a very interesting collection. Don't miss the huge tile panel of Lisboa before the earthquake: it is overwhelmingly beautiful!!! The only down part is that for the fee they charge, it seems as if the venue should be in better conditions. It is worn off, showing lack of conservation, and the smell of mold is a bit too much in some of the rooms. Other than that, it is worth adding to the list.

Excellent museum in a lovely historical building. The Museu Nacional do Azulejo (National Tile Museum) as well as being an interesting museum in it's own right is housed in "the ancient Convent of Madre de Deus (Mother of God), founded in 1509 by Queen D. Leonor (1458-1525)". The museum is a bit out of the way. However we caught the 794 bus from Santa Apolónia and it stops outside the museum. My recommendation is to tell the driver when boarding. Our driver was extremely helpful both on the way there and coincidently on the way back.The museum is free on Sunday till 14:00 and also with the Lisboa card.After spending about 1.5 hours in the museum we had a drink and baguette at the museum's very pleasant and reasonably priced cafeteria.

Slightly out of the way, but overwhelming. Got here sort of by coincidence as we visited the Oceanario first. On our way back to the center we made a stop at this Museu Nacional do Azulejo. We were flabbergasted, this is the most impressive museum that we visited in Lisbon. Especially the beautifully decorated church/chapel, which is of a splendour which we did not see elsewhere. And as far as the location (slightly out of the center) concerns: taxis are cheap and will get you there in a few minutes for under 8 euros. There's no excuse for not visiting!

Interesting but not convenient. Lovely rooms with an extensive collection of Portuguese tiles. We took a bus there from the center near Rossio, but took a taxi back because we couldn't work out how to take public transportation--which had otherwise worked very well for us.

Interesting historic building & museum. This is not walking distance from the boulevard. We took cabs to and from, which are very inexpensive. Ancient tiles very interesting. The building was a convent at some point. Nice cafe to take a break afterwards.

Free on Sundays before 14:00. We did the whole museum in about an hour - but we aren't really museum-y people. It was winter when we went and we had basically the whole place to ourselves. The tile displays are incredible, especially the church on the first floor. Definitely worth a visit! We snagged a taxi from Santa Apolonia (train station) and it was only 4.50.

Don't go on the weekend!. If you are interested in the restoration of the amazing tile work in Lisbon, the restorers only work Monday thru Friday. While the museum itself is amazing, a major disappointment was not being able to see them at work.

Best of Lisbon. I went on a Sunday before, I think 2pm, and it was free. Even when it isn't free, it is inexpensive. This far far exceeded my expectations. I was dragged by my husband but now I want to visit ever Sunday. I will be going back soon! Make the trip, it is a beautiful building, church, museum, cafe... can't be beat.

Loved it!. I found the museum to be beautiful in so many ways! The former convent and church were worth the tour alone. The church is gorgeous, and as we understood from the docent, still used for weddings. I can see why. The tiles dating back to the 1600s were incredible. My husband and I wandered around admiring everything from the floors to the ceilings. If you enjoy art, and especially if you enjoy the tiles of Portugal...do not miss this. There is a "senior" admission discount, but you have to ask for it.
Wow!. A must for anyone visiting Lisbon... Not only a wonderful collection of tiles and pottery but a very beautiful building to enjoy.

Just one of a kind. First of all it is one of my favorite museum ever. Second of all you can only see it here. To understand the morish influence in Portugal this is the place. The building itself is a ex convent and of stunning cultural value. The museum explain why Lisbon and Portuguese house have tiles outside. Just go. On Sunday morning before 2pm is free.

Free Sunday admission?. We were pleasantly surprised to arrive and be admitted to the museum for free, though I'm not at all sure if this is a regular thing. I love tile, so I really enjoyed the museum. My husband was not all that excited to go, but he enjoyed it in the end. Some of the rooms are really surprising and sumptuous - like the complete church! Lots of amazing tile and good information on the various glazing techniques. We got there on the purple line of the Yellow Bus.

Tile Lover. While I am an aficionado of ceramics I found it overwhelming and repetitive. I would have loved to have a docent to learn more about what I was seeing - a mistake on my part by not joining the group I traveled with. The Chapel was way over the top. It was an experience in Portuguese history and expansion into the East

Ceramics Rule!. Portugal is world famous for its ceramic tiles and this museum aims to record this important part of Portuguese history. Set in a former convent the visitor is guided through some amazing rooms, and courtyards displaying some of the country's finest tiles. A good place to visit when on the way to the Aquarium.

Loved it!!!!. I'm so glad I made the effort to go to this museum, an absolutely beautiful and unique collection and not something you'll see in other places. I walked there but took a taxi back to my hotel near Rossio Square because of heavy rains and it was only 5£.

National Tile Museum. I definitely recommend this museum. It is well worth the admission price.The tiles are beautiful. The history of the tiles is interesting. Imaging all the work and time that went into decorating so many of Portugal's architecture with these small hand painted tiles - wow!There is a church inside the museum (included in the admission price).The church is beautiful. Be sure to walk upfront and look at the floor and the base tiles along the wall. The museum is accessible by bus, taxi or walking. There is a cafe near the museum entrance. A nice spot to grab coffee and a pastry and talk about what you saw in the museum.

Delightful and well-laid out museum. The National Tile Museum is a great way to spend at least half a day- The tile exhibits are gorgeous and give the viewer a sense of the history of Lisbon as well as the history of decorative tiles as they are used architecturally in this area- The convent building in which the exhibitions are housed is also fascinating on its own-

Interesting. Tile facades are special part of Lisbon and after this visit we could pay more attention to styles and techniques. Very well organized exhibition showing how the Moor tradition and later the Dutch tradition were implemented in the Portugal way, and how the techniques "work". Missed a section of modernn everyday tiles, now we saw artist's unique work from 20th century but a hint to modern kitchens and bathrooms would be cool. After this visit you look at Lisbon metro stations with different eyes.Bus 794 stop downtown was a bit hard to find, use online maps.

Worth the price. Interesting museum chronicling the history of Portugal signature styles through ages. Chapel with tiles is breathtaking. New takes on ancient art form interesting. Lovely cafe spot with nice choices. Recommend.

Interesting Museum set in an old Convent. Very interesting museum with a history of tiles which are really works of art. Set in an old convent I found the church fascinating with fabulous works of art on the walls and ceiling. Also interesting is the Panoramic of Lisbon on the top floor which shows Lisbon as it was prior to the Earthquake. Well worth the visit but would have liked better information on what we were looking at.
azulejo...azulejos. azulejos all around. how beautiful to see what was done in the past with tiles to decorate the walls.

AMAZING MUSEUM. one of my favorite experience in lisbon was the visit to the tile museum. there is so much see which is just so inspiring. the ticket cost 5 euro and i think it's really worth the visit. the cafe is so nice too where you can enjoy cup of coffee or lunch! Its collection is the only of its kind in the world, and contains a splendid array of tiles from as early as the 15th century along with displays on how they're made. It is housed in the monastic buildings of the Madre de Deus Convent, which after renovation following the Great Earthquake had its interior turned into one of the most magnificent in the city. The splendor and opulence of the chapel is just amazing!!!

A tour and a tile!. This was a great little tour and opportunity to make and take home an original tile. Following a short tour of the museum where we learned the history and heritage of Portuguese tile making and painting, we had the opportunity to paint our own tile after instruction by a tile artist. This was great fun and well work the 39 euro cost. The entire tour and tile creation took about two hours. Book well in advance if you have a group. You have an original souvenir from Portugal that you will never see in duplicate!
Different!. fantastic!!! Of course you have to like tiles which I do!! In the museum you can see a very unusual church, yes,a church!
Fantastic. Housed in a former convent. Quite cold with unfriendly staff BUT the displays are outstanding. The chapel was gorgeous - simply stunning!

A lovely gem of a museum.. This is a really nice little museum, tucked away from the city's bustling center.The museum is housed within an old convent, dating back to the early 16th century.It features numerous tiles and decorative panels from various eras and with numerous styles.There are 3 levels to the museum, of which, simply do not miss the stunning panorama of Lisbon from the 17th century (2nd floor), the beautiful Nossa Senhora da Vida (on the entrance floor), the breathtaking Madre de Deus church (also on the entrance floor) and the beautiful cloisters.Give yourself between an hour and two hours to take it all in.The entrance if free for LisboaCard holders (5 Euros, otherwise).

An oasis of visual interest. A bit out of the way, but a local bus takes you there easily enough once you've worked out which one to take. The converted convent is a beautiful building from the outside, the plant-surrounded entrance charming, the large shaded patio restaurant with pool with turtles a relaxed place to have lunch or a drink, and then you have the room after room of superb tiled walls, the convent's chapel covered with tiles, the interesting things in the shop. This is one of the best attractions in Lisbon.

Wonderful. This museum was the highlight of our trip to Lisbon. The exhibition of portuguese tiles was extraordinary, it was a shame the exhibition of hispanic tiles w\s not available. I would definitely recommend anyone interested in ceramic tiles to visit this museum.

Unusual, so worth looking out. Located in an attractive former convent, this unusual museum is worth a visit to gain more understanding of the tile work that is so typical of Portugal. It is a bit off the beaten track, but easily accessible by local bus services.
Interesting but could have been better. Good display albeit somewhat repetitive. Promised to show you how the different types of tiles are created but did not at all.
Amazing!. Do not miss this gem. The tile panorama of the city before the 1755 earthquake and also the chapel are major higjlights. Don't miss it

Disappointing. We trekked out to the Tile Museum because I loved seeing all the gorgeous tile throughout Lisbon and was looking forward to learning more about the history of the tiles. We also heard that the museum was free on Sundays. We got there around 3 and found out the museum is only free until 2. Most of the plaques were not in English and the staff was pretty gruff to us. I enjoyed seeing the collections, but didn't learn anything about the history which was disappointing.

Astonishing Museum. If the title "Tile Museum" doesn't tell you anything, just ignore that and head on out to visit it. You would never imagine how many gorgeous things can be done with ceramic tile - and this musuem will show you centuries of them. It incloses a beautiful old church. And there's a nice café with interesting "kitchen" tiles on display. One of the most interesting places in Lisbon.

a gem. With a little bit of research we were able to find this museum which is tucked away in an area that is not a mainstream tourist area. Buses do indeed get you within a block or two! We got there just in time for opening and were able to easily wander through this museum at our leisure. There were no crowds to fight through so it was easy to see everything and read as much as we pleased about each of the exhibits. This museum was packed with tile murals from every era and the written explanations were in English and were packed with interesting information. The Portuguese know how to "do tile" and the tile murals are absolutely worth viewing. An excellent way to spend a couple of hours.

Difficult to get to but worth the trip.. It took us 2 days to figure out how to get here using public transportation. What ever you do, do not go to the St. Apolonia metro stop expecting to get a bus to the museum. This is what you need to do to get there. Go to the Arroios metro stop and find the 718 or 742 bus stop which is right in front of a bakery. Tell the driver that you want to go to the tile museum and he will let you know when to get out. When you get out you will be directly across the street from it. We arrived at 2pm on a Sunday afternoon and the admission was free. Lots of beautiful hand painted tile work inside covering several centuries of history. On the top floor is the gigantic panoramic view of Lisbon painted on tile work. Amazing.

Well worth a visit, pleasant cafeteria. Little treasure of a museum, easily reached by bus from the centre of town (if you don't miss the stop like we did, as not all buses go directly past the museum and stop 150m or so around the corner). I found it made me appreciate even more the tiled houses you see everywhere in the city, and the tiling in many of the churches also. The cafe is small but very pleasant to sit in, with a courtyard area full of plants - we saw quite a few locals calling in for something to eat.

Must see in Lisbon. It is totally incomprehensible why other reviewers claim this place hard to be find or get there. From Praça do Comércio (which is in the center without doubt) you have 3 different choice of buses (759 or 781 or 728) to get there. From the bus station you need to walk a few hundred meters to the museum. For us it took less than 15 minutes.It is worth to go there not just for the tiles and the temple inside (Igreja da Madre de Deus) - which is truly amazing - but some pieces of modern art. Personally my favourite is Sofia Castro's masterpiece: Bad animal with good heart-ill weeds grow apace.Free of charge with Lisbon card.

Less then expected. This was a place I was super excited about going to! However, it's hard to get there, you have to take a taxi. Once there the entry and restaurant are nice however the museum seems to be in disrepair. The direction in which to walk was wonky and sometimes passed back over things you had already seem. The caption were only in English about 1/3 of the time. While it has a lot of potential, now, it just seems like a hodpodge of tiles in random places.

Nice objects; facility needs improvement. Excellent examples of tile works. Well displayed (chronology); chapel was the HIGHLIGHT of the visit.Unfortunately the building suffers from 'deferred maintenance'; needs improvements to be at par with its contents.Very small cafeteria and not many alternatives in the area for refreshments; not a good 'walking area' around the museum.
The best museum in Lisbon. In my opinion the best museum to visit in Lisbon!Really worth a visit!! Don't miss the amazing church inside the museum!
Beyond expectations.... While a tile collection doesn't sound thrilling, the venue and tile combined make the bus trip out and back well worthwhile. Nice small cafeteria for a lunch as well.

Worth the Effort. The Tile Museum is not close to most of the central tourist attractions, and you'll have to take a cab or bus. We took the bus from praca de comercio and it was easy there and back. It doesn't appear to be a "big" draw for most tourists, but that just means it's not very crowed. It was great. And I'm not especially excited about tiles. Don't miss the top floor. There's only one item there (a panoramic painting of the Lisbon waterfront before the 1755 earthquake - across hundreds of tiles), but it's one of the highlights.

Great Museum to showcase Portugal Tiles. #1 TIP: Request for audio tour - it was very very insightful. You will appreciate it more with the narrator*Review based on having an audio tour*PROs:-The main points of the museum are numbered and very easy to navigate.-Easy lay-out that shows the evolution of this amazing art that many Portuguese people should be proud of!-Unique art work + church inside the museumCONs:-Far from the main centre but cab ride is quite cheap.-Did not have a lot of audio available so just had to wait for 15 minutes-Few exhibit were closedOverall, worth a visit and would make you appreciate Tiles a bit more!

wanted a little more but ok. i'm not really a tile amateur and maybe thats why i wasn't so impressed about this museum. i wanted to see something more colorful more impressive. this is just my personal opinion but lisbon is full with beautiful tile (on buildings, churches, flea markets etc.) the museum ight be more for those that want more.to come here easy you can take 2 or 3 buses from praca de comercio, i can't remember what number or you can come to the museum when you plan your day in alfama, it's really not far from the castle of sao jorge.
Worth the visit. This museum is far from the center but is really worth the visit even if you are not an amateur of tiles

Tile heaven. This is one kind of art and craftsmanship the Portuguese lead the world.It is out of the city centre and poorly signposted - but the bus drivers were helpful - a really wonderful Portuguese trait. Taxi is another way to get there.Superb collection in a former nunnery - complete with a marvelous gilt and tile chapel. Fairly quiet when we were there, so it is relaxing. Lovely courtyard cafe, too. Get out of the crowds, and see some real Portugal.

Beautiful tile art!. This is definitely an interesting museum! It's a bit outside the center of the city and we had a hard time finding it, but it was worth it once we did. The tile exhibits are beautiful!

Highly recommended site beyond the central-city circuit. 3 stories of exquisite displays in a former convent easily reachable by bus or tram from Praco do Commercia main plaza or from Santa Appolonia final stop in Metro blue line.Uncrowded. (No bus groups, yay!)We went after reading a recommendation by Frank Bruni of The New York Times, and are glad we did. Sublimely pleasant cafe with inside garden courtyard tables, wine or beer and unexpectedly fine food (far, far better than at the Gulbenkian museum at the city's north end). Don't miss the tile-wall city panorama (pre- earthquake) on the top floor.

One for the tile fans!. This museum is away from the centre - you'll need a bus or taxi to get there - but it has an interesting collection of tiles set in an old convent building. Courtyard cafe is cool and pleasant.

Impressive but not time consuming. My friends and I visited on a Sunday and found out to our pleasure that it is free on Sundays! We took the 759 bus from Plaza Figueira and the bus driver was kind enough to tell us when to get off! From the bus stop, you cross the street and walk down towards a church and it is on the right side of the road. We thoroughly enjoyed every room from the early tile work to the church to the modern tile work.... but best of all is the panorama tile composition at the very top floor of Lisbon pre-earthquake! I would recommend going at the end of your trip so you can recognize what is what on that panorama. Neat little gift shop as well and friendly staff, plus a cheap cafe inside! We took a little over an hour and saw everything we wanted to see.

Amazing collection of tiles. This museum is housed in an old convent. The Chapel is beautiful and I enjoyed wandering around the cloisters and the various galleries. The layout was a little confusing, we received no map of the exhibitions and there didn't seem to be a suggested path, but we encountered one happy circumstance: we visited on a Sunday afternoon (after 2 pm) and entrance was free!

Could be better organized. Pluses. It has a beautiful chapel. It was a convent. It has a shaded garden with cafe that defines tranquil. If you get the audio guide you can learn a bit about tile patterns and that the subways in Lisbon date from only 1959 and I wonder if their tile decor inspired that started in the NYC subway system 25 yrs ago or so

worth the trip. This museum isn't exactly centrally located but its worth the trip. It is easy to get to the museum via public transit. The tiles on display are wonderful and the building the museum is housed in- a former monastery- is a sight to see in itself. When is Lisbon, add this to your list.

PORTUGAL´S SPECIAL. DON´T MISS IT. Tiles are Portugal´s Pride. This large Museum gives you a comprehensive view of tiles along the centuries. Plan a day long visit to it, this Museum deserves such a visit. There is a nice restaurant.

Heart of Portugal. The Portugues are the masters of tiles / azulejos and the museum is there to prove it. I was completely amazed by it, the way they turned this carft into art. All over Lisboa (subway included) you can see great art works made by tiles of tiple made into artwork if you wish. The museum shows how the craft has evolved throughout history and a great panoromic view of old Lisboa crafted - obviously - in Azulejos.There are some exhibits of modern / contemporary works which are also quite spectacular.

Great museum, worth the trek. It was a beautiful museum, with rooms based in an old convent, the most ornate church, cloisters within and examples of tiles throughout the ages. The cafe was lovely, in an internal terrace garden and the best bit of all - the terrapins swimming in the pond. It was a real walk to get there however, a good mile beyond the main tourist areas, so either get the bus or wear comfortable shoes!

A Hidden Gem. Was pleasantly surprised by this marvelous museum after Rick Steves gave it a mere one star (out of three) of places to visit in Lisbon. The building itself is gorgeous, and the tiles are really fascinating. Even if you don't think you're interested in tiles, this is well worth your time. In addition to tiles, there are church chapels and ornate interiors full of gold-leaf splendor and other architectural treats. Make sure to have a coffee on the large garden patio or lunch in the charming cafe.

Tile Kingdom. A bit tricky to find, but if you are interested in tiles do take the effort (or just take a taxi). The history and development of the Portuguese tiles (Azulejos) are described and shown very well, including contemporary pieces.

I am an azulejo fan!. This Museum is a very special or unique. Bus nr. 794 runs from across Casa dos Bicos to Madre de Deus Church, you cross the street and you are there. Nice big gate, little court with palm trees.The stuff is very polite, and give all informations, you need. The museum is so beautiful, showing the azulejos from th XV. century. One of the most interesting is a very very long white-blue, showing Lisboa before the 1755 big earthquake. Must see!. After the visit you can have a rest in an inside garden restaurant. Museum shop. I liked it very much.

an excellent overview. The museum is in the midst of a major transition from a fuddy-dud assemblage of times to a well documented and well labeled survey of (mostly) Portuguese tiles. The collection is eye-opening and stunning.The museum is reach on bus 579 that leaves from Praça Figueira.

Make the effort. This museum is a little off the beaten track compared to other museums in Lisbon, but well worth it. I walked there from the Alfama but it is probably worth taking the bus if coming from any further. It is located in the old Convent Madre de Jesus. There are rooms and rooms of azulejos but somehow you never tire of the changing colours, patterns, techniques. There are some English translations of signs, and videos. I was amazed when i walked into the Igreja da Madre de Deus, the chapel of the convent. Lined with tiles and gold decorations it is stunning - a very special place to experience. And don't think you have seen it all until you climb to the top floor to see the tile panorama of Lisbon depicting the city before the 1755 earthquake. Extremely detailed and great to examine after a few days exploring Lisbon, so you can picture where palaces, monasteries, bridges etc were, and what remains. The cafe is pleasant with hot and cold dishes and a nice outdoor terrace. The shop offers great cards, scarves, textiles and .....tiles!

Tiles. We enjoyed our visit to the museum. There were some very interesting tiles and also the beautiful Convent church to see full of gold. I did not like the modern pieces at all. The panoramic of Lisbon was very interesting. Well worth a visit

Portuguese memories on tails.. If you are looking for the true Portugal history and culture you should visit this museum, where you find out the truth historic Portuguese landscape/buildings/costumes/traditions as well as the amazing Portuguese tail manufacturing technique/fine art.

Cultural, creative and calm. We dropped by here as part of our day exploring Lisbon by bike. The exhibits were informative and wide ranging. We particularly liked the modern works interspersed with the historical works. An unhurried wander around the exhibits was achieved in under 2 hours followed by a coffee in the cafe. Worth the trip away from the centre city.

A unique experience. A must see museum. It is in a convent with an over the top baroque chapel. The juxtaposition of contemporary ceramic art with historic tiles is exceptional. You will need a taxi to get there but they are very affordable. If you don't go you have cheated yourself out of an unusual experience.
Azulejos museum ... Amazing. Magnificient chapel ... Great surprise in this museum. Also very interesting fresque of Lisbonne beforebthe earthquake

Do not miss it!. Well actually you might miss it if you don't pay attention---we took the bus from Sta Appolonia and went too far, got off at the wrong stop and had to ask for directions 4 times before we got it right! The bonus was we got to see a really pretty part of Lisbon with lovely private homes. But once we found it we were enchanted. This museum does a wonderful job of presenting the old tiles along with new artwork by contemporary ceramic artists. There is a decent self-serve café with a shady garden in the back.

Worthwhile for anyone interested in Portugese art or architecture. This museum has a comprehensive collection of Portugese tiles on display, as well as many other ceramic artworks. There is also information on how the hand painted glazing is done. The museum is located in a former monastery, with beautiful painted murals on thd walls and ceilings in sections. Free entry on Sundays.

Wonderful stop!. Can't imagine why more tourists are not visiting this lovely museum. The story of tile making and design is fundamental to a visit to Portugal and this museum tells it well. You will have greater appreciation for the tiles you will see throughout your visit on walls, in churches, hotels and museums. There is also a charming garden cafe and bar if you feel like a glass of wine or a snack. And directly across the street is a Mitadoro with a gorgeous view. When you are ready to leave, just walk down the hill into town. A perfectly lovely way to spend a couple of hours on a sunny day!
Fascinating. Interesting museum located in an old convent giving a great insight into the history of tiles. Would highly recommend this place even if you are not a tile specialist

Wow! If you like tile, you'll love this one.. Beautiful exhibits, including videos and models showing how painted tiles are created. There were many historical styles and examples, including a long panorama of the city in azulejos. Also, some modern examples to show what is being done with ceramics, not just flat tiles. In a lovely old building, that appears to have been something like a convent. It's not easy to find and is located in an industrial district, but bus service is readily available.
Must see. This is one of my favourite museums in Lisboa.Very good collection and beautiful museum.Do not miss...

Worth the trip. This is worth the bus ride if you're interested in finding out more about the ceramic tiles you'll see all over Lisbon and the rest of Portugal. Plus the museum has free entry on Sunday mornings!

for tile lovers. This is a mecca for lovers of Portuguese tiles. Since I turned out to not particularly like them (the style is too coarse for me), I was disappointed. I like Arab geometrical patterns (like in the National Palce of Sintra) - and those were far and few between.
Fascinating. A must-see for decorative arts lovers. They also have a lovely garden cafeteria. Located on a bus line, but make sure you check-- the schedules can be tricky.

Peaceful and lovely off the beaten path. Take bus 759 or 754, or a taxi (5 euros from Commerce square). Beautiful former convent houses a collection of tiles showing the development and excellence of this historic Portuguese art form. We especially enjoyed a room showing very modern designs juxtaposed with 15th and 16th century tiles. The ornate chapel is not to my taste but is still impressive. Much more interesting for me were the rose garden and the temporary exhibitions. There is a tranquil courtyard cafe and tearoom. The return bus stops right outside the museum wall.

Wrap up eight hundred years of tiles in a superb 16th Century Church for bliss. I would repeat what Dee Dee from Armidale, Australia wrote.This somewhat hidden gem is one of the most interesting and beautiful museums I haveever visited. Read the other reviews as they tell it all - a must visit for any visitor toLisbon; understand the history, the culture, the beauty.
Fun and informative. I really enjoyed the floor that had all the modern tiles on it! it was just fun to wander around and learn about Portugal's amazing history!
Beautiful. Loved this museum and got a good sense of the art of tiles throughout the times. Would definitely recommend.

Pretty!. It was a way to go via public transport but it was a nice museum. Seeing all the different tiles going back hundreds and thousands of years was interesting. It wasn't too big a museum that your feet hurt either.
My favorite. This is set in an old nun convent with the most amazing church. The detail and building is simply breath taking. The tiles are interesting and a center of Portugal.

A hidden Gem (Museu nacional do Azulejo). So much to see here, what a pity that they don't advertise more as it was difficult to find once you got off the bus at Lidl Supermarket. The passing buses are 28, 718, 742,759,794.Fantastic interiors of Madre de Deus Mid 16th Century Church and examples of tiles as you have never seen them before.Also a nice little café with outside court yard.
