The History of Portuguese Ceramics. If you're interested in the origins and manufacture of Portuguese tile, visit this museum. The bus stops right in front of this former convent. Lovely cafe.

Great afternoon treat. The tile museum seemed an off the beaten track tourist destination, however on a rainy day it seemed a great thing to do with the children (ages 9 & 11). It is quite hard to get there, we were told to take bus 794 but it was hard to find where to catch this bus from. The bus stop is on the side of the yellow building across from Casa dos Bicos (House of the Pointed Stones). The bus stop you need to get off at is Igreja Madre Deus which is just outside the museum. Inside the museum there are 100s of tiles and we spent the afternoon exploring all the floors. The church is a bit of a surprise and completely over the top. The huge tile overview of Lisbon prior to the 1755 earthquake is great and we spent quite some time pointing out parts of Lisbon we had been to during our week stay.

Great museum. This museum is a little out of the way but only a couple blocks from Tram/Bus stops. It is worth the trip. Various tiles from many centuries some humorous, other religious, and geometric. Top floor has a tile overview of Lisbon prior to the earthquake in 1700 were you can pick out parts that survived such as Belem Tower. Worth the small fee.

mind blowing. I admit I am a bit obsessed with azulejos. I spent 3 hours here and took about 500 photos. The church and convent themselves are works of art, before you add in the museum displays. If you aren't into tiles, don't go. If you are, or just love art, its a must see. Catch the 794 or 759 bus.
We came out seeing the city in a new way. Its a very Portuguese thing and highly enjoyable. We came out seeing the tiles which are so characteristic of the city in a new way

Don't Miss the Tile Panorama Upstairs. This museum that is a bit out of the way is worth the side trip east of downtown. Of particular note is the ceramic tile panorama upstairs that depicts Lisbon prior to the devasting earthquake in 1755.

More than you'd think. Tiles sound like a rather specialist interest, and I avoid home decor magazines at all costs. But this is a beautiful place, and the church and its upper galleries are spectacular. Cafe is great too. And if you're into ceramics...

Uniquely Portuguese experience with a wonderful collection of tiles. This is a uniquely Portuguese experience, or at least the only tile museum I've visited. It has an extensive collection of tiles, and as some reviewers have noted, the piece on the top floor showing Lisbon's skyline is impressive.What is stopping me for giving it 5 stars is that I feel the presentation of the tiles could be improved. There was insufficient explanation on the history of the tiles on display. There were also renovation/refurbishment works going on. That said, this museum is well worth a visit if you are in Lisbon.Please note that the museum is called Museu Nacional de Azulejo in Portuguese.

If you enjoy viewing tile work don't miss this museum. At the recommendation of a tour guide friend I visited the National Tile Museum in Lisbon. All I can say is "Wow"! I'm very glad I took the time to see this museum. Yes, it's not in the very center of town, I took a public bus there, but it's easy to find and well worth the effort. The tiles run the gamut from religious to 20th century geometric and I enjoyed every bit of it.

An eye opener. I had anticipated just more of the same blue tile one sees everywhere, only to find out there is a lot more to Portuguese tile than I ever imagined. More importantly, once you have seen what is in this museum, you will be able to judge much more critically the tilework you see elsewhere in Portugal. It is definitely worth your time!
unique. This is great collection from all over the place, with ancient and modern tiles to enjoy. Worth the taxi ride.

Heaven as decorated by tiles. We already knew before we got to Lisbon that the characteristic blue azulejo tiles were going to be a highlight for us. We were in love with the iznik we saw in Istanbul, and the Spanish azulejos we have seen in places like Cordoba.So I made sure to visit this museum on our first day in Lisbon, and this was the perfect plan. The combination of the incredible collection of tiles from 4 centuries and the convent rooms all decorated in tile just delighted us beyond description. I even liked (some) of the modern tiles!The highlight of the collection has to be the 18th-century (pre-earthquake) map of the city in tile, filling an entire gallery on the top of the museum. They call it the panorama I believe. Just spectacular.The museum's cafe is very nice - with some refreshing and filling salads. The waiter there seems easily overwhelmed, but if you are patient, it is just the most tranquil spot, perfect for refreshment and contemplation of the museum's riches!

Outstanding tile collection inside a convent. We were pleasantly surprised with not just a chronological showcase of tiles but probably the most decadent displays of paintings and religious artifacts in gold in a convent. Like other reviews, the directional signs weren't prominently displayed but we thoroughly enjoyed this hidden gem. Too bad it's not as well advertised especially with signage on road ways. Be sure to see the panoramic tile collection near the end. It is amazing and ceramic artistry at its best.
Excellent Museum. Wonderful museum with lots of exhibits of beautiful tiles and explanations of how they were done. Lovely courtyard for lunch or a snack.

Not good orientation. The place has an amazing tile collection, but the museum hasn't a good orientation for a self guided visit. Some times you get lost with too much tiles... the best is the Lisbon skyline before earthquake portrayed on a huge 23 meters tiles panel, is on the last floor.

Very interesting!. I arrived at this museum in a rainy day where I did not know what to do for a couple of hours...and I did not have many expectations. But I found out a real little jewel! The museum has lots of azulejos, organized cronologically in rooms, and nice "patios". If you did not have a clue about azulejos, this place gives you precious hints without being too verbose...or boring. And after all those decorated tiles, you can get a decent caffè in the inside bar. Worth the visit.

Interesting. We had a very good guide. She described as we went along the styles, colour, designs and dates of the tiles. Although very beautiful without this insight it may have become just lots of tiles. There is a wonderful church on the site and some exceptional china pieces and art works too. The restaurant was very nice with a good selection of lunches. We were able to do the tile workshop. You decorate a plan tile provided. The museum fire it and you collect a few days later. I've hung mine, its a reminder of the day.

Old and new - tiles are always beatiful. The museum is located a little bit outside of the heart of Lisbon so the best is take a bus. Very interesting vast collection of tiles, some details about production, fascinating view of Lisbon before the earthquake of 1755. I liked contemporary part of tiles collection. Being in Lisbon tiles are everywhere but it is worthy to see them in special place

Most interesting Musuem on Iberian Tour. Tile making is historically important and interesting in Lisbon. This museum has the most fascinating collection of tile displays imaginable. It is even connected to a chapel of a former monastery whose walls are covered with tiles. A three hour tour is recommended. Don't miss this!

Worth a visit. Plenty of tiles, as you'd expect, and religious iconography. The chapel is quite something, as is the panoramic tiled artwork of Lisbon before the earthquake. Worth a visit although it is a bit out of the way. Take a taxi from the centre for 5 euros each way, it's not worth the fuss of public transport
Unique Collection, well displayed. While the location could be a challenge to some, this is a world class collection and the panorama of Lisbon before its earthquake is a must-see.

Excellent Overview of Portuguese Tile. The building is fabulous but so is the collection. It starts in the XV century and ranges up to the present. It shows a bit about tile making but as much as anything, the progression of design from Moorish & Arab designs through to more European designs in later centuries. It was certainly worth a two hour visit--oh and the chapel and choir loft is a knock-out!

Azulejos Forever!. If vacations had themes, our trip to Portugal would have a theme of azulejos, the elaborate tiles that the Portuguese used to decorate their homes, churches and government buildings (inside and out). They range from abstract geometrical designs, to floral patterns, to portraits, panoramas and history lessons. The originals were white and blue (thus "azulejos" - azul is the Portuguese word for blue), but quickly expanded the palette to every color in the spectrum. The Tile Museum is a double pleasure: not only does it provide wonderful examples of tile artistry through history, but it is housed in the former Mother of God Convent and some of the art from the convent has been preserved in several rooms. Some will find the tiles from the 20th century, including a Cubist rendering, not to their taste, but I found them a pleasant diversion from the more traditional themse of older tiles. On the other hand, there could be nothing more whimsical than the huge tiled presentation of "the chicken's wedding", with baboons as the coach drivers, etc. Also, don't miss the cafe - good food and a delightful garden seating area.The only drawback to the Museum is its location, in the far eastern Lisbon neighborhood of Xabregas, along the river about halfway between Alfama and Nations' Park. I believe there are buses available.

A must. This museum should definitely be on your list if you are visiting Lisbon, not only for their collection of tiles but also for the building itself. The monastery was built in the XVI century and survived the earthquake, it has a beautiful church and chapels. The collection of the tiles and tile panels is amazing! You can see tile panels that have always been part of the monastery, tiles saved from destroyed buildings (palaces, churches) and some donated. Just beautiful. Definitely don't forget your camera. And then end the visit with a snack at their restaurant/cafeteria which is decorated with tiles as well.
Amazing!. This museum is not in central Lisbon, but easily accessible by metro and bus. An old convent houses the most remarkable examples of Portuguese tile work.;; Worth the find!

could try harder. i dont get this museum. its supposed to be one of LIsbons gems but i dont know why! hard to find by walking - get the number 794 bus which drops you outside. at least i went on a sunday morning and it was free! the highlight for me was not the tiles but the beautiful chapel that is steeped in history. if you had to not do something in Lisbon. this is it.
Interesting. This was somewhat out of the way but accessible by bus. Very interesting self guided tour with electronic headsets.

Tile museum visit. We enjoyed the visit and there was an extremely helpful lady who exxplained it all to us. our personal preference is for the older tiles - superb - and the top floor Lisbon panorama. The 20th century ones are not to our taste.
Interesting. An amazing array of ceramics some over 300 years old in a beautifully decorated arena. They should have more information in English though.
well worth a visit. even if you think it would not be interesting, the rang of tiles and pictures created are truly impressive......the building, an old nunnery is also very interesting.

1001 and 1 ways to decorate tiles!. You need to take a bus or a taxi to see this but well worth it for the building itself, never mind the tiles! Complete history of Portuguese tile making and well laid out on different floors.

Off the track, but worth it. Recommended by a local, it took a bit of time (and an adventure on the local bus) to get there, but it was a great museum if you're interested in azulejos -- fascinating stuff and nicely laid out. It includes contemporary tiles as well as those from the 1500s.

Do not miss. Although this is a little way out of centre of town and a 20 minute walk from nearest metro, it is really a must. We loved to find out about the history of the many tiles everywhere in Lisbon. It was a lovely building - a converted church we think as it still has lovely'church part'. Refreshments in nice cafe. It IS on the the blue bus open air tour which runs hourly. - do not miss.

Beautiful and Great. Impressive tiles dated by to the middle age. Rich history about different tiles. The museum is designed in chronological order, from ancient to contemporary. However, we did it reversely as if a trip through time, in which we saw the art's progression from refinement to abstraction. Really worth visiting!

Beautiful tiles!. We were able to use our Lisboa card and have free admission otherwise it is five euros. This museum is located in a 16th century convent and cloister. The church of Madre de Deus is very ornate with blue tiled scenes decorating the sides and gold decor everywhere else. The Rocco altar is quite spectacular. Throughout the several floors are tile scenes from as early as the 17th century. Photographs are allowed. On the top floor is the 118 foot tiled Panorama of Lisbon which is supposed to be the country's longest piece. Portugal is known for their use of tiles throughout the city and I believe you should put this museum on your list because the tiled scenes are quite unique and beautiful.

Nice tiles, little information. This tile museum has many impressive tile compositions, many up to 300 years old. It is quite spacious and a nice way to spend an hour if the weather is not so good. Unfortunately, there is very little information in English and very little history on the art form and why and how it became so prevalent in Portugal.

Different. It's rather out of the way but can be reached by bus (infrequent on sunday) or by taxi. It's set in what was a monastery and the overall collection is well worth a look. The chapel is amazing, if rather OTT for anglo-saxon protestant taste.

Go!. I never thought I would visit a tile museum, but tiles are everywhere in Lisbon and help define the city's unique character. Some beautiful examples of the art, as well as the famous image of Lisbon before the earthquake. The museum is a bit off the beaten track, but a couple of buses stop outside.

Tiles are everywhere. I preferred the 17th century tiles and paterns. The restauration department is fabulous and schools are doing a "tile-make-day" for the kids.The church was a bit too much of the "goldy-oldy": it was literarely plastered with goldfoil : if you like that ( there is also a church like that in Rome ) :go and see it.We did not.There are enough beautiful churches in Lisbon without the "rumbazumba-look how-much-gold-i got-church". Restaurant and shop : Very, very friendly.

Definitely worth a visit. Since it was winter, there was some work going on around the museum. The staff in the museum was rather surly and some things aren't well marked (like don't walk on the parquet floors); but the items on display on marvelous and the restaurant is great.

An old convent full of tiles. The building itself is worth seeing and the tiles were wonderful. There is a beautiful church inside and the tiles are arranged around the balconies of an inner courtyard
great traditional art. One of the best things I saw in Lisbon. Not really hard to get there if you're used to live in a big city where distances are far bigger. Worth a visit!

Splendid Portuguese fine art tiles. This excellent museum of some of the finest azulejos Portugal has produced is attached to the magnificent Madre de Deus church. A little out of the way (bus 759 from the Santa Apolónia metro station), but well worth a visit. See the fascinating panorama of Lisbon before the earthquake of 1775 painted on tiles.

Great museum. The only downside is that it's not the easiest to get to. (We took the metro to Santa Apolonia, then grabbed a taxi and it cost only about 4-5 euros for the taxi fare) But once we were there, we were so glad we went! Lovely building inside and out. The tiles are amazing. I didn't realize that it's connected to a church. The church was tiny but gorgeous. You might think a museum of only tiles could get repetitive and boring, but it was not boring at all, and there was a huge array of tiles, from simple patterned ones to huge works of art. We ordered hot drinks in the cafe and were pleased with the lovely atmosphere of the cafe.

Enjoyable and pleasant setting. This was enjoyable for the visual, decorative content and historical information.It is well laid out. There is some technical detail on the manufacture and dating methods of tiles .Displayed pieces from 1600s to modern .Excellent cafe,reasonably priced and clean.Good facilities.

Fabulous free day!. The museum is well worth a visit. We went on Sunday when it is free. You can take the 754 or 798 bus to get there. They leave from the Santa Apolonia or Tereiro do Praca metro stations or you can take the 754 from downtown at Rossio or Restauradores. Get off at the Igrega Madre Deus stop. The museum is inside the convent. The regular price is 5 euro admission. There are three floors each showcasing different centuries of artwork. The chapel and the panorama of pre-1755 Lisbon are worth the trip.

Ask for audiotour!!. The tile museum is located a little bit out of the center but definatly worth a visit. Easy to reach by car and there is also a bus stop right in front of the Madre de deus church (where the museum is located in).One very important thing is that they do not offer the audio tour, you have to ask for it. And it makes all the difference in the world! Your given headphones and a 'pointer', troughout the museum you can 'point' it to numbers on the wall and a story will be told. Without these stories I think the museum might be a bit boring and overpriced so make absolutely sure you get the audio tour (its is included in the price).The entrance is €5,-.The museum is very friendly for disabled people.

directions for walking from Sta Apollonia metro station. The 794 bus stops at the museum door, but we couldn't see the 794 bus stop at the metro station so, having read that it's an 800 metre walk, we decided to go on foot. Lucky we had a map because there are no signs anywhere to keep you on the right track. Leave the metro station on the Line 1 side, turn right and just keep walking, under the Vasco da Gama bridge, until you see the convent gates. The entry is off the road on the lower side. It took us about 15 minutes, the chapel alone is well worth the walk, the tiles are very interesting, and we had a very nice inexpensive snack lunch at the restaurant/café.

Great all round atraction. Situated in a splendid 16 th century convent the museum has a great collection of tiles (from old to 20 th century great portuguese artists). Moreover at the site (included in the price of the museum) you have by far one of the most beautiful churches in Lisbon.Finally had a fab cappuccino with a really delicious up side pineapple cake. So don't forget to visit the cafeteria (also beautiful tiles there coming from two old palace kitchens in Lisbon)

Worth a visit. The tiles tell the history of the country and are nice in and of themselves. However, there's an amazing church right inside the museum, which could serve as a separate attraction. It's great!

Great tiles, wish there had been more information about tile history and creation. I went to the Tile Museum on a Sunday, when admission is free, and I'm so glad I did, because I went through the museum pretty quickly, even though I saw everything, some things twice. I thought the tiles were beautiful, and it was very interesting to learn about their context, but I had been hoping for a little more information about the history behind tiles in Lisbon, and how they're made, or some other interesting facts or knowledge of tiles. As it was, I left with some fantastic pictures, and with a glad feeling from having been able to see so many pretty tiles.Overall, I'd say, go on a Sunday, because otherwise I'm not sure the entrance fee is worth what you get.

So many tiles. We took the bus here, it lets you off about three blocks away, looks like kind of a run down area but there were four of us walking from the stop trying to find the museum and we were fine. We arrive in the morning and there were few other visitors which was nice. We enjoyed learning about the history of tiles and the development of the different styles and how other cultures influenced over time. Make sure you visit the top floor at the end to see the panoramic tile picture of Lisbon.

I'm glad I went. Good collection of tiles, but some rooms currently closed. The 24m panorama of Lisbon pre-earthquake was worth the price of entry if one has an interest in historical towns. I found it fascinating and spent at least 30 minutes studying it. Lots of beautiful tiles, which I love. The building is a treat as well including the chapel. Well worth visiting.

Magnific. The building is an old convent, with beautiful garden unfortunately not very easy to find. But after 1 hour walk we star our visit with a soup and a cake in the cafeteria.
The museum will take you into the history of Lisbon.
Don't miss the great fresco of Lisbon before the earhquake!

Nice museum!. This is a beautiful museum located in an old convent. Even if you have no interest in tile, the presentation of the tile will probably draw you in. We went here mostly because the museum was so well reviewed, not because we were particularly interested in the subject matter, and ended up staying longer than we planned to. Plus the beautiful church alone makes it his museum worth going to.
Lisbon soul. If you really want to feel the spirit of Lisbon this is that place ! From XV century till XIX-XX. great exibition ! On sundays it is free untill 14:00 o'clock;)

Great place to spend a couple of hours.. Not the sort of thing that would usually attract me to be honest, but having gone I ended up really enjoying it. Fantastic array of tiles and lots of history and stories to keep you informed. Give it a go as you will be surprised how good it is here. The cafe&restaurant is very good too.

Interesting place. Take a bus from downtown to Oriente train station and hop off by the museum. Spend a couple of hours and marvel at the history and designs, then take refreshment in the restaurant. A good place to see

Interesting place to spend a rainy day. Excellent collection of tiles from various periods over the last 500 years. If you like the tile work you see in historic places around Lisbon then this place is worth a stop, otherwise I don't know that it will be too interesting for you. The building itself is an old convent, with a gorgeous chapel that is worth the trip alone. On Sunday morning entry is free, so that's probably the best time to plan a trip if your schedule allows.Note: The museum can be reached by bus (easy to catch from the Praca do Comercio) or a walk through the Alfama. If you're in the Praca do Comerico (the main square in Lisbon) then stop by the tourist office on the Northwest side of the square and they will help you figure out what bus to take. The museum isn't the greatest part of town (not particularly scenic) so plan on walking up through the Alfama or catching the bus back into town after your visit.

unforgettable. very informative, you will never more look at a portuguese tile the same way! the hearing guide is fantastic and makes from the visit so much better unlike other museums where you need to struggle with small fonts in their description slips... wonderful resyaurant inside!

See some of Portugal heritage in tile form!. This museum has some very nice tile work, and while not as exiting as an amusement park, it is a must see if you are interested in what makes Portugal what it is.
Azulejos. Azulejos, and only azulejos, and that's what makes Lisbon and Portugal so unique. Great panorama of pre-Earthquake (1755) Lisbon.
Brilliant. If you are interested in tiles and design, this is worth a visit. The modern section was equally good.

Learn about the history of tiles in Portugal. This museum is filled with beautiful tiles from various periods in history. The museum itself is also beautiful--don't miss the elaborate chapel. I particularly enjoyed the tile mural of pre-1755 earthquake Lisbon. It was fun to find places that we had visited depicted in these tiles.

worth a visit. If you get on a Sunday before 14pm you have the chance to get in for free.
Very nice experience; good explanations, good pieces.
We got there by bus from Santa Apolonia metro station.
Enjoyable look at history through colorful tiles. Short taxi or bus ride from Alfama or Baixa, but we enjoyed learning more about the colorful tiles seen throughout Portugal.

Interesting if you like tiles...but even so, needs some love. We had been interested in all the tiles we had seen around the country, so this was a natural stop for us. The variety is impressive, the fact that you can watch restoration work being done is really cool, and the mural of pre-earthquake Lisbon - with some of the landmarks that still exist today - was incredible.That being said, it isn't close to anything else, some of the rooms were closed making the layout confusing and disjointed, and the museum building itself obviously needed to have some money spent on it - one of the windows in the chapel was broken, but hadn't been fixed. Based on the condition of the tape, it had been there awhile.The staff also weren't especially helpful or interested in answering questions.

Interesting Perspective on Lisbon History. Tile is such an integral part of Lisbon that the Tile Museum is a good stop. You will learn about the history and influences of Portuguese tile. You also get a chance to visit a well-preserved convent and beautiful chapel.

Museu Nacional do Azulejo. A must go to better understand Portugal History.. Probably the best tile collection in the World. Housed in the old convent of Madre de Deus in Lisbon it has tiles representing the different eras of Portugal until the XX Century. There is even a tile view of Lisbon before 1755 earthquake. The old church of the Convent remains has magnificent as in the old days and surely one of the most beautiful Portuguese churches. This place is heaven for decorative art lovers. Free admission on Sundays until 14h00. The Museum Shop has a weird guy attending that does not speak foreign languages and stress with that for how many years God knows. Portugal at its best..

A sweet place to spend an afternoon, but definitely all tiles.. We went here at a fellow B&Ber's recommendation. This is a beautiful museum that has a range of tiles in a fun presentation. There's also a church-type space filled with tiles for a different presentation. I loved seeing it, I'm glad I went, and I would recommend... but part of me wishes there were more than just tiles. It's hard to look at just tiles for more than an hour or two. And, for a tile museum, the gift shop had an oddly small tile offering.

all the tiles you could want to see. An absolute amazing collection of tiles with a great explanation on a free (with the 5 euros entrance ticket) personal audio guide. I stayed several hours to see it all. Easy to reach too> take bus 759 from the city center squares and get off when you see the Lidl supermarket sign.
Wonderful museum. I loved everything about the museum.I spent an afternoon there and was in awe of the the craftwork involved. I would thoroughly recommend a visit.

Hard to find, and nothing amazing. We took a very long walk to find this museum... and it was okay. Not terrible, but probably not worth the trek unless you are really into the tiles and want to know a lot more. There are some interesting displays, but, overall, we found this to be quite average.

Tiles. On my first trip to Lisbon I marveled at the tiled buildings and sidewalks. On my second trip I visited the National Tile Museum and really enjoyed learning the history of tiles and seeing the numerous wonderful displays. It was the perfect activity for a couple of hours on a rainy day.

the BEST of THE BEST!!!!. The National Tile Museum has positively got to be one of THE best places in Portugal to visit to experience the uniqueness (and perhaps one might even use the word, "genius" in this respect) of the traditional Portuguese aesthetic!! Firstly, the museum is housed in the architectural gem of the "Manueline" Convent of Madre de Deus situated on what was once almost the shoreline of the River Tejo. The main portal of the building is, I think, an almost-perfect 19th c. reconstruction of the original "Manueline" doorway. The church in this convent ( I do not know how much of what one sees today has been re-built/restored and how much of it actually survived the earthquake of 1755, because the unity of guilded wooden carving and wall tiles and paintings on the cofferred ceiling look perfectly harmonious....) is a wonderful amalgamation of artistic "churchwork"--e.g. guilded carved wood, paintings, tiles, etc.-- from the 16th through 19th centuries. Secondly, the collection of TILES here , exhibited chronologically from the 15th c.through to the 21st c.,, is unequalled for their range and quality---they have much of "the BEST of the best" on display in their permanent collection---including an incredible, and vast, early 18th c. blue and white tile "panorama" pictorial view , from the river , of the Lisbon shoreline BEFORE the earthquake of 1755!! --- and there is at present also an excellently-curated temporary exhibition of tile panels and relevant ceramics. Thirdly, and reason enough to visit this museum if only for this, is their cafe: It is adjacent to a quite salubrious and lovely shaded garden area (in which one can eat and drink and relax when the weather permits). The cafe's walls are themselves covered with a totally UNIQUE and idiosyncratic set of 19th c."kitchen" azulejos depicting a riot of food products--fish, chorizos, hares, "leitao" (suckling pigs), game birds, gourds, cheeses etc.etc. all "hung" , that is, depicted as though these were actually hanging from the walls! .And even if the food offerred weren't quite good (which it actually IS!!), sitting and eating among these tiles alone would be reason enough to take a meal here!! This Museum is absolutely NOT a place to be missed when visiting Lisboa!!

Essential viewing in Lisbon. If you want to understand Lisbon, go there first, you'll see how the azulejos (tiles) have been linked to the Lisbon scenery for centuries. Lots of marvels to see in this small museum set in a beautiful building.

Yes - a tile museum. I wasn't too excited about going to a tile museum.Sounded boring, this was anything but.It turns out to be a first rate art museum.The tiles are magnificent.Also there is a really impressive reconstructed over the top , Rocco coo (?) church.Well worth going to!

A must see musuem when in Lisbon. This museum is a great find! Well set up for all to visit - they have audio guides included in the entrance price, also set up with braille and a system for those hard of hearing - if you like the tiles that you see in the city, this is the place to learn about the history of them & their uses. It is in a old church which is quite interesting - easy to get to by public bus from the center of Lisbon.

The Tile museum in Lisbon is well worth visiting. Anyone who has been to Portugal will know how important Tiles are in that country. They are everywhere! And this museum is a great place to see how they have developed over the centuries and to see how beautiful they can be. Each section is dedicated to a century - 17th c., 18th c., and so on. So you can see how tiles developed over time. Some of the examples are staggering. The highlight is a wall which must be 15 metres wide at least which is a picture made up of tiles of Lisbon as it looked from the river before the earthquake of 1755. This museum is well worth a visit - spending a couple of hours looking at tiles sounds boring, but it isn't - it's fascinating and I would recommend it. There is a charge normally but because we went on National Holiday we got in for free!

An extraordinary, unique experience.. The story of Portuguese tiles is all here in this unique museum. The exhibits are quite breath taking, we've never seen anything like this before. A history of decorative tiles and their applications is fascinating. Portugal certainly has a pre-eminent position in this expression.

Went on a rainy day and was pleasantly surprised. There aren't many places that going to a tile museum would be interesting. But because of the history of tiles in Portugal, this place is actually pretty cool. All levels of the museum have great tile displays. The pre earthquake panorama in tile on the top floor is the topper. There is also a brief look into the area where tiles are stored and restored. There are crates and crates full of tiles.The museum itself is housed in an old convent. The building itself is beautiful. The cloister/garden has been turned into an outside dining area. We ate lunch here and honestly it was some of the best food we ate in portugal (being vegetarians). The veggie quiche was awesome. Also there is an elevator for wheelchair access to every level.

From Old to New. This museum is not an easy find. Thankfully friends from Portugal advised me and we spent the morning walking through the restored convent offering a comprehensive collection of Portugese tiles from ancient to modern. They also have a nice cafe looking out onto a garden and gift shop. Fascinating, don't miss this if you have the time.

Beautiful tile work in a charming convent. The tile works here cover several centuries and are an amazing collection of wonderful tile pieces. Unique! Displayed attractively in this very old convent. If you like tile, do not miss this museum!

A "must see". Tile art is something very characteristic about Lisbon. In this museum you can follow all th history of tile art. The highlights are: 1) the 23 m. long panorama of Lisbon before the tsunami of 18th century 2) the church inside the museum with the impressive sculptures

Comprehensive collection of Portugese tiles from ancient to modern.. Not well signposted from the bus but worth seeking out for a display of tilemaking from the earliest to modern. The gallery of modern tiles is particularly impressive. There is a lovely cafe for hot or cold lunch with a sitting out area if preferred.

Mind-Blowing Collection. Large murals made of tile, mostly blue-on-white but sometimes more colorful, are a Portuguese specialty. This museum houses some gorgeous examples, some old, some contemporary. The collection is housed in an old convent, in rooms off the cloisters. Most of the pieces on display are labeled in Portuguese and English, and there's enough background information to provide a basic education about the art form. A visit here is also good preparation for the tilework in some of the churches and palaces you're likely to see on your visit to Lisbon.

NOT TO BE MISSED. If you are interested in Portuguese culture and what makes Portuguese decoration unique then you should really visit this place. A real find. The museum is in a convent and the decoration is overwhelming as is the chapel which is a site to behold! Don't go to Lisbon without visiting this fabulous homage to the tile!
Not your usual. The history of tiles in Portugal. Some very interesting examples of this type of decoration. Worth a side trip if you have the time

More Tiles and More. The Tile museum is a bit hard to find, get very good directions or take a taxi. But the exhibits are beautiful and give some insight into the orgins and history and artestry of the tiles seen all over Portugal. Worth the effort

azulejos. A fine Manueline entrance and cloister, gilded wood, painted and tiled church, and superb series of tiled displays. Especially enjoyed huge panorama of Lisbon before the 1755 earthquake- with cathedral and Belem monastery still recognisable. Nice (tiled) restaurant.
Nice building, interesting info about the tiles art. I enjoyed visiting the building and the museum. Interesting to see tiles of different centuries and to be explained how a beautiful tile is made.

A real treasure. You'll se azulejos, or painted tiles, everywhere in Portugal. This museum, housed in a convent, which is worth the trip in itself, contains tiles from different centuries through Lisbon's history. The most amazing, though, is the panoramic tile wall done early in the 18th century, before the earthquake devastated Lisbon. The sense of history is amazing. The chapel in the convent is among the most impressive in Lisbon, complete with reliqueries! The museum has a lovely restaurant in an open courtyard, with some very nice appetizers, sandwiches, quiches, and omelettes, at very reasonable prices. If the weather is nice, the meal is a relaxing end to a beautiful museum tour.
A must see. We visited this museum on a recent trip to Lisbon. It was definitely a highlight of the trip. The chapel in the museum was amazing.

Very nice!. The museum is really very nice and enjoyable. The church came as a surprise since I didn't know it was there, and it is sure worth a look!Not really easy to find by public transportation if you take the bus n. 781 as it leaves you in the middle of a busy street and there are no signs to guide you to the museum, bring a map. The restaurant is not worth a lunch, maybe just a beer or coffee

National tile museum. It was a beautiful place. The exhibits were from the 15th to the 20th centuries, and were housed in a most attractive building. It was rather a long walk from the Santa Apolonia tube station so best to best to take the 794 bus.

A unique and rewarding experience. This is an art museum and a history museum combined, tracing the history of tile as an art form and using that to help interpret the history of Lisbon. The collection of tile art from the 15th to 21st centuries is really quite spectacular, with many outstanding pieces, not least of which is the depiction of Lisbon before the 1755 earthquake. An added attraction is the fact that it is situated in an old convent, the ornately decorated chapel of which is worth a visit in its own right. The free audio guide is well worth getting; while a little long-winded in places, it provides an excellent description of what you are seeing and its significance. When your feet grow tired, take a break in the wonderfully cool and relaxing garden attached to the cafe.Reachable by the 759 bus, a taxi is just as cheap for two people.This has been our most rewarding experience in Lisbon so far, and I highly recommend it.

Far from the city center, but worth the trip. This is a great museum. The Portuguese love their tiles. There were some spectacular peices. The museum has a lovely cafe and courtyard. Also the mosaic of Lisbon pre 1755 is not to be missed!
Disappointing. An acquired taste since everything is two dimensional and almost all the same color. We prefer ceramics. We were glad to visit but it was below our expectations.

Fantastic museum. What a beautiful place! The building and the exhibition, all great. The only low pint for me was the modern work, which seemed poor and lifeless when compared with the older azulejos. Don't miss the chapel when you are there, amazing, though some more information would be good as there's so much to see in there.

Great, unique museum. This museum was recommended to us and was really interesting. Lisbon has a lot of beautiful tile throughout and this gave us a chance to see different types and how it's changed through the years. I haven't seen tile museums before, so if you want something that's very Portugese, check it out.
Overview. Here you get a great overview over the history of the azulejos. The location is a bit separated from the city center, so you better take a taxi to visit it.
Well worth the visit. We loved this museum - the history of Portuguese tiles is beautifully presented. The tiles will delight you!

Great Museum. The word “azulejo” means ceramic tile. They have a national museum dedicated to the azulejo in a former convent, the Convent of the Mother of God. The outside of the convent is not imposing, but inside the convent one finds the huge chapel fascinating. The style is baroque and the walls of the chapel and ceiling are filled with huge paintings, all in gold colored frames. The artwork in the chapel is outstanding and impressive. We did not expect to see such a beautiful chapel. It is really a big church, and not a chapel. In the rooms of the former convent, one can see the history of the ceramic tile in Europe, especially in Portugal. The Portuguese became famous making ceramic tile with blue painted scenes. Some of the most beautiful tiles are found in this museum.

A collection of beauty!. Overwhelming collection of 'Azulejos'; which is seen in Lisbon and Portugal almost on and in every house. This museum has not only an amazing collection, but also gives you the history of one the things a visitor to Portugal remembers and admires most...

A walk back in history. Don't miss the tile museum with incredibly beautiful hand made ancient tiles depicting religious scenes, nature and LISBOA. There is a beautiful chapel as well and a sweet open air garden where you can enjoy a cafe'.

Original Museum, dedicated to an art that deserved such a space.. This museum is without a doubt a place not to miss. It is original; you won’t find many others in the world dedicated to this art. The building itself is beautiful; the courtyard is amazing not to say the church filled with golden details and paintings. The panels of tiles are beautiful, including some modern ones and the tile set of Lisbon before the earthquake is a precious and enormous set. The restaurant looks very nice with an esplanade but I didn’t stayed there.At Sunday until 2PM the entrance is free.

Inspiring visit. An amazing building with fantastic display of traditional Portuguese tiles...the setting is amazing and I found the history very interesting. There are also some tile displays by artists over the last few years - a little mix or art and history!
Recommended. Recommended, but a bit far out. There are buses (we took 794 from the north side of St Apolonia railway station) or take a taxi.

Hidden Gem. If you like tiles a visit here gives you a wonderful insight into the history of tile making in Portugal. At certain times you can also have a go at painting your own tile, which once fired will be posted to you - a novel way to remember Lisbon.

This museum wasn't on my short list... but. Was very glad we went. Portugal is all about the beautiful tile. Every where you go you see it used in so many ways, the sidewalks, walls, decor... tile. Why not see how they make it and the beauty up close. Photography is allowed. The setting is the old Convent of the Nuns of St. Claire. It makes the perfect place for the museum. It was an unexpected surprise to see the chapel and the blending of the tile work inside is a must see. Well done museum. Grab a bite in the cafe, there isn't much to eat in the area. It is simple fare but fresh and the outdoor cafe is enjoyable. Staff could learn to smile and be grateful for the tourist but it didn't take away from the meal.

For tile lovers. Like most other national museums and monuments in Lisbon, the Azulejo museum is free on Sunday mornings til 2pm. So go on a Sunday if you can. Its easy to get to from town - 794 bus from Comercio Square and takes about 10mins.The museum is set in a beautiful grand house, which is a sight in itself. There are many many rooms of tiles and good transitions between them with some explanations in English. This might be quite obvious, but you must really like tiles to visit. It also has a lovely outdoor cafe.

Breathtaking Museum and Church. This museum is a stop on the hop-on hop-off bus. Each room displays tiles and tile arrangements from many different buildings in Portugal. There were also several displays of 20th century tiles. One room had four pieces by Della Robbia which were made for the convent. Almost all of the displays have an English translation. The commentary for each room is also in English. The building itself is very interesting, especially the church and choir loft. A wedding was being held in the church; therefore, we got to view the wedding from the choir loft. That was very exciting. The restaurant in the courtyard is excellent. The food was great and the service was very good.
Azulejo Museum. Beautifully prepared exposition. Well explained history of azulejos. All exhibits are accessible for the blind :)
tiles.. museum is a find. been to lisbon many time but never here. it is well worth the trip.the tiles are in a monestary and that would be worth a visit.

Enjoyable but could have been more informative on 20thc tiles. Worth a trip if like me after a visit to Lisbon you've become a bit obsessive about tiles! But it would have been good to find out more about the 20thc. Designs - many of which are still on display in the streets in various states of disarray. Lovely coffee shop and garden. Disappointing gift store. Easy to get to on a bus from town centre.

A special place. Although a little difficult to find, you can take the bus (ask for the number) and get very close. It is well worth the visit. I especially liked the tiled view of Lisbon before the earthquake and the lunch in the garden there.

Great Museum, Off the Beaten Path. I really wanted to see this museum while in Lisbon. It's in a convent which makes it a beautiful setting for the tile displays. Loved the tile work and the chapel. It's rather inexpensive at 5 euros and not crowded. Great little gift shop, too! Great if you want to take a break from the more popular sites (and the crowds!).

Interesting Museum - Confusing layout. We enjoyed this Museum very much, especially the first section where they describe the tile making process. There is a great cafe and refreshing gardens as well. However we found the layout confusing as there is no guide available when purchasing your ticket (5 Euros at time of writing). The Chapel on the ground floor and the Panorama of Lisbon before the 1755 earthquake on the top floor are noteworthy, but the whole collection is interesting and varied.The easiest way to get there is by the 794 bus that drops you directly outside the Museum. Catch it from Praca do Comercio or the Terreiro Paco bus stops in town. Get off at stop Igreja Madre Deus and just cross the road. To get back into town the stop is to the right of the exit on the same side of the street.

Can be combined with Museu de Agua & a meal at a doca. While interesting, this is not like the Louvre where you can stay a week and not finish. With kids, we went to the Museu da Agua after (a short cab ride away as we did not really see any other public transport option). We had a meal at a doca near Sta. Apolinaria station after.

miles or tiles. A visit to the museum was one of the highlights of our visit to Lisboa. Tiles from the time the Moors occupied Lisbon to the present day and the exquisite Chapel of the Convent Madre de Deus.Some say it is difficult to find. Take the Metro to Santa Apolonia, exit the station away from the river and find the bus stop for buses going away from Lisbon. Ask the locals which number bus to take. the museum is 5-10 mind away.
Portugal on a tablet (made of clay). A very interesting place to visit, not to be missed in your itenery of your Lisboa trip. Easy to reach by bus using your Lisboa 24 h ticket.

Make the trip here--its worth it. This is a beautiful and interesting museum to visit. It was a little difficult to find and thanks to a VERY helpful bus driver and a lady getting off at the same stop we got there--not sure where we would have ended up without them. Lesson here--don't rely on Google directions for this one.
Unique museum. This museum was small, but it was very unique. It is worth a visit if you are interested in the Portuguese tiles.

A must of azulejos. Don't go east! just visit this museum and learn about an art that comes from the middle east, brought to this corner of Europe by the Arabs, many centuries ago. It's a blast of colour, of themes and stories. But ask for a Guide (like me) to learn about it!

Unexpectedly awesome. I wasn't sure I would enjoy visiting this museum but I knew it was worth the try, at least. In August, during the week of the Festival dos Oceanos, you have free entry in all the museums and attractions participating to it. It's a great way to explore places you don't know yet :)Well organised, in the most perfect environment, the exhibition will lead you all the way through the history of "azulejos" from the beginning. Since azulejos are so spread everywhere in Portugal, a visit here will make more sense than you could think.
Beautiful. The chapel inside is breathtaking. The vista of Lisbon wonderful too. Lovely stop.

A Must when in Lisbon. This is a wonderful museum and well worth a visit. The chapel there is stunning and has been kept in marvellous condition. We loved the tile mural on the top floor of Lisbon before the 1755 earthquake.
The art world of tiles. You will be amazed at the number and quality and tiles in this great museum that is near several other museums, including the must-see Fado Museum.
Very interesting. Different and enchanting, the history of the azulejo. Do not miss the huge panel at the 3rd floor. The audio guide helps understanding a little bit more and is free, so not to miss.

Beautiful Museum. Off the beaten path, but worth the extra effort! This museum shows the evolution of tiles through time. Don't miss the chapel and the huge panels showing Lisbon before the earthquake. The cafe is a great place to take a break for coffee or lunch!

Worth an hour long detour. Interesting museum with well explained exhibits set inside a lovely building. Probably a little too much on the historical side, the collection could definitely benefit by having more contemporary pieces I felt.The building also contains a quite stunning little church which is worth the admission money alone. There is not a great deal else in the area so I'd recommend a cab there and back.
Beautiful. There was a really good selection of displays. Lovely food in the cafe
Unusual and wonderful!. Didn't get to re-visit this year, but enjoyed it many years ago and treasure the little blue-and-while tile (azulejos) of a cherub that I bought there.

Bicycle Visit to the Tile Museum. We hired bicycles close to our hotel and cycled to this wonderful museum in an old monastery. The ride took only 20 minutes and was straight along the coast, with only one hill! It was a great way to combine things with some exercise.The museum was fascinating and just a lovely oasis of calm in the city, super restaurant where you could eat outside - fabulous service. The chapels within the museum are quite something - so ornately decorated with paintings and gold everywhere - and tiles everywhere too. We did very little sightseeing but I insisted on fitting this one in and it did no disappoint. Cycling back we discovered all sorts of amazing markets and little side alleys of the city which we would never otherwise have seen. Then we were bay by 2pm and in time for our cab to the castle and great evening out.

Great...if you are interested in tile.. This is a wonderful museaum that gives you the history of tile in Portugal with many rooms filled with examples. It is easy to get to by bus. We thought it was great because you could see the movement in styles throughout the centuries from the antique to the present. The setting is beautiful and it looked like there was a wonderful restaurant connected with it. There is also a beautiful church that is part of the complex, which is an old convent. Entrance is partially covered by the Lisboncard but it would have been a wonderful experience even if we had to pay full price.
We loved it!. a little out of the way, but is well worth it. Get an audioguide (included), and get to the chapel, it is unbeleivable!

gorgeous tiles in lovely setting. the museum is reachable with bus 28 and any buses that go along the coast. it's a little out of the way but worth a visit and can also be visited with the parque das narcoes which is not too far away. we started the tour on the top floor, so didn't really follow the exhibition which went through different periods, and there is an amazing panel showing the lisbon front in the time before the earthquake. throughout the building there are amazing examples of art on tiles - with patterns, figures, etc. there is information about tile making and how azulejos came to be an important part of portuguese culture. there is also an amazing church which is beautiful. when we were there it was not too busy so we were able to wander around quite freely and the cloister is a lovely, peaceful place and is worth spending some time in. for anyone who marvels at the azulejos they encounter in portugal, or anyone who appreciates beauty, this is the place to visit.

Enjoyable Visit to the Tile Museum. This was the only museum my husband and I ventured into during our May 2012 visit to Lisbon. The museum is a bit out of the way-it took us an hour to walk from Rossio square and we opted for a quick bus back to the square after our visit. The museum was free on Sunday morning till 2pm I believe. Interesting items to view and an amazing chapel area.

An unusual museum with beautiful tiles. We visited on a Sunday, and it was free until 2:00. The Tile Museum (Museu Nacional do Azulejo) was a former convent with incredible tiles on the walls everywhere. The state has now taken it over, preserved the tiles and converted many of the rooms into a museum with exhibitions about tile making and with many beautiful historical tiles. The Moors brought ceramic tile making into Portugal many centuries ago and it is still a major industry of Portugal. This museum is a great way to learn about this part of Portuguese heritage. We walked through many of the exhibitions and learned about ceramic tiles and tile making and then we arrived at something you should not miss. The Sala do Capitulo, or Chapter House, is a chapel where the nuns held their services. It is magnificent – the only church I have ever seen with incredible ceramic tiles on the walls, depicting religious scenes or just beautiful artwork.

Fascinating collection in an amazing building. This is an astonishing place to visit. The museum is located in a former convent which itself is extensively tiled -- so the visit consists of viewing both the tiles and exhibitions as well as the building and tiles in situ. There is a good explanation of the history of tile making, the tile making process and how tile making evolved over time. We now know how, when looking at a tiled wall, to distinguish the truly old tiles (with the three spots in the glaze) from later replacements (without those spots).There is a magnificent chapel (see attached photo) as well as an impressive cloister -- both extensively tiled. Walking the cloister one sees how the tiles were designed to give instruction and admonition to the women of the convent. (An example is in one of the attached photos.) However, as also shown in an attached photo, not all of the tiles on display are of a religious nature. (One of the most amusing is that of the Wedding of the Chicken.)The museum is a couple of miles east of the city center. One can reach it by a 20-minute walk from Santa Apolonia station or by bus 794 from Terreiro do Paco (just east of Praca do Comercio) or Santa Apolonia. Admission is included in the Lisboa Card. It is truly a worthwhile, and enjoyable, place to visit.

Stupendous collection. A taxi from the center cost 5 euros and it was well worth the trip. The building that houses the tiles is gorgeous--wonderful setting for the antique azuelos as well as newer tile creations.
What a museum... I with my wife went here last month. It is great experience to be there and watch the real art of Portugal. one must visit this place.

An absolute must!. We visited Lisbon for three weeks and had a chance to see many of the city´s museums during our stay. The Azulejo Museum was the favorite of the whole family, including our thirteen-year-old daughter. We particularly enjoy learning about the unique culture of the city or country we are visiting, and this museum fits the bill perfectly. The museum covers the whole history of azulejo tiles, from tiles with moorish influences through classic 16th and 17th styles to modern examples. An outstanding representation and overview of a vital element of Portuguese culture.In addition to the excellent exhibits on azulejos, the museum is set in a former convent, with a church and choir which are interesting rooms on their own. The courtyard restaurant is also very pleasant.

Far More Than I Expected. Having visited Portugal on several occasions, I have learned a lot about the azulejos and seen many examples, so I thought the Museu Nacional do Azulejo would be interesting for sure. However, if was far more than I expected, with not only wonderful exhibits but also beautifully decorated rooms and stairways that were amazing! A friend a I both enjoyed our visit there immensely and would recommend it to anyone who has an interest in museums and the culture and history of Lisbon and Portugal. We were not disappointed at all! It is especially interesting since it focuses on a subject that is different from what is found in most historical museums.

Good for lunch. The ambience with the 19th century foodie tiles was great and they produced a good snack for our lunch as we were visiting this and a number of other museums that day. Was a superb prelude to the wonderful museum with its many delights.
A great way to understand Portuguese style. Lovely museum that both educates while entertaining. Make sure not to miss the panorama of Lisbon before the earthquake.

If you like tiles worth to visit. If you like tiles and old tiles worth to visit. Full of especially old tiles with different design and arrangement. I was impressed. Must visit the tile panorama of the Lisbon: is oustanding. A bit dissapointed by the gift shop. I was expected to buy some tile with antique design, but no offer there.

Step back in time.... The old convent housing the National Tile Museum was a fascinating building, although in a slightly sketchy area of the city. The collection of tiles was interesting, but I found the tiles on the houses (as I walked throughout the city) to be just as neat.

Just beautiful. This museum is difficult to get to, but don't let that put you off. The tiles are absolutely beautiful, and the church is spectacular. A good introduction to the national craft of Portugal. The restaurant within it is also very good and reasonably priced.

More Interesting Than It Sounds - Hard to Find. I did not want to go here, but my mom wanted to and I was pleasantly surprised. After seeing the blue tiles all over the country this really helped understand more about them. It gave me an appreciation of the tiles. It can be a bit hard to get to as it is not in the tourist center but to the east of the historic center.
Worthwile although a bit off. This museum is interesting and well organized. The road there is a bit tedious but not too far.
azulejos in portugal. unique! so many different items, and the building is allready a worth a visit!
Very interesting. Although it's a bummer to get to (get your concierge to explain because you won't find it on your own!), this is a very interesting museum to see at the end of your stay....
Nothing Like this elsewhere. I didn't expect to find this so fascinating. This is truly unique--you won't see this sort of sort anywhere else. Manageable size.

Well worth the effort to get there. I suppose one has to like Portuguese tiles to want to come here - but we do - and the collection is magnificent. Even if you don't it will be worth coming for the building which houses them - the former Madre de Deus Convent which is full of wonders. We particularly liked a beautiful 18c 'crib' (a nativity scene crammed with little vignettes of 18c country life as well as the usual shepherds, wise men and Holy Family) made for the nuns and still looking fresh.

Tiles, tiles, tiles.... If you like the typical Portugese tiles this one is for you. You need about 45 min to get a quick glance at everything. This one is especially worth visiting because of the tiled church they have integrated into the museum. After all this has been a monestary.

Gorgeous museum. Not only is the collection of exquisite quality, but the building it is housed in is gorgeous, too. The museum has a wonderful, wonderful restaurant located in a courtyard garden that is not to be missed. One of the very best museums I've ever been to.

A stunning baroque convent and church containing a fascinating museum. Tiles are a feature of Lisbon, and this museum tells you about them, and shows a large historical selection, but it's the building itself that is really special. It is an old convent, with excellent tiles in its cloisters, and a staggering church, where every surface that isn't tiled is either painted or gilt. The best exhibit as such is the 18 metre long tile panorama of Lisbon before the 1755 earthquake, which really helps understand the city. Also not to be missed is the convent's 18th century crib set, in the tiled St.Anthony chapel. The cafe is very good as well.
History of Portugese Tiles. Fantastic if you are into tiles. If not, then go somewhere else.
Certainly worth the effort getting there. A beautiful, old building houses a fantastic collection.
A must!. Should be on anyone's top ten list of what to see and do in Lisbon!
go for the building as much as the tiles!. Really super museum with good English audio guide. Excellent cafeteria

terrific convent and azulejos collection. thank you to the reception desk to have suggested a free guided tour in french. We got excellent explanation from a passionnate volunteer. Both the azulejos collection and the magnificent convent/ church worth a 2 1/2 hour guided visit. (Put a warm coat on in winter)
Go and see. these tiles are very picturesque and worth to see. You will find out how it is made and how they achieve this special blue color
Fascinating. Unusual and fascinating...Worth going out of one's way to learn the craft and history behind the ubiquitous tiles

Museum located in old Convent. The Museu do Azulejo is located in the former convent Madre de Deus (Order of Saint Clare). Not only the collection of tiles but also the building itself deserves our attention. There are two cloisters (one in Manueline style), an upper and lower choir, a richly decorated church and a chapterroom.The permanent collection starts with an explanation of the different production methods. Then some rooms are dedicated to the early Hispano-Moresque Tiles. The next rooms are dedicated to the early Portuguese tiles. Other rooms show the Oriental influence.....Finally on the top floor there is the Panoramic View of Lisbon that shows us the city before the great earthquake.

Five Hundred Years of Astonishing Tiles. About the first thing a new tourist in Lisbon notices is the vast volume of tile on both the inside and outside of (almost) all the buildings. Very attractive, very distinctive. The Museum traces the history of tiles in Portugal, including a very wide array of displayed tiles, both decorative and artistic, and some thoroughly informative displays on how they're made. The museum is inside a former convent, in the visit, and it is spectacularly beautiful, including the church altars and paintings on the walls and ceilings. One real highlight, up on the top floor, is a panoramic view of pre-earthquake Lisbon, all done in painted tiles. Many present day landmarks are still readily visible in the panorama, as well the depiction of many churches and buildings that were destroyed in the earthquake. We figured we'd spend an hour at the Tile Museum. We ended up spending about three very entertaining hours there. A must-see in Lisbon!

It is interesting. For me it was interesting what I had seen. Different tiles (it was my first time I saw this kind of tiles). I really liked them as I have liked the building all over Lisboa, as well as Porto, decorated with them. I liked also the modern option of tiles.

A travel into history. This museum is a old monastery in a old part of the town that used to be far away of the city center when it was built. Inside we travel along the history of the portuguese tiles. We can observe fantastic tile panels along the walls, showing how they were important in the portuguese culture

Surprised how much I enjoyed this. OK, so you have to be interested in tiles, and I had very very low expectations - but I was surprised how much I enjoyed all the tiles from different eras, and especially modern artists. The best was the huge tile painting of old Lisbon, where you could pick out the structures from a few hundred years ago that had stayed around, and those that had appeared later, or disappeared altogether. Altogether very enjoyable and surprising!
Interesting overview. You really get a feel for the evolution of tile making, a very important cultural development for the Portuguese

No visit to Lisboa is complete w/a stop here!. The 'tile' museum (aka azulejo) is a great way to gain a better understanding of the beautiful buildings that grace the cities! While we generally use tile INside our homes, so many bldgs have them on the exterior - in brilliant colors and patterns. Worthy of a visit to learn more about the different patterns and history. The tiles are ubiquitous throughout Portugal. This museum will give a deeper appreciation for the architecture/buildings as you enjoy your stay. Very well done and only requires a couple hours of time. worth it!

Stunning, worth a trip!. I loved the tile museum. Very manageable size, interesting exhibits and a lovely outdoor dining area covered by a canopy. Food is affordable compared to other museum cafe prices. Don't miss the tile mural of Lisbon on the top floor, it is a must see!

Some disinterested rude staff but quite interesting.. OK cafe space for coffee also. Informative overview and explantions but could have done with a little more english. Poor merchandising choice in shop. I am not a fan of over ornate catholic churches- so this part was not for me.

Tile museum in the city of tiles, a good one too. Whereever one goes in Lisbon, especially in the old parts of the city, one can never miss tiles. This museum gives a very good history of tile industry. A good place to visit.

Worth a Visit. While not one of the best known museums in Lisboa, the Tile Museum is fascinating. It displays one the art forms for which the Portuguese are justifiably world famous, but this is definitely NOT the place for children; they'll be totally bored. It's easy to see this and the National Coach Museum, another worthwhile visit, in the same day. I'd recommend them both with moderate enthusiasm.

Only for experts. I went to the Museum because I received a free ticket. I did not find anything what would be interesting for me - non expert. In addition there is only very limited information in English.

Glad we went. It's a little out of the way, but worth the visit. Portugal is famous for its tile, especially the blue and white. The museum has a large collection which is shown in a chronological fashion. It was helpful in viewing tile in other attractions during our trip. Also has a nice restaurant. The building, a convent, is lovely. Don't miss the church!

Amazing. We almost didn't go to this museum, having seen tiles all over Lisbon, but at the last minute at almost the end of the day, we decided to make the trip to this museum. We were blown away by the Madre de Deus Convent. Having been to the Vatican, I can say that this convent rivals the Vatican in beauty and grandeur. We would never have known about this, as no one in Lisbon mentioned the Convent, but did tell us we should see the Tile Museum. I highly recommend a visit; it is truly magnificent.

So much more than just tiles!. We almost skipped this, but I'm so glad we went! Sure, you can see gorgeous tile, learn about the origins, how it's made (very interesting as described), but this place is worth seeing just for the incredible chapel. Picture the most ornate one you've seen and add a ton of tile work-- it adds beauty and serenity, definitely worth seeing. BONUS: if you think "relics" are interesting, then this is the place for you! In a small chapel, dozens of different little statues with glass containers built-in house various pieces of bones. Really fascinating. Museum visit takes about an hour and you should plan on 15-20 minutes each way from city center via bus or tram.

You really can't miss. If you visit Lisboa, you will see that there are tiles everywhere. So, the best place to learn more about the tradicional tiles, and see an amazing collection of old and beautiful tiles, you must go to Museu do Azulejo. Located in the old Monastery of the Mother of God, from the beggining of the XVI century, with a magnificent church covered in gold, this is a remarkable museum.

Do not miss this lovely tile museum!. As you explore Lisbon, you might have noticed that tiles adorn numerous facades of buildings or metro walls. This lovely museum housed in the premises of a former convent, offers a glimpse into the technique of tile making and its origins in Portugal. The museum presents the chronological evolution of tile art over the years from flat ones to those with elaborate shapes and contoured surfaces. Do not miss the 36-m long tile panel depicting a scene of Lisbon before the earthquake. The museum also offers access to an interesting baroque chapel decorated with tiles. The Museum can be reached by a short taxi ride(about 10 mins) from Baixa.

Interesting in beautiful old convent. We loved this museum for its interesting, inspiring and beautiful displays of tiles and for the setting, in an old convent. End the visit with a coffee or light meal in the pleasant café in the green museum inner yard. If you are interested in tiles this museum is highly recommendable, and even if you are not, you will enjoy the cool vibe of MNAz. Buses stop right outside of the museum or on the main road below, but a taxi is only around 6 euros from Baixa.
Amazing!. I wondered why the Lonely Planet quide suggested going to a tile museum! However, it is worth it to see the majestic Chapel - the ceiling and the woodwork is breathtaking.

A great experience in Lisbon. A great experience! It was surprise for us! Museu do Azulejo is really interesting! You can find all the aspects about azulejo manufacture (that is incredible). It should be add in a tourism rout when visit Lisbon!

Beautiful Museum in a fabulous setting.. This was not my first choice for a visit but we went with friends who really were interested in tiles and it was a great find. The museum is interesting with beautiful examples of tiles through the centuries. It is attached to a catholic girls school with a small but stunning church including lovely tilework. It is a bit difficult to locate so be sure you know where you are going. It really helps you appreciate all the beautiful tile buildings you see throughout Lisbon.

This is a great museum. If you have already seen lots of museums you get to the point where you only want to go if it has something really special. This one does. Azulejos are tiles. You find them all over the middle east, the Mediterranean countries, and in Latin America. The ones in Portugal are beautiful and decorate rooms and buildings all over the country. This museum tells you about them and shows lots of examples of very historical and beautiful ones. Plus the museum is located in a former convent which is nice to see on it's own. The tiles also make wonderful gifts to take home.
